primary: He was three years above me
example:
A: You know Dave?
B: Yeah, he was three years above me in high school.
A: Did you guys hang out?
B: Not really, since he was three years above me.
A: He seems older.
B: He is, he was three years above me in college.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は３（みっ）つ年上（としうえ）だった。／３（さん）学年（がくねん）先輩（せんぱい）だった。
chinese: 他比我高三届 (Tā bǐ wǒ gāo sān jiè) / 他大我三岁 (Tā dà wǒ sān suì)
spanish: Me saca tres años / Iba tres cursos por delante

primary: She was three years below me
example:
A: Who's that girl?
B: Emily. She was three years below me in school.
A: So she's younger?
B: Yeah, she was three years below me.
A: I barely knew anyone who was three years below me.
B: Different crowds, makes sense.
japanese: 彼女（かのじょ）は３（みっ）つ年下（としした）だった。／３（さん）学年（がくねん）後輩（こうはい）だった。
chinese: 她比我低三届 (Tā bǐ wǒ dī sān jiè) / 她小我三岁 (Tā xiǎo wǒ sān suì)
spanish: Es tres años menor que yo / Iba tres cursos por detrás

example:
A: I guessed she was 25.
B: You are way off, she's 40.
A: Is the answer 100?
B: Way off. Try 1000.
A: His estimate for the project was way off.
B: Yeah, we're over budget now.
japanese: 全然（ぜんぜん）違（ちが）う。／大（おお）ハズレ。
chinese: 差远了 (Chà yuǎn le) / 完全不着边 (Wánquán bùzháo biān)
spanish: Ni de lejos / Estás muy equivocado

example:
A: I gotta use the bathroom. Save my seat.
B: Got you, be quick though.
A: Can you save my seat while I grab a drink?
B: Sure, but if Beyonce walks in, she gets it.
A: Did you save my seat?
B: I tried, but some guy just sat down.
japanese: 席（せき）取（と）っておいて。／ここキープしておいて。
chinese: 帮我占个座 (Bāng wǒ zhàn gè zuò) / 帮我留个位子 (Bāng wǒ liú gè wèizi)
spanish: Guárdame el sitio / No dejes que nadie se siente ahí

meaning: 방사 유정란 / 풀어 키운 닭이 낳은 알
example:
A: Why are these eggs 8 dollars?
B: They're pasture raised eggs, top tier.
A: I only buy pasture raised eggs now.
B: Boujee! But do they taste better?
A: Pasture raised eggs have orange yolks, it's wild.
B: Nutrient density, fam.
japanese: 平飼（ひらガ）い卵（たまご）。／放（はな）し飼（ガ）いの卵（たまご）。
chinese: 散养蛋 (Sànyǎng dàn) / 柴鸡蛋 (Cháijīdàn)
spanish: Huevos de corral / Huevos camperos

meaning: 딱 촉이 와 / 왠지 그럴 것 같아
example:
A: You think he's lying?
B: Yeah, I have a gut feeling.
A: Why did you turn left?
B: I have a gut feeling this is a shortcut.
A: Don't trust that deal.
B: Same, I have a gut feeling it's a scam.
japanese: なんとなくそんな気（き）がする。／ピンときた。
chinese: 我有预感 (Wǒ yǒu yùgǎn) / 我直觉很准 (Wǒ zhíjué hěn zhǔn)
spanish: Tengo un presentimiento / Me da buena espina (o mala espina)

example:
A: Why is she asking so many questions?
B: She's such a busybody, ignore her.
A: Don't be a busybody, let them live.
B: I'm just curious!
A: Our neighbor is a total busybody.
B: Always watching from the window, right?
japanese: お節介（せっかい）。／出（で）しゃばり。
chinese: 爱管闲事的人 (Ài guǎn xiánshì de rén) / 事儿妈 (Shìrmā)
spanish: Un metomentodo / Un cotilla

primary: Don't get me started on her boyfriend
meaning: 걔 남친 얘기는 꺼내지도 마 / 말도 마라
example:
A: Is she still with that guy?
B: Don't get me started on her boyfriend, he's the worst.
A: I heard they fought.
B: Don't get me started on her boyfriend, drama 24/7.
A: Is he nice?
B: Girl, don't get me started on her boyfriend.
japanese: 彼（かれ）の話（はなし）はしないで。／彼（かれ）の話（はなし）を始（はじ）めると止（と）まらなくなる。
chinese: 别跟我提她男朋友 (Bié gēn wǒ tí tā nánpéngyou) / 提她男朋友我就烦 (Tí tā nánpéngyou wǒ jiù fán)
spanish: Ni me hables de su novio / Mejor no toquemos ese tema

example:
A: It's raining on our beach day.
B: It can't be helped, let's go to a museum.
A: The flight is delayed.
B: It can't be helped, grab a beer?
A: I wish I could fix it.
B: It can't be helped, don't stress.
japanese: 仕方（しかた）がない。／しょうがない。
chinese: 没办法 (Méi bànfǎ) / 这也是没办法的事 (Zhè yěshì méibànfǎ de shì)
spanish: No se puede hacer nada / Es inevitable

example:
A: Why did you take that job?
B: Out of necessity, bills were piling up.
A: She learned to cook out of necessity.
B: Yeah, takeout gets expensive.
A: We moved here out of necessity.
B: Gotta go where the work is.
japanese: 必要（ひつよう）に迫（せま）られて。／背（せ）に腹（はら）は代（か）えられない。
chinese: 出于必要 (Chūyú bìyào) / 迫不得已 (pò bù dé yǐ)
spanish: Por necesidad / No quedó más remedio

meaning: 다른 방법이 없어 / 선택의 여지가 없어
example:
A: You really sold your car?
B: I had no other choice, needed the cash.
A: Why did you agree?
B: No other choice, they pressured me.
A: We have no other choice but to walk.
B: Ugh, my feet already hurt.
japanese: 他（ほか）に選択肢（せんたくし）がない。／そうするしかなかった。
chinese: 别无选择 (Bié wú xuǎnzé) / 没得选 (méi de xuǎn)
spanish: No tenía otra opción / Fue lo único que pude hacer

meaning: 네가 말을 꺼내서 하는 얘긴데 / 말이 나온 김에
example:
A: This room is messy.
B: Since you bring it up, you never clean either.
A: We need to save money.
B: Since you bring it up, stop buying coffee.
A: He seems distracted.
B: Since you bring it up, I noticed that too.
japanese: そう言（い）われてみれば。／話（はなし）のついでだけど。
chinese: 既然你提到了 (Jìrán nǐ tídào le) / 说到这儿 (shuō dào zhèr)
spanish: Ya que lo mencionas / Hablando de eso

meaning: 그냥 대충 하는 거야 / 영혼 없이 하는 중이야
example:
A: You like your job?
B: Nah, I'm just going through the motions.
A: You seem checked out.
B: Yeah, I'm just going through the motions lately.
A: Is he serious about her?
B: Doesn't look like it, he's just going through the motions.
japanese: ただ惰性（だせい）でやってるだけ。／心（こころ）こもってないね。
chinese: 我只是走个过场 (Wǒ zhǐshì zǒu gè guòchǎng) / 应付一下 (yìngfù yīxià)
spanish: Lo hago por inercia / Lo hago sin ganas

primary: I'm not the type to regret things easily
meaning: 나 원래 쉽게 후회 안 해
example:
A: Do you regret dating him?
B: Nah, I'm not the type to regret things easily.
A: You spent a lot on that bag.
B: Worth it. I'm not the type to regret things easily.
A: That was a risky move.
B: I live for it. I'm not the type to regret things easily.
japanese: 私（わたし）、あんまり後悔（こうかい）しないタイプなんだ。／済（す）んだことは気（き）にしない。
chinese: 我不是那种容易后悔的人 (Wǒ bùshì nàzhǒng róngyì hòuhuǐ de rén) / 我很少后悔 (wǒ hěn shǎo hòuhuǐ)
spanish: No soy de los que se arrepienten fácilmente / No suelo mirar atrás

example:
A: Wanna get dinner?
B: Let's hit that conveyor belt sushi spot.
A: Conveyor belt sushi is fun but dangerous.
B: Yeah, I stack up plates without noticing.
A: Is the fish fresh at conveyor belt sushi?
B: Hit or miss, but it's cheap.
japanese: 回転（かいてん）寿司（ずし）。／くるくる寿司（ずし）。
chinese: 回转寿司 (Huízhuǎn shòusī) / 旋转寿司 (xuánzhuǎn shòusī)
spanish: Sushi giratorio / Sushi de cinta

example:
A: No cilantro on my tacos, please.
B: It tastes like soap to you?
A: I love cilantro, pile it on.
B: You're lucky, I can't stand it.
A: This salsa has too much cilantro.
B: Perfect for me, pass it here.
japanese: パクチー。／香菜（シャンツァイ）。
chinese: 香菜 (Xiāngcài) / 芫荽 (yán suī)
spanish: Cilantro / Culantro

example:
A: He texted me out of the blue.
B: After ghosting you? The audacity.
A: It started raining out of the blue.
B: NYC weather is bipolar.
A: She quit her job out of the blue.
B: Must have been fed up.
japanese: 突然（とつぜん）。／急（きゅう）に。
chinese: 突然 (Tūrán) / 冷不丁 (lěng bù dīng)
spanish: De la nada / Inesperadamente

primary: I'll get out of your hair.
meaning: 이제귀찮게 안 할게 / 방해 안 하고 갈게
example:
A: Thanks for the help, I'm busy now.
B: Cool, I'll get out of your hair.
A: I need to finish this report.
B: Alright, I'll get out of your hair then.
A: Stay for dinner?
B: Nah, I'll get out of your hair, you look tired.
japanese: 邪魔（じゃま）しないようにするね。／お暇（いとま）するね。
chinese: 我就不打扰你了 (Wǒ jiù bù dǎrǎo nǐ le) / 我不麻烦你了 (wǒ bù máfan nǐ le)
spanish: Te dejo tranquilo / No te molesto más

primary: Give a big round of applause to ~
example:
A: Give a big round of applause to our guest!
B: *Clapping loudly*
A: Next up, give a big round of applause to DJ Khalid!
B: Another one!
A: Let's give a big round of applause to the chef.
B: The food was fire, he deserves it.
japanese: 〜に盛大（せいだい）な拍手（はくしゅ）を。／〜に大（おお）きな拍手（はくしゅ）をお願（ねが）いします。
chinese: 把掌声送给... (Bǎ zhǎngshēng sòng gěi...) / 让我们为...鼓掌 (ràng wǒmen wèi... gǔzhǎng)
spanish: Un fuerte aplauso para / Démosle un gran aplauso a

meaning: 할 말이 좀 있어 / 상의할 게 있어
example:
A: Can we meet? I have something to discuss.
B: Sounds serious. What's up?
A: I have something to discuss regarding the lease.
B: Ugh, they raising the rent?
A: Hey, I have something to discuss about last night.
B: Oh no, was I embarrassing?
japanese: 話（はなし）があるんだけど。／相談（そうだん）したいことがある。
chinese: 我有事想跟你谈谈 (Wǒ yǒu shì xiǎng gēn nǐ tántán) / 我有事想商量 (wǒ yǒu shì xiǎng shāngliáng)
spanish: Tengo algo que comentar / Hay algo que quiero hablar contigo

primary: Who are you to say that
similar: 2. Since when are you the expert?
example:
A: You really shouldn't eat so much junk food.
B: Who are you to say that?
A: I'm just looking out for your health.
B: Look who's talking, you had pizza for breakfast!
A: Okay, fair point, I'm the pot calling the kettle black.
B: Exactly, so let me enjoy my fries in peace.
japanese: どの口（くち）が言（い）うか。／よく言（い）うよ。
chinese: 你凭什么这么说 (Nǐ píng shénme zhème shuō) / 轮得到你说吗 (lúndédào nǐ lái shuō ma)
spanish: ¿Quién eres tú para decir eso? / Mira quién habla

primary: Let's clear up any misunderstandings before we go
example:
A: Let's clear up any misunderstandings before we go.
B: Agreed, I don't want weird vibes.
A: I think you took that the wrong way.
B: Let's clear up any misunderstandings before we go then.
A: We good?
B: Yeah, glad we cleared up any misunderstandings before we go.
japanese: 行（い）く前（まえ）に誤解（ごかい）を解（と）いておこう。／はっきりさせておこう。
chinese: 咱们把误会解开 (Zánmen bǎ wùhuì jiěkāi) / 咱们把话说清楚 (zánmen bǎ huà shuō qīngchu)
spanish: Aclaremos las cosas antes de irnos / Vamos a resolver el malentendido

meaning: 그냥 하는 말이야 / 내 말은 그렇다는 거지
example:
A: That shirt is... bright.
B: You don't like it?
A: I'm just saying, it's loud.
B: Hater.
A: He's not gonna change. I'm just saying.
B: I know, but I love him.
japanese: ただ言（い）ってみただけ。／独（ひと）り言（ごと）だよ。
chinese: 我只是随便说说 (Wǒ zhǐshì suíbiàn shuōshuo) / 别当真 (bié dāngzhēn)
spanish: Solo lo digo / Es un comentario, nada más

example:
A: You were happy five minutes ago.
B: I know, I'm very moody.
A: Don't take it personal, she's very moody.
B: Hard to keep up with her.
A: I need chocolate when I'm very moody.
B: Note taken.
japanese: 私（わたし）、気（き）分屋（ぶんや）なんだ。／感情（かんじょう）の起伏（きふく）が激（はげ）しくて。
chinese: 我很情绪化 (Wǒ hěn qíngxùhuà) / 我喜怒无常 (xǐnùwúcháng)
spanish: Soy muy temperamental / Tengo muchos altibajos emocionales

example:
A: My phone is acting up.
B: Did you try turning it off and on?
A: My knee is acting up again.
B: Getting old, huh?
A: The car is acting up.
B: Mechanic time, prepare your wallet.
japanese: 調子（ちょうし）が悪（わる）い。／暴（あば）れ出（だ）した。
chinese: 出毛病了 (Chū máobìng le) / 闹脾气了 (nào píqì le)
spanish: Está fallando / Me está dando problemas

example:
A: The elevator is broken.
B: That's really inconvenient, we live on the 10th floor.
A: Cash only?
B: Yeah, that's really inconvenient.
A: They rescheduled the meeting to Friday at 6pm.
B: That's really inconvenient for my weekend plans.
japanese: それは不便（ふべん）だね。／面倒（めんどう）くさいね。
chinese: 真不方便 (Zhēn bù fāngbiàn) / 太麻烦了 (tài máfán le)
spanish: Es muy inoportuno / Qué molestia

meaning: 인생 즐기면서 살아 / 후회 없이 살아
example:
A: She travels every month.
B: She really lives life to the fullest.
A: Why save it for a special occasion?
B: Exactly, live life to the fullest.
A: I want to live life to the fullest, no regrets.
B: Start by booking that ticket.
japanese: 人生（じんせい）を謳歌（おうか）する。／思（おも）いっきり生（い）きる。
chinese: 尽情享受生活 (Jìnqíng xiǎngshòu shēnghuó) / 活得精彩 (huó de jīngcǎi)
spanish: Vivir la vida al máximo / Disfrutar a tope

example:
A: You okay?
B: Don't talk to me, I'm in a food coma.
A: That thanksgiving dinner put me in a food coma.
B: Same, napping immediately.
A: I can't work, I'm in a food coma.
B: The post-lunch slump is real.
japanese: 食（た）べ過（す）ぎて動（うご）けない。／満腹（まんぷく）で眠（ねむ）い。
chinese: 饭气攻心 (Fànqì gōngxīn) / 吃饱了犯困 (chī bǎo le fànkùn)
spanish: Me ha dado el mal del puerco / Estoy que exploto de lleno

example:
A: Dinner at 8?
B: Sounds like a plan.
A: We finish this, then we drink.
B: Sounds like a plan to me.
A: Meet at the park.
B: Sounds like a plan, see you there.
japanese: いいね。／それで決（き）まり。
chinese: 听起来不错 (Tīng qǐlái bùcuò) / 就这么办 (jiù zhème bàn)
spanish: Me parece bien / Trato hecho

primary: This is not a knee-jerk reaction.
meaning: 욱해서 그러는 거 아냐 / 충동적인 거 아냐
example:
A: Are you sure you want to quit?
B: Yes, this is not a knee-jerk reaction. I've been unhappy for months.
A: You're breaking up with him?
B: It's verified. This is not a knee-jerk reaction.
A: Selling the house seems sudden.
B: It's not. This is not a knee-jerk reaction.
japanese: 衝動的（しょうどうてき）なことじゃないよ。／よく考（かんガ）えた上（うえ）でのことだよ。
chinese: 这不是一时冲动 (Zhè bùshì yīshí chōngdòng) / 这是考虑过的 (zhè shì kǎolǜ guò de)
spanish: No es una reacción impulsiva / Lo he pensado bien

primary: Its not going through the motions
meaning: 그냥 대충 하는 거 아냐 / 진심이야
example:
A: Does he really love her?
B: Yeah, it's not going through the motions with them.
A: You practice hard.
B: I want to win, it's not going through the motions.
A: This apology feels real.
B: It is, it's not going through the motions.
japanese: 形式的（けいしきてき）にやってるわけじゃない。／本気（ほんき）でやってる。
chinese: 我可不是应付了事 (Wǒ kě bùshì yìngfù liǎoshì) / 我很当回事 (wǒ hěn dāng huí shì)
spanish: No es solo por cumplir / Lo hago de verdad

example:
A: Are you really moving to Japan next month?
B: I told you, I mean business about this move.
A: I thought you were just dreaming again.
B: No, I'm dead serious, I already bought the ticket.
A: Wow, you're not playing around this time.
B: Nope, it's time to get down to brass tacks and pack.
japanese: 本気（ほんき）だよ。／遊（あそ）びじゃない。
chinese: 我是认真的 (Wǒ shì rènzhēn de) / 我不是在开玩笑 (wǒ bùshì zài kāiwánxiào)
spanish: Voy en serio / No estoy bromeando

primary: Are you up for the dinner?
example:
A: We're going to K-town.
B: Nice.
A: Are you up for the dinner?
B: Always down for K-BBQ.
A: Are you up for the dinner later?
B: Depends on where we going.
japanese: 夕飯（ゆうはん）どう？／ご飯（はん）行（い）く元気（げんき）ある？
chinese: 你想一起吃晚饭吗 (Nǐ xiǎng yīqǐ chī wǎnfàn ma) / 赏光一起吃个饭吗 (shǎngguāng yīqǐ chī gè fàn ma)
spanish: ¿Te apuntas a cenar? / ¿Te hace una cena?

meaning: 나도 그러고 싶은데 (못 해) / 맘은 굴뚝같은데
example:
A: Come to fast!
B: I wish I could, but I have work.
A: Be there in 10?
B: I wish I could, traffic is crazy.
A: Buy the shoes!
B: I wish I could, but my bank account says no.
japanese: 行（い）きたいのは山々（やまやま）だけど。／そうできればいいんだけど。
chinese: 我也想去，但不行 (Wǒ yě xiǎng qù, dàn bùxíng) / 倒是想去，可是有事 (dàoshì xiǎng qù, kěshì yǒushì)
spanish: Ojalá pudiera / Me encantaría, pero no puedo

example:
A: Is the party for everyone?
B: Yeah, bring your significant others.
A: No significant others allowed on boys' night.
B: Fair rule.
A: Do you have a significant other?
B: Nope, riding solo.
japanese: パートナー。／大切（たいせつ）な人（ひと）。
chinese: 另一半 (Lìngyī bàn) / 家属 (jiāshǔ)
spanish: Parejas / Medias naranjas

example:
A: Can you pass the salt?
B: Sure thing.
A: Thanks for the ride.
B: Sure thing, anytime.
A: Watch my bag?
B: Sure thing, go ahead.
japanese: もちろん。／いいよ。
chinese: 没问题 (Méi wèntí) / 当然可以 (dāngrán kěyǐ)
spanish: Dalo por hecho / Claro que sí

example:
A: I forgot my wallet.
B: Don't stress, I got you.
A: I need a ride home.
B: I got you, hop in.
A: Keep this a secret.
B: I got you, lips sealed.
japanese: 任（まか）せて。／了解（りょうかい）。
chinese: 我帮你 (Wǒ bāng nǐ) / 包在我身上 (bāo zài wǒ shēnshang)
spanish: Yo me encargo / Déjamelo a mí

example:
A: Can I get a napkins?
B: Here you are.
A: Where's my phone?
B: Here you are, you left it on the table.
A: One iced coffee please.
B: Here you are, enjoy.
japanese: はい、どうぞ。／これだね。
chinese: 给你 (Gěi nǐ) / 拿着 (názhe)
spanish: Aquí tienes / Aquí está

example:
A: We should applaud her effort.
B: Yeah, she tried hard.
A: I applaud your honesty.
B: Truth hurts, but needed to be said.
A: Everyone stood up to applaud.
B: Standing ovation vibes.
japanese: 拍手（はくしゅ）する。／称賛（しょうさん）する。
chinese: 鼓掌 (Gǔzhǎng) / 喝彩 (hècǎi)
spanish: Aplaudir / Elogiar

meaning: 내 말 똑똑히 들어 / 잘 들어
example:
A: Can I borrow money?
B: Read my lips: No.
A: Are you sure?
B: Read my lips, I am not going.
A: Maybe next time?
B: Read my lips: Never.
japanese: よーく聞（き）いて。／言（い）っとくけど。
chinese: 听好了 (Tīng hǎo le) / 仔细听 (zǐxì tīng)
spanish: Escúchame bien / Léeme los labios

example:
A: You still play video games?
B: Yeah, I'm young at heart.

A: Maybe you'd prefer a more creative role. 
B: I think so, this definitely isn't my calling.
japanese: 私（わたし）には向（む）いてない
chinese: 我不适合 (Wǒ bù shìhé) / 我不是这块料 (Wǒ bùshì zhè kuài liào)
spanish: No valgo para esto / No estoy hecho para esto

example:

B: What a bummer! I was so excited.
A: I know, I even bought a new outfit for it. 
B: That really sucks, we've been waiting for months.

B: True, but it's still a major drag.

chinese: 真扫兴 (Zhēn sǎoxìng) / 太令人遗憾了 (Tài lìng rén yíhàn le)
spanish: Qué fastidio / Qué bajón

example:

B: I know, it's really starting to get on my nerves.
A: Should we ask him to stop? 
B: It's been driving me crazy all morning. 
A: I'll go say something politely. 
B: Thanks, it's really grating on me too.

chinese: 让我心烦 (Ràng wǒ xīnfán) / 触动我的神经 (Chùdòng wǒ de shénjīng)
spanish: Me saca de quicio / Me pone de los nervios

meaning: 나를 좀 인정해 줘 / 나를 너무 무시하지 마
example:

B: I've done this dozens of times, I'm not that clueless. 
A: My bad, I didn't mean to doubt you. 
B: Thanks, just acknowledge my experience once in a while.
japanese: もう少（すこ）し信用（しんよう）してよ／見直（みなお）してよ
chinese: 给我点面子 (Gěi wǒ diǎn miànzi) / 承认我的努力 (Chéngrèn wǒ de nǔlì)
spanish: Dame algo de crédito / Reconócemelo

example:

B: I just found myself in a position to move and took it.
A: It must have been a big change. 
B: It was, but I landed in a great neighborhood. 
A: I'd love to wind up in a city like that someday. 
B: You should, it's an incredible place to find yourself facing new challenges.
japanese: 気（き）づいたら〜にいた／〜という状況（じょうきょう）に陥（おちい）る
chinese: 发现自己处于 (Fāxiàn zìjǐ chǔyú) / 偶然陷入 (Ǒurán xiànrù)
spanish: Verme en / Encontrarme en

similar: 1. If you're in the mood to
example:

B: If you ever feel like joining, let me know. 
A: I’m not really in the mood to work out today. 
B: No worries, if you're up for it tomorrow, just call. 
A: Thanks, I might take you up on that. 
B: Great, the offer stands whenever you're ready.
japanese: もし〜したくなったら／気（き）が向（む）いたら
chinese: 如果你什么时候想 (Rúguǒ nǐ shénme shíhòu xiǎng) / 只要你愿意 (Zhǐyào nǐ yuànyì)
spanish: Si alguna vez te apetece... / Si te dan ganas de...

example:
A: We’re falling behind on the marketing plan. 
B: We really need to keep things on track. 
A: Let's set some strict deadlines for each phase. 
B: Good idea, we can't afford to get sidetracked now. 
A: I’ll send out the updated schedule today. 
B: Perfect, let's stay on target and finish this.
japanese: 順調（じゅんちょう）に進（すす）める／脱線（だっせん）させない
chinese: 确保一切顺利 (Quèbǎo yīqiè shùnlì) / 步入正轨 (Bù rù zhèngguǐ)
spanish: Mantener el rumbo / Que no se desmadre

primary: Stop complaining / don't be so dramatic / cry me a river
meaning: 불평 좀 그만해 / 오버하지 마 / 어디 한번 실컷 짜보시지
example:
A: This line is taking forever, my life is over! 
B: Oh, cry me a river, it’s only been five minutes. 
A: But I have so much to do today! 
B: Stop being so dramatic and just wait. 
A: You’re so insensitive to my suffering. 
B: Seriously, quit your whining and look at your phone.
japanese: 文句（もんく）言（い）うな／大袈裟（おおげさ）にするな／泣（な）き言（ごと）は聞（き）きたくない
chinese: 别抱怨了 (Bié bàoyuàn le) / 有什么好哭的 (Yǒu shénme hǎo kū de)
spanish: Deja de quejarte / A llorar a la llorería

meaning: 내가 총대를 멜게 / 비난은 내가 감수할게
example:
A: The client is going to be furious about the delay. 
B: Don't worry, I'll take the heat for this one. 
A: Are you sure? It was a team mistake. 
B: I'm the lead, so I'll handle the backlash. 
A: That’s very brave of you, thanks. 
B: It’s fine, I’ll take the fall and explain the situation.
japanese: 私（わたし）が責任（せきにん）を取（と）る
chinese: 我来承担责任 (Wǒ lái chéngdān zérèn) / 挨骂也值了 (Āimà yě zhí le)
spanish: Yo cargo con el muerto / Me comeré el marrón

primary: I'm stuck between A and B.
similar: 1. I'm torn between A and B
example:

B: I'm stuck between Japan and Italy. 
A: Both sound amazing, but they are so different. 
B: Exactly, I’m totally torn between the two. 
A: Japan is closer, but Italy has better food. 
B: I know! I'm in a real dilemma here.
japanese: AとBで迷（まよ）っている
chinese: 我在AB之间左右为难 (Wǒ zài AB zhījiān zuǒyòu wéinán) / 纠结不定 (Jiūjié bùdìng)
spanish: Estoy dudando entre A y B / No sé si A o B

example:
A: Should I accept the job offer right now? 
B: It’s a big move, maybe you should sleep on it. 
A: I’m afraid they might give it to someone else. 
B: They’ll wait a day; just take some time to think. 
A: You're right, I'll mull it over tonight. 
B: Good, things always look clearer in the morning.
japanese: 一晩（ひとばん）考（かんが）えさせて
chinese: 考虑一晚 (Kǎolǜ yī wǎn) / 容我再想想 (Róng wǒ zài xiǎngxiǎng)
spanish: Consultarlo con la almohada / Pensarlo bien

primary: You are quite bold / You've got some nerve
similar: 4. You've got a lot of gall
example:

B: Wow, you've got some nerve!

B: It’s just that you are quite bold to ask for that much.

B: True, you've definitely got some gutsy energy.

chinese: 你胆子真大 (Nǐ dǎnzi zhēn dà) / 好大的胆子 (Hǎo dà de dǎanzi)

primary: Keep it to yourself / Keep a lid on it
meaning: 너만 알고 있어 / 비밀로 해 줘
example:

B: Yeah, but keep it to yourself for now. 
A: I won't tell anyone, I promise. 
B: Seriously, keep a lid on it until it's official. 
A: My lips are sealed, I'll stay mum. 
B: Thanks, we don't need any office rumors yet.
japanese: ここだけの話（はなし）にしておいて／他言無用（たごんむよう）で
chinese: 别告诉别人 (Bié gàosu biérén) / 保密 (Bǎomì)
spanish: Guárdatelo / Chitón

primary: If you are clued in, you'll get it / If you know, you know
similar: 5. You either get it or you don't
example:

B: If you are clued in, you'll get it. 
A: Is it some kind of secret club or something? 
B: If you know, you know, I can't say more. 
A: Come on, just tell me if I'm in the loop or not. 
B: You'll figure it out soon enough, just watch.

chinese: 知情者自明 (Zhīqíngzhě zìmíng) / 懂的都懂 (Dǒng de dōu dǒng)

example:
A: Can I help you find anything specific today? 
B: No thanks, I'm just browsing.

B: Thanks, I'll just keep looking around.

chinese: 我随便看看 (Wǒ suíbiàn kànkàn) / 只是逛逛 (Zhǐshì guàngguang)

example:

B: Hey, mind your tongue, the owner is right there.

B: Still, you should watch your language in public. 
A: My bad, I'll keep it civil from now on. 
B: Thank you, let's just enjoy the food.

chinese: 注意言辞 (Zhùyì yáncí) / 说话客气点 (Shuōhuà kèqi diǎn)
spanish: Cuida esa boca / Ojo con lo que dices

example:

B: Okay, I'll try not to back out now.

chinese: 临场脱逃 (Línchǎng tuōtáo) / 犯怵 (Fànchù)

example:

B: No way, that's apples and oranges.

B: True, but the training is like night and day. 
A: I guess the endurance needed is poles apart. 
B: Exactly, it's a completely different ballgame.

meaning: 인생 좀 살아라, 쓸데없는 짓 그만해라
example:

B: Just checking his stories, relax.

B: I have a life! This is research.
A: It's pathetic. Go touch some grass.
B: Fine, putting the phone down.

chinese: 去过你自己的生活吧 (Qùguò nǐ zìjǐ de shēnghuó ba) / 找点正经事做 (Zhǎo diǎn zhèngjing shì zuò)

meaning: (안 좋은 일에) 미련 갖지 마 / 잊어버려
example:

B: It’s water under the bridge now, just move on.

B: Good, don't linger on it and focus on the next task.

example:

B: A little. Old habits die hard.

meaning: 완전 내 취향이야 / 내가 정말 좋아하는 거야
example:

B: Definitely, I'm all about that kind of atmosphere.

example:

B: Sounds fair, let's settle the tab and head out.

meaning: 난 원래 이래 / 태어날 때부터 이랬어
example:

B: I don't know, I guess I was born this way. 
A: I wish I had your natural energy in the morning.

B: Well, it’s just who I am, I can't really change it.

chinese: 我天生就这样 (Wǒ tiānshēng jiù zhèyàng) / 生来如此 (Shēnglái rúcǐ)

5. The crux of the matter is

B: Exactly, that’s the crux of the matter.

chinese: 关键在于 (Guānjiàn zàiyú) / 归根结底 (Guīgēnjiédǐ)

meaning: 긁어 부스럼 만들지 마 (잠자고 있는 사자를 건드리지 마)
example:

B: Good call, don't stir the pot when he’s like this.

example:

B: The weather looks iffy, so let's see how it goes. 
A: We can't wait too long or it'll be taken. 
B: Let's play it by ear for a few more days. 
A: Okay, let's see how the dust settles with the forecast. 
B: Exactly, we'll cross that bridge when we come to it.

chinese: 走着瞧吧 (Zǒuzheqiáo ba) / 看看再说 (Kànkan zàishuō)

meaning: 아주 쉬운 결정 / 생각할 필요도 없는 일
example:
A: Should we accept this partnership deal? 
B: Absolutely, it’s a no brainer.

A: I thought it would be a slam dunk too. 
B: It’s a total cinch, let's sign it now.

chinese: 显而易见的事 (Xiǎn'éryìjiàn de shì) / 想都不用想 (Xiǎng dōu bùyòng xiǎng)

similar: 1. Now that I think about it
5. When you put it that way
example:

B: Come to think of it, he wasn't at the meeting either. 
A: Now that I think about it, he mentioned a vacation. 
B: On second thought, maybe he’s just working from home. 
A: Actually, I should check the shared calendar. 
B: Good idea, thinking back, he did seem busy lately.

chinese: 经你这么一说 (Jīng nǐ zhème yī shuō) / 想起来了 (Xiǎng qǐlái le)

meaning: 나에 대해 좋게 말해줘 (나 좀 잘 봐달라고 해줘)
example:

B: Yeah, we’ve worked together for years. 
A: Could you put in a good word for me? 
B: Of course, I'd be happy to vouch for you. 
A: Thanks, I really need someone to talk me up. 
B: Don't worry, I'll give you a boost during lunch.
japanese: 私（わたし）のことを良（よ）く言（い）っておいて／口添（くちゾ）えして
chinese: 替我美言几句 (Tì wǒ měiyán jǐ jù) / 帮我说好话 (Bāng wǒ shuō hǎohuà)
spanish: Habla bien de mí / Échame un cable con eso

example:
A: Want to grab some drinks after the shift? 
B: Sorry, I'm wiped out today. 
A: It was a pretty hectic day, wasn't it? 
B: I'm spent, I just want to go home and sleep. 
A: I get it, I'm feeling pretty beat myself. 
B: My brain is fried; I’m totally running on empty.
japanese: ヘトヘトだよ／全（まった）く力（ちから）が残（のこ）ってない
chinese: 我累垮了 (Wǒ lèi kuǎ le) / 精疲力竭 (Jīngpílìjié)
spanish: Estoy reventado / Estoy hecho polvo

example:
A: Why did you agree to do all her work again? 
B: I don't know, she just walked all over me. 
A: You need to stop letting people treat you like a doormat. 
B: I know, she really knows how to push me around. 
A: She definitely took advantage of your kindness. 
B: Next time, I won't let her run roughshod over me.
japanese: 彼女（かのじょ）にいいように扱（あつか）われた／踏（ふ）みつけにされた
chinese: 她对我呼来喝去 (Tā duì wǒ hū lái hè qù) / 她根本不把我放在眼里 (Tā gēnběn bù bǎ wǒ fàng zài yǎn lǐ)
spanish: Me pasó por encima / Me trató como un trapo

primary: Don't be so hard on yourself
meaning: 자신을 너무 달달 볶지 마 / 자책하지 마
example:
A: I can't believe I missed that deadline. 
B: Don't be so hard on yourself, it was a tight schedule. 
A: I feel like I let the whole team down. 
B: Cut yourself some slack, you've been working so hard. 
A: Thanks, I’ll try not to beat myself up about it. 
B: Good, just give yourself a break for tonight.

chinese: 别对自己太苛刻 (Bié duì zìjǐ tài kēkè) / 别太为难自己 (Bié tài wéinán zìjǐ)
spanish: No seas tan duro contigo mismo / Tente paciencia

similar: 4. He's cranky on an empty stomach
5. He needs a snack to be human
example:
A: Why is James being so short with everyone? 
B: He's moody when he's starving, haven't you noticed? 
A: Oh, so he's just hangry? 
B: Exactly, he's always a grouch when he hasn't eaten. 
A: Let's get him some pizza before the meeting. 
B: Good idea, he's way too cranky on an empty stomach.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は空腹（くうふく）だと不機嫌（ふきげん）になる
chinese: 他一饿就脾气暴躁 (Tā yī è jiù píqi bàozào) / 饿肚子让他心情不好 (È dùzi ràng tā xīnqíng bù hǎo)
spanish: Se pone de malas si tiene hambre / El hambre lo pone insoportable

primary: it just popped up in my mind / It just occurred to me
example:
A: How did you solve that bug so quickly?
B: It just popped up in my mind while I was making tea.
A: That’s a total flash of inspiration.
B: It just occurred to me that the syntax was wrong.
A: Well, I'm glad it hit you when it did.
B: Me too, it saved us hours of work.
japanese: ふと思（おも）い浮（う）かんだ
chinese: 我突然想到 (Wǒ tūrán xiǎngdào) / 脑子里灵光一现 (Nǎozi lǐ língguāng yī xiàn)
spanish: Se me ocurrió de la nada / Me vino a la mente

primary: Long legs run in the family
example:
A: Your brother is so tall!
B: Yeah, long legs run in the family.
A: My family is the exact opposite.
B: It's definitely in our genes; my dad is tall too.
A: Must be nice to reach the top shelf.
B: It’s a useful family trait, I guess.
japanese: 足（あし）が長（なが）いのは家系（かけい）だ／遺伝（いでん）だ
chinese: 长腿是家传的 (Cháng tuǐ shì jiāchuán de) / 我们家都是大长腿 (Wǒmen jiā dōu shì dà cháng tuǐ)
spanish: Viene de familia / Lo llevamos en la sangre

primary: Apple doesn't fall far from the tree
example:
A: Did you see his kid fixing that computer?
B: Apple doesn't fall far from the tree.
A: He's a genius, just like his father.
B: He’s definitely a chip off the old block.
A: It's amazing to see him follow in those footsteps.
B: Like father, like son, as they say.
japanese: 蛙（かえる）の子（こ）は蛙（かえる）／似（に）たもの親子（おやこ）
chinese: 有其父必有其子 (Yǒu qí fù bì yǒu qí zǐ) / 孩子随爹妈 (Háizi suí diēmā)
spanish: De tal palo, tal astilla / Hijo de tigre, pintito

example:
A: Why are you calling me at 3 AM?
B: Sorry, this idea just came out of the blue.
A: It’s totally unexpected, even for you.
B: I know, it came out of left field and I had to share.
A: Can it wait until tomorrow morning?
B: Probably, but it was just such a sudden thought.
japanese: 出（だ）し抜（ぬ）けに／突然（とつぜん）
chinese: 突然 (Tūrán) / 冷不丁地 (Lěngbùdīng de)
spanish: De la nada / Sin previo aviso

example:
A: Do you ever go to that fancy French restaurant?
B: Only once in a blue moon.
A: Is it too expensive or just too far?
B: Both, so we very rarely go there.
A: We go about once a year for our anniversary.
B: Yeah, it’s a once in a lifetime kind of price.
japanese: ごく稀（まれ）に／滅多（めった）にない
chinese: 罕见 (Hǎnjiàn) / 千载难逢 (Qiānzǎinánféng)
spanish: Una vez a las quinientas / Muy de vez en cuando

primary: He has an audacity to show up here
example:
A: I can't believe Mark is at the party after the fight.
B: He has an audacity to show up here.
A: He really has some nerve after what he said.
B: What a cheek, acting like nothing happened.
A: I’m surprised nobody has kicked him out yet.
B: He’s got some gall, that’s for sure.
japanese: よくもぬけぬけと来（こ）られたものだ／厚顔無恥（こうがんむち）な
chinese: 他居然还有脸来这儿 (Tā jūrán hái yǒu liǎn lái zhèr) / 胆子不小敢露面 (Dǎnzi bù xiǎo gǎn lòumiàn)
spanish: Qué descaro aparecer por aquí / Hay que tener cara

example:
A: The neighborhood is generally very safe.
B: That being said, be cautious at night.
A: Should I avoid certain streets?
B: Mind you, it’s better to stick to the main roads.
A: Thanks, I’ll be sure to watch out.
B: Still, it’s always good to be aware of your surroundings.
japanese: とは言（い）っても気（き）をつけて／そうは言（い）うけど
chinese: 虽说如此，还是要小心 (Suīshuō rúcǐ, háishì yào xiǎoxīn) / 话虽这么说但我还是得提醒你 (Huà suī zhème shuō dàn wǒ háishì děi tíxǐng nǐ)
spanish: Dicho esto, ten cuidado / Aun así, ándate con ojo

example:
A: Have you heard the urban legend about this building?
B: Yeah, it gives me a chill just thinking about it.
A: They say the elevators move on their own at night.
B: Stop, you’re giving me the creeps!
A: Sorry, I didn't mean to send shivers down your spine.
B: It’s just a really hair-raising story.
japanese: ゾッとする／寒気（さむけ）がする
chinese: 瑟瑟发抖 (Sèsè fādǒu) / 让我感到一阵恶寒 (Ràng wǒ gǎndào yīzhèn èhán)
spanish: Me da escalofríos / Se me pone la piel de gallina

primary: You seemed a little far fetched
example:
A: He claims he met a billionaire at the bus stop.
B: You seemed a little far fetched there.
A: Why? It could happen in New York.
B: It’s a bit of a stretch, don't you think?
A: I suppose it does sound a bit fishy.
B: Yeah, that story is definitely hard to swallow.
japanese: ちょっと信（しん）じ難（がた）い／話（はなし）が大（おお）きすぎる
chinese: 你这说法有点离谱 (Nǐ zhè shuōfǎ yǒudiǎn lípǔ) / 听起来不太靠谱 (Tīng qǐlái bù tài kàopǔ)
spanish: Me sonó a cuento chino / Suena un poco exagerado

primary: I'm a second away from buying that
meaning: 당장이라도 그걸 살 것 같아 (지름신 강림 직전)
example:
A: That new phone looks incredible on you.
B: I'm a second away from buying that.
A: It’s a lot of money, though.
B: I know, I’m on the verge of buying it right now.
A: Maybe you should sleep on it first.
B: I’m this close to getting it, the temptation is real.
japanese: 喉（のど）から手（て）が出（で）るほど欲（ほ）しい／買（か）いそうだ
chinese: 我马上就要买了 (Wǒ mǎshàng jiù yào mǎi le) / 差一点就剁手了 (Chà yīdiǎnr jiù duòshǒu le)
spanish: Estoy a un paso de comprarlo / Casi, casi me lo llevo

primary: What do you take me for?
similar: 1. Who do you think I am?
2. Do I look like a fool?
example:
A: Are you sure you can handle this deal alone? 
B: What do you take me for? I've done this before. 
A: I just don't want you to get tricked. 
B: I'm not that naive, I know exactly what I'm doing. 
A: Fair enough, I'll leave it to you. 
B: Thanks, just give me some credit for my experience.
japanese: 私（わたし）を誰（だれ）だと思（おも）ってるの？／馬鹿（ばか）にしないで
chinese: 你把我当成什么人了? (Nǐ bǎ wǒ dàngchéng shénme rén le?) / 瞧不起谁呢 (Qiáobùqǐ shéi ne)
spanish: ¿Por quién me tomas? / ¿Me ves cara de tonto?

example:
A: You bought ten pairs of shoes today? 
B: Yeah, I guess I got carried away at the mall. 
A: You definitely went overboard with the credit card. 
B: I just got too excited when I saw the 70% off sign. 
A: You should probably return at least half of them. 
B: I know, I was just caught up in the moment.
japanese: 調子（ちょうし）に乗（の）りすぎた／夢中（むちゅう）になりすぎた
chinese: 我做得过火了 (Wǒ zuò de guòhuǒ le) / 一时冲动 (Yīshí chōngdòng)
spanish: Se me fue la mano / Me dejé llevar

primary: I'm not big on holding things with regret.
similar: 1. I don't dwell on the past
example:
A: Do you ever wish you had taken that job in London? 
B: Not really, I'm not big on holding things with regret. 
A: It was such a great opportunity, though. 
B: Maybe, but I don't dwell on the past once I decide. 
A: I wish I could move on as quickly as you do. 
B: Life is too short to look back and wonder "what if."
japanese: 過去（かこ）を引（ひ）きずるタイプじゃない／後悔（こうかい）はしない主義（しゅぎ）だ
chinese: 我不是个爱后悔的人 (Wǒ bùshì gè ài hòuhuǐ de rén) / 往事随风 (Wǎngshì suí fēng)
spanish: No soy de arrepentirme / Lo hecho, hecho está

primary: In one ear, out the other
meaning: 한 귀로 듣고 한 귀로 흘리네
example:
A: Did you tell him to bring the files for the meeting? 
B: I did, but with him, it's in one ear, out the other. 
A: He’s obviously not even listening when we talk. 
B: Exactly, it’s like I'm talking to a brick wall. 
A: We need to make sure he actually hears us this time. 
B: I'll send it in a text so it actually sinks in.
japanese: 馬（うま）の耳（みみ）に念仏（ねんぶつ）／右（みぎ）から左（ひだり）へ受（う）け流（なが）す
chinese: 左耳进右耳出 (Zuǒ ěr jìn yòu ěr chū) / 当成耳边风 (Dàngchéng ěrbiānfēng)
spanish: Le entra por uno y le sale por el otro / Como hablarle a la pared

example:
A: I need your absolute best quote.
B: This is as low as I can go.
A: Can't you knock off another hundred?
B: I'm already losing money on this.
A: Alright, send me the invoice.
B: Pleasure doing business with you.
japanese: ここからいくら引（ひ）ける？／ベストプライスを出（だ）して
chinese: 最低报价 (Zuìdī bàojià) / 最优价格 (Zuìyōu jiàgé)
spanish: Dame tu mejor precio / ¿En cuánto me lo dejas?

meaning: 나도 알 건 다 알아 / 바보가 아니야
example:
A: Trust me, this investment is a guaranteed win. 
B: Look, I wasn't born yesterday, tell me the risks. 
A: I promise there's almost zero risk involved. 
B: You can't trick me with that "guaranteed" talk. 
A: I'm just trying to help you make some money. 
B: I've been around the block; I know nothing is free.
japanese: 世間（せけん）知（し）らずじゃない／子供（こども）じゃないんだから
chinese: 我又不是三岁小孩 (Wǒ yòu bùshì sān suì xiǎohái) / 我也走南闯北过 (Wǒ yě zǒunánchuǎngběi guò)
spanish: No nací ayer / No soy tonto

similar: 3. I'll have to pass for now
example:
A: Are we still on for the movies tonight? 
B: I’m swamped with work, let's take a raincheck. 
A: No problem, we can always go some other time. 
B: Thanks for understanding, can we reschedule for Friday? 
A: Friday works perfectly for me. 
B: Great, I'll have to pass for tonight and finish this.
japanese: また今度（こんど）にしよう。
chinese: 改天吧 (Gǎitiān ba) / 下次再说 (Xiàcì zàishuō)
spanish: Lo dejamos para otra / ¿Te parece si lo posponemos?

primary: There he goes again, acting up again
example:
A: Why is Kevin yelling in the breakroom now? 
B: There he goes again, acting up again over nothing. 
A: It's the same old story every single Monday. 
B: He really loves making a scene in front of everyone. 
A: Someone needs to tell him to calm down. 
B: Here we go again, I'll go try to quiet him down.
japanese: また始（はじ）まったよ。／彼（かれ）の癖（くせ）が出（De）た。
chinese: 他又开始了 (Tā yòu kāishǐ le) / 没完没了了 (Méiwánméiliǎo le)
spanish: Ya está otra vez... / Ya empezó con lo mismo

example:
A: I'm thinking of quitting my job and starting a blog. 
B: It's risky, but it could work. That's my two cents. 
A: I was hoping for a bit more encouragement. 
B: Just my thoughts, you should have a backup plan. 
A: I guess my take on it was a bit more optimistic. 
B: For what it's worth, I think you're talented enough.
japanese: あくまで私（わたし）の意見（いけん）だけどね。
chinese: 这只是我的个人观点 (Zhè zhǐshì wǒ de gèrén guāndiǎn) / 拙见 (Zhuójiàn)
spanish: Es mi humilde opinión / Yo solo digo...

primary: Hear me out, read my lips
meaning: 내 말 끝까지 들어봐 / 똑똑히 들어
example:
A: I don't think we should invest in that startup. 
B: Hear me out, the market is shifting rapidly. 
A: But they haven't made a profit in three years. 
B: Read my lips: their new tech is a game changer. 
A: Okay, let me finish looking at their data first. 
B: Just pay attention to their patents, mark my words.
japanese: いいから聞（き）いて。／私（わたし）の言（い）うことをよく聞（き）け。
chinese: 听我说完 (Tīng wǒ shuō wán) / 听清楚了 (Tīng qīngchu le)
spanish: Escúchame bien / Léeme los labios

primary: I didn't see this coming / I couldn't expect this
example:
A: The company is relocating to London next month.
B: Wow, I didn't see this coming. 
A: It was a sudden decision by the board.
B: I'm totally blindsided; I have a lease here.
A: Many of us are in the same boat.
B: This really came out of left field for everyone.
japanese: まさかこうなるとは思（おも）わなかった。／予想外（よそうがい）だ。
chinese: 始料未及 (Shǐliào wèi jí) / 真没想到 (Zhēn méi xiǎngdào)
spanish: No me lo vi venir / Me tomó por sorpresa

primary: I'm still green at heart / I'm young at heart
example:
A: You're going bungee jumping for your 60th birthday?
B: Why not? I'm still green at heart. 
A: I hope you've cleared this with your doctor.
B: Don't worry, I'm still young at heart. 
A: You definitely have more energy than I do.
B: Age is just a number if you keep a positive spirit.
japanese: 気持（きも）ちはまだ若（わか）いよ。
chinese: 心态年轻 (Xīntài niánqīng) / 老当益壮 (Lǎodāngyìzhuàng)
spanish: Soy joven de espíritu / El corazón no envejece

similar: 4. Can't put my finger on it
example:
A: Are you sure we turned off the stove before leaving?
B: I think so, but I can't shake the feeling that I forgot. 
A: We’re already ten miles away from home.
B: Something just feels off about today.
A: Let’s just turn back and check for peace of mind.
B: Thanks, that nagging thought would have ruined the trip.
japanese: 嫌（いや）な予感（よかん）が拭（ぬぐ）えない。
chinese: 这种感觉挥之不去 (Zhè zhǒng gǎnjué huīzhībùqù) / 总觉得哪里不对劲 (Zǒng juéde nǎlǐ bù duìjìn)
spanish: No me quito la sensación de encima / Tengo un mal presentimiento

meaning: 분위기 파악 좀 해 / 눈치 좀 챙겨
example:
A: Why did you start talking about work during the party?
B: I just thought it was a good time to bring it up.
A: You really need to read the room. 
B: Was everyone really that uncomfortable?
A: Yes, you should check the vibe before talking shop.
B: My bad, I'll try to pick up on the mood next time.
japanese: 空気（くうき）を読（よ）んで。
chinese: 察言观色 (Cháyánguānsè) / 看看场合 (Kànkan chǎnghé)
spanish: Lee el ambiente / Ubícate un poco

example:
A: Have you tried that new Italian place on 5th?
B: Yes, I can't recommend it enough. 
A: Is the pasta really as good as they say?
B: It's beyond impressive; you have to try the carbonara.
A: I'll make a reservation for this weekend then.
B: Trust me, it’s worth every penny.
japanese: 本当（ほんとう）におすすめ！／絶対（ぜったい）いいよ！
chinese: 强烈推荐 (Qiángliè tuījiàn) / 怎么夸都不为过 (Zěnme kuā dōu bù wéigo)
spanish: Lo recomiendo muchísimo / Tienes que probarlo sí o sí

primary: Pick up on that / catch on to that / take a hint
example:
A: Did you notice Sarah was upset during lunch?
B: No, I didn't pick up on that at all. 
A: She barely said a word and left early.
B: I guess I failed to catch on to her mood. 
A: You really need to learn how to take a hint. 
B: I'll try to read between the lines better next time.
japanese: 気（き）づく／察（さっ）する
chinese: 领会 (Lǐnghuì) / 识趣 (Shíqù)
spanish: ¿Pillas la indirecta? / ¿Te das cuenta?

example:
A: I'm blowing my paycheck on kitchenware.
B: Le Creuset again?
A: I need that dutch oven!
B: You don't even cook.
A: It looks good on the stove though.
B: Expensive decoration, but okay.
japanese: 調理（ちょうり）器具（きぐ）／キッチン用品（ようひん）
chinese: 厨具 (Chújù) / 厨房用品 (Chúfáng yòngpǐn)
spanish: Utensilios de cocina / Cosas para la cocina

example:
A: How was your date with that guy from the app?
B: He was such a yapper, I couldn't get a word in. 
A: Oh no, was he at least interesting?
B: No, he was just a total chatterbox about his car.
A: That sounds like a long and exhausting night.
B: It was; he's a real motor mouth when he starts.
japanese: おしゃべりな人（ひと）
chinese: 话痨 (Huàláo) / 碎嘴子 (Suìzuǐzi)
spanish: Cotorra / Habla hasta por los codos

example:
A: How long will it take to finish this report?
B: About three hours, give or take. 
A: Can you get it done before the meeting at 4?
B: It’ll be done roughly by then, more or less.
A: Great, let me know if you need any help.
B: It’s approximately a ten-page document, so I'm good.
japanese: およそ／だいたい
chinese: 大约 (Dàyuē) / 上下浮动 (Shàngxià fúdòng)
spanish: Más o menos / Aproximadamente

example:
A: How did the meeting with the new client go?
B: Great! We really hit it off during lunch. 
A: That’s a relief; I heard they were difficult.
B: Not at all, we clicked instantly over shared hobbies.
A: I'm glad to hear you're seeing eye to eye.
B: Yeah, we got along famously from the start.
japanese: 意気投合（いきとうごう）する／馬（うま）が合（あ）う
chinese: 投缘 (Tóuyuán) / 一见如故 (Yījiànrúgù)
spanish: Hicimos buenas migas / Hubo química al instante

example:
A: I heard you're dating a doctor now.
B: Yeah, and he is a legit, catch.
A: Is he nice too, or just successful?
B: He's the total package, honestly.
A: I'm so happy you found a keeper.
B: Thanks, I feel like I struck gold.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は優良（ゆうりょう）物件（ぶっけん）だ／逃（のが）したら損（そん）だ
chinese: 他真是个不可多得的好对象 (Tā zhēnshì gè bùkěduōdé de hǎo duìxiàng) / 一等一的好人选 (Yīděngyī de hǎo rénxuǎn)
spanish: Es un partidazo / Es un tesoro

example:
A: I know you’re right, but I don't want to apologize.
B: Sometimes you just have to swallow your pride.
A: It’s just so hard to admit I was wrong.
B: Just suck it up and make things right.
A: Fine, I’ll put my ego aside this once.
B: Good call, it’ll save the friendship.
japanese: プライドを捨（す）てる／折（お）れる
chinese: 放下身段 (Fàngxià shēnduàn) / 委曲求全 (Wěiqūqiúquán)
spanish: Trágate el orgullo / Baja la cabeza esta vez

example:
A: The crowd is going to go bananas when the band starts.
B: I know, everyone has been waiting for hours.
A: I think I might flip out a little myself.
B: Don't go ballistic and lose your phone!
A: I’ll try to stay calm, but no promises.
B: Let's just go nuts and enjoy the show!
japanese: 気（き）が狂（くる）う／大興奮（だいこうふん）する
chinese: 欣喜若狂 (Xīnxǐruòkuáng) / 发疯 (Fāfēng)
spanish: Volverse loco / Perder los papeles

similar: 1. Playing it close to the vest
example:
A: Did she say anything about the new project?
B: No, she was being very cagey about it.
A: Why is she so tight-lipped lately?
B: I think she's playing it close to the vest until it's official.
A: She’s always been a bit guarded with info.
B: Yeah, she can be really evasive when she wants to.
japanese: 秘密（ひみつ）主義（しゅぎ）の／ハッキリ言（い）わない
chinese: 守口如瓶 (Shǒukǒurúpíng) / 故弄玄虚 (Gùnòngxuánxū)
spanish: Reservado / No suelta prenda

example:
A: Should we book the flights or the hotel first?
B: First things first, let's check our budget.
A: That makes sense, priority one is the money.
B: To begin with, we need to know what we can afford.
A: I’ll pull up the spreadsheet now.
B: Great, let's start at the top and work down.
japanese: まず初（はじ）めに／最優先（さいゆうせん）事項（じこう）として
chinese: 先说正事儿 (Xiān shuō zhèngshìr) / 凡事有先后 (Fánshì yǒu xiānhòu)
spanish: Lo primero es lo primero / Antes que nada

meaning: 가장 친한 친구, 평생 가는 절친
example:
A: She's been my best friend since pre-K.
B: That's a long time to know someone.
A: We're practically sisters at this point.
B: Does she know all your secrets?
A: Every single one. She's my ride-or-die.
B: Those are the ones you keep.
japanese: 親友（しんゆう）／マブダチ
chinese: 至交 (Zhìjiāo) / 死党 (Sǐdǎng)
spanish: Mejor amigo / Colega del alma

meaning: 잘 안 풀리는 날 / 컨디션 난조인 날
example:
A: You missed three shots in a row today.
B: Yeah, I'm just having an off day.
A: It’s okay, everyone has a rough one sometimes.
B: I feel totally out of sorts and off my game.
A: Don't let a small slump get you down.
B: Thanks, I'll try again tomorrow.
japanese: 調子（ちょうし）が出（で）ない日（ひ）／ツイてない日（ひ）
chinese: 运气不好的一天 (Yùnqì bù hǎo de yītiān) / 状态不佳 (Zhuàngtài bùjiā)
spanish: Tengo un mal día / Hoy no es mi día

example:
A: Do you like your new luxury watch?
B: Honestly, I’m having some buyer's remorse.
A: Why? It looks amazing on you.
B: I keep having second thoughts about the price.
A: The post-purchase blues are real, but it's a great piece.
B: I'm just wishing I could return it and save the money.
japanese: 買（か）って後悔（こうかい）すること
chinese: 剁手后的后悔 (Duòshǒu hòu de hòuhuǐ) / 买后悔了 (Mǎi hòuhuǐ le)
spanish: Me arrepentí de comprarlo / Culpa del comprador

similar: 2. Kill two birds with one stone
example:
A: I'm going to the kitchen to get some water.
B: While at it, could you grab me a soda?
A: Sure thing, might as well kill two birds with one stone.
B: Thanks, I appreciate you helping me out.
A: No problem, I'll grab it along the way.
B: You're the best, thanks for being so helpful.
japanese: ついでに
chinese: 顺便 (Shùnbiàn) / 捎带手 (Shāodàishǒu)
spanish: Ya que estás en eso / Aprovechando el viaje

meaning: 인생을 좀 즐겨 / 좀 풀어져 봐
example:
A: I shouldn't eat this cake; I have a marathon to train for.
B: Oh, come on, live a little!
A: I’ve been so strict with my diet lately.
B: Just treat yourself once; you need to let loose.
A: Maybe you're right, I should loosen up.
