B: Good. Don't push yourself too hard, just enjoy the vibe.
A: Thanks, fam. I'll hit you up when I land.
B: Sounds good. Peace out!
japanese: 自分（じぶん）を大切（たいせつ）にしてね／元気（げんき）でね
chinese: 多多保重 (Duōduō bǎozhòng) / 照顾好你自己 (Zhàogù hǎo nǐ zìjǐ)
spanish: Cuídate mucho / No te descuides

example:
A: I'm thinking about starting my own podcast, but I'm nervous.
B: Honestly? Go for it! You've got so many interesting stories to tell.
A: You really think people would listen?
B: 100%. Your perspective is unique, and that's what matters.
A: Alright, I'm gonna start recording this weekend.
B: That's what I'm talking about! I'll be your first listener.
japanese: やっちゃえよ！／行（い）け！
chinese: 放手去做吧! (Fàngshǒu qù zuò ba!) / 去干吧! (Qù gàn ba!)
spanish: ¡Dale! / ¡A por ello!

example:
A: Did you hear what the new manager did this morning?
B: Ugh, yeah. Honestly, he's a piece of work. Always micromanaging.
A: It's getting really old, really fast.
B: Facts. I don't know how much longer I can deal with it.
A: Hopefully he chills out once he's settled in.
B: I wouldn't hold my breath. He seems set in his ways.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は一筋縄（ひとすじなわ）ではいかない／厄介（やっかい）な人（ひと）だ
chinese: 真是个奇葩 (Zhēnshì gè qípā) / 真是个极品 (Zhēnshì gè jípǐn)
spanish: Menuda pieza / Es un personaje

example:
A: I'm trusting you with this big account. Don't mess it up.
B: I won't let you down, I promise. I've been preparing for this.
A: I know you have. I believe in your skills.
B: Thanks for the opportunity. I'm gonna give it 110%.
A: That's the energy I like to see.
B: I'll have the first draft ready by tomorrow morning.
japanese: 期待（きたい）は裏切（うらぎ）らないよ／任（まか）せて
chinese: 我不会让你失望的 (Wǒ bùhuì ràng nǐ shīvàng de) / 包在我身上 (Bāo zài wǒ shēnshàng)
spanish: No te fallaré / No te decepcionaré

primary: I've been trying to reach you.
similar: I've been trying to get ahold of you.
I've been blowing up your phone.
I've been trying to connect with you.
I was trying to find you.
example:
A: Yo, I missed like five calls from you! What's up?
B: Man, I've been trying to reach you all day! Where were you?
A: My phone was on silent during the movie. My bad.
B: All good. Anyway, we're all meeting at the pizza spot in ten.
A: Say less. I'm leaving right now.
B: Bet. See you there.
japanese: ずっと連絡（れんらく）してたんだけど／探（さが）してたよ
chinese: 我一直都在联系你 (Wǒ yīzhí dōu zài liánxì nǐ) / 找你半天了 (Zhǎo nǐ bàntiān le)
spanish: Te he estado buscando / Llevo rato llamándote

primary: It was a stroke of luck.
example:
A: How did you find such a great apartment in this market?
B: Honestly, it was a stroke of luck. I saw the listing five minutes after it went up.
A: That's insane. Most spots are gone in an hour.
B: For real. I signed the lease before anyone else even toured it.
A: You definitely used up all your luck for the year on that one.
B: Facts. But honestly? Totally worth it.
japanese: まぐれだ／運（うん）が良（よ）かっただけ
chinese: 真是走运 (Zhēnshì zǒuyùn) / 瞎猫碰上死耗子 (Xiāmāo pèngshàng sǐ hàozi)
spanish: Fue un golpe de suerte / Fue pura chiripa

example:
A: You've been really quiet lately. Is everything alright?
B: I'm just stressed, I guess. It's no big deal.
A: Look, don't bottle up your feelings. It's better to talk about it.
B: I just don't wanna bother anyone with my problems.
A: You're not bothering me. That's what friends are for.
B: Thanks. Maybe I do need to vent a little.
japanese: 溜（た）め込（こ）まないで／吐（は）き出（だ）して
chinese: 别憋在心里 (Bié biē zài xīnlǐ) / 把话说出来 (Bǎ huà shuō chūlái)
spanish: No te guardes las cosas / Desahógate

example:
A: There's pizza left?
B: Yeah, don't be shy, take some.
A: I don't want to be greedy.
B: We're gonna throw it out otherwise.
A: In that case, give me two slices.
B: That's the spirit.
japanese: 遠慮（えんりょ）しないで
chinese: 别不好意思 (Bié bù hǎoyìsi) / 别害羞 (Bié hàixiū)
spanish: No tengas vergüenza / Sin miedo

similar: I'm starting to appreciate you more.
example:
A: I know I'm a bit much sometimes, but I mean well.
B: Don't worry about it. Honestly? You're growing on me.
A: Oh, really? I thought I was annoying you.
B: You were at first, but now I think you're just hilarious.
A: I'll take that as a win.
B: As you should. Let's get some coffee.
japanese: だんだん好（す）きになってきた／良（よ）さが分（わ）かってきた
chinese: 我越来越喜欢你了 (Wǒ yuèláiyuè xǐhuan nǐ le) / 你挺招人喜欢的 (Nǐ tǐng zhāorén xǐhuan de)
spanish: Te estoy cogiendo cariño / Me estás ganando

similar: I worked late into the night.
I put in extra hours at night.
example:
A: You look exhausted. Did you actually get any sleep?
B: Barely. I burnt the midnight oil to finish that presentation.
A: Was it worth it? Hope the client liked it.
B: They loved it. All that effort really paid off.
A: Good to hear, but you should definitely crash early tonight.
B: 100%. My brain is officially fried.
japanese: 夜遅（よるおそ）くまで頑張（がんば）った
chinese: 挑灯夜战 (Tiǎodēngyèzhàn) / 熬夜苦干 (Áoyè kǔgàn)
spanish: Me quedé trabajando hasta tarde / Trasnoché trabajando

example:
A: What was your lap time?
B: Shy of two minutes.
A: That's a new personal best!
B: I wanted to break 1:50 though.
A: You're getting faster.
B: Next time, I got this.
japanese: 2分（ふん）弱（じゃく）／2分（ふん）切（き）るくらい
chinese: 差两分钟 (Chà liǎng fēnzhōng) / 不到两分钟 (Bù dào liǎng fēnzhōng)
spanish: Menos de dos minutos / Casi dos minutos

primary: That would be the best case scenario.
similar: If everything goes right, that's what happens.
example:
A: If we launch by Monday, we'll beat all our competitors.
B: That would be the best case scenario. Everyone's working overtime.
A: Do you think we can actually make it happen?
B: It's a tight squeeze, but it's definitely possible.
A: Fingers crossed. This would be huge for the team.
B: For real. Let's just keep this momentum going.
japanese: それが一番（いちばん）いい形（かたち）だね／理想（りそう）的（てき）だね
chinese: 那是理想情况 (Nà shì lǐxiǎng qíngkuàng) / 最完美的打算 (Zuì wánměi de dǎsuàn)
spanish: Sería lo ideal / En el mejor de los casos

example:
A: New York is honestly the best city for inspiration.
B: I couldn't agree more. The energy here is just different.
A: For real. Everywhere you look, there's someone doing something creative.
B: It's like you can't help but feel motivated.
A: Facts. I never want to live anywhere else.
B: Same. This city is just in my blood.
japanese: 全（まった）く同感（どうかん）です。／激（げき）しく同意（どうい）。
chinese: 我完全赞同 (Wǒ wánquán zàntóng) / 你说得太对了 (Nǐ shuō de tài duì le)
spanish: Totalmente de acuerdo. / Ni que lo digas.

primary: I've got a memory like a sieve.
similar: My brain is like a blank slate sometimes.
example:
A: Did you remember to pick up the milk on your way home?
B: Oh snap! I completely forgot. I've got a memory like a sieve.
A: I literally texted you ten minutes ago!
B: I know, I know. I saw it and then immediately got distracted.
A: It's all good, I'll just go grab it now.
B: My bad, fam. I'll make it up to you.
japanese: 記憶力（きおくりょく）がザルなんです。／すぐ忘（わす）れちゃうんです。
chinese: 我这脑子像漏斗 (Wǒ zhè nǎozi xiàng lòudǒu) / 贵人多忘事 (Guìrén duō wàngshì)
spanish: Tengo memoria de pez. / Se me va la olla.

example:
A: Wait, I didn't see this appetizer on the bill.
B: Don't worry about it, it's on the house. Thanks for coming in tonight!
A: Oh, that's so sweet! Thank you so much.
B: Of course. You guys are regulars, we gotta show some love.
A: We really appreciate that. The food was incredible as always.
B: Glad you enjoyed it! See you next time.
japanese: 店（みせ）のおごりです。／サービスです。
chinese: 免单 (Miǎndān) / 这份算我们的 (Zhè fèn suàn wǒmen de)
spanish: Invita la casa. / Es cortesía de la casa.

primary: I think you should get a second opinion.
example:
A: The mechanic says my car needs a whole new engine.
B: That sounds extreme. I think you should get a second opinion.
A: You're right. I don't really trust that guy anyway.
B: Take it to my guy in Queens. He's honest and won't overcharge you.
A: Good looks. I'll give him a call tomorrow.
B: Definitely. Better safe than sorry.
japanese: セカンドオピニオンを聞（き）いた方（ほう）がいいと思（おも）うよ。／別（べつ）の人（ひと）にも聞（き）いてみたら？
chinese: 再咨询一下别处 (Zài zīxún yīxià biéchù) / 听听其他意见 (Tīngting qítā yìjiàn)
spanish: Deberías pedir una segunda opinión. / Mejor que preguntes a otro.

similar: You're at the top of your game.
example:
A: I really appreciate all the help you've given me with this project.
B: Any time! Honestly, your work ethic is second to none.
A: Wow, thanks. I really try to put in the effort.
B: It shows. You're easily the most dedicated person on the team.
A: That means a lot coming from you.
B: Facts. Just keep doing what you're doing.
japanese: あなたは誰（だれ）にも引（ひ）けを取（と）らないよ。／君（きみ）が一番（いちばん）だよ。
chinese: 你是顶尖的 (Nǐ shì dǐngjiān de) / 独一无二 (Dúyīwú'èr)
spanish: No tienes rival. / Eres el mejor, sin duda.

example:
A: Guess what? I just won a thousand dollars on a scratch-off!
B: No way! Don't pull my leg, show me the ticket.
A: I'm dead serious! Look right here.
B: Oh my god, you actually did it! That's insane!
A: I know! I'm still in shock.
B: Drinks are definitely on you tonight then!
japanese: からかわないでよ。／冗談（じょうだん）でしょ？
chinese: 别逗我了 (Bié dòu wǒ le) / 别开完笑 (Bié kāiwánxiào)
spanish: No me tomes el pelo. / ¡Venga ya, no bromees!

example:
A: Pizza or Tacos?
B: I'm torn. Both sound good.
A: Tacos are cheaper.
B: But pizza is comfort food.
A: Let's flip a coin.
B: Or just get both. Feast night?
japanese: 迷（まよ）っちゃうなあ。／選（えら）べないよ。
chinese: 左右为难 (Zuǒyòu wéinán) / 挺纠结的 (Tǐng jiūjié de)
spanish: Estoy indeciso. / No sé qué hacer.

example:
A: I think we should skip the launch and just start a new project from scratch.
B: Honestly? You have lost the plot. We're 90% done!
A: I just feel like the market has changed, you know?
B: In three months? No way. We need to finish what we started.
A: Maybe you're right. I'm just feeling a bit overwhelmed.
B: Take a breather. We're almost at the finish line.
japanese: 話（はなし）の筋（すじ）が見（み）えてないね。／状況（じょうきょう）わかってる？
chinese: 你糊涂了吧 (Nǐ hútu le ba) / 你搞错状况了 (Nǐ gǎocuò zhuàngkuàng le)
spanish: Se te ha ido la olla. / No te enteras de nada.

primary: Let's just keep it between us.
similar: Just between the two of us.
example:
A: I'm planning on quitting my job next month.
B: Oh wow! Have you told anyone else yet?
A: No, so let's just keep it between us for now.
B: Of course. Your secret is safe with me.
A: I appreciate that. I just want everything to be in place first.
B: Smart move. Let me know if I can help with anything.
japanese: ここだけの話（はなし）にしておこう。／内緒（ないしょ）だよ。
chinese: 咱们私下知道就行 (Zánmen sīxià zhīdào jiù xíng) / 别外传 (Bié wàichuán)
spanish: Que quede entre nosotros. / Esto no sale de aquí.

example:
A: Alright, we've got another big shipment coming in tomorrow.
B: Got it. You know the drill, I'll be here early to organize everything.
A: Good looks. I'll handle the documentation then.
B: Sounds like a plan. We'll be done by lunch if we move fast.
A: For sure. Let's get it.
B: Catch you in the morning.
japanese: やり方（かた）はわかってるでしょ？／いつもの手順（てじゅん）だよ。
chinese: 老规矩了 (Lǎoguīju le) / 你懂得 (Nǐ dǒng de)
spanish: Ya sabes cómo va esto. / Ya te sabes el rollo.

primary: It's been a roller coaster ride.
similar: There have been many ups and downs.
example:
A: How has the first year of your startup been?
B: Honestly, it's been a roller coaster ride. Some days are great, some are stressful.
A: I can imagine. Entrepreneurship is no joke.
B: For real. But I'm learning a lot through all the chaos.
A: That's the best way to grow though.
B: Facts. I wouldn't trade it for anything.
japanese: 波瀾万丈（はらんばんじょう）でした。／山（やま）あり谷（たに）ありでした。
chinese: 起起伏伏 (Qǐqǐfúfú) / 波折不断 (Bōzhé bùduàn)
spanish: Ha sido una montaña rusa. / Ha habido de todo.

example:
A: I really look up to you, especially how you handle difficult clients.
B: Wow, thank you! I appreciate that a lot.
A: No, seriously. You're always so calm and professional.
B: It took years of practice, trust me. I used to be so stressed.
A: Well, you're killing it now.
B: Thanks, fam. That means more than you know.
japanese: 尊敬（そんけい）しています。／憧（あこが）れています。
chinese: 向你学习 (Xiàng nǐ xuéxí) / 崇拜你 (Chóngbài nǐ)
spanish: Te admiro mucho. / Eres un ejemplo para mí.

similar: It doesn't live up to the hype.
example:
A: Everyone's talking about that new brunch spot in SoHo. Have you been?
B: Yeah, and honestly? It's overrated. Food was mid at best.
A: Oh really? The pictures look so good though.
B: It's all for the aesthetic. The actual taste just isn't there.
A: Good to know. I'll save my money for somewhere else.
B: Definitely. There are way better spots for half the price.
japanese: 過大評価（かだいひょうか）されてるよ。／大（たい）したことないよ。
chinese: 名不副实 (Míngbùfùshí) / 也就那样吧 (Yějiù nàyàng ba)
spanish: Está sobrevalorado. / No es para tanto.

example:
A: So what happened with the date?
B: Long story short, he ghosted me.
A: No way! He seemed so nice.
B: Turned out to be a jerk.
A: His loss, seriously.
B: Yeah, on to the next one.
japanese: 手短（てみじか）に言（い）うと／要（よう）するに
chinese: 长话短说 (Chánghuà duǎnshuō) / 总而言之 (Zǒng'éryánzhī)
spanish: Resumiendo. / En pocas palabras.

similar: I'm not one to hold onto things.
example:
A: I'm really sorry about what I said during the argument yesterday.
B: Don't worry about it. I don't hold a grudge. We're good.
A: Thanks, I was really worried you'd be mad for a while.
B: Life is too short for all that negativity. Let's just move forward.
A: I appreciate that. You're a real one.
B: Facts. Let's grab some lunch and put it behind us.
japanese: 根（ね）に持（も）ったりしないよ。／後腐（あとくさ）れはないよ。
chinese: 我不记仇 (Wǒ bù jìchóu) / 我挺大度的 (Wǒ tǐng dàdù de)
spanish: No soy rencoroso. / No guardo rencor.

primary: I don't know off the top of my head.
similar: I'd have to check my notes.
I don't have that info on hand.
example:
A: Do you remember the address of that new spot in Queens?
B: Honestly? I don't know off the top of my head. Let me check my phone.
A: No rush. I just wanted to see if it was close to the train.
B: Found it! It's right on 31st Ave.
A: Perfect. That's super easy to get to.
B: Facts. We should definitely go this weekend.
japanese: ぱっと思（おも）い出（だ）せないな。／すぐには出（で）てこないな。
chinese: 一下想不起来 (Yīxià xiǎng bù qǐlái) / 没底儿 (Méidǐr)
spanish: Ahora mismo no caigo. / No me viene a la cabeza.

example:
A: Why are you looking so stressed out today?
B: It's these constant train delays. I'm honestly fed up with it.
A: I feel you. The MTA has been a nightmare lately.
B: For real. I've been late to work three times this week.
A: Maybe it's time to start biking or something.
B: Facts. At least then I'm in control of the timing.
japanese: もううんざりだよ。／愛想（あいそ）が尽（つ）きたよ。
chinese: 受够了 (Shòugòu le) / 烦透了 (Fántòu le)
spanish: Estoy harto. / Ya no aguanto más.

primary: I've got a lot on my plate.
example:
A: You coming through to the basketball game tonight?
B: I wish! But I've got a lot on my plate with these finals coming up.
A: Damn, I forgot you were in grad school too.
B: Yeah, it's a lot to handle all at once.
A: Respect. I'll catch you after you pass all those tests.
B: Bet. I'll definitely need a drink then.
japanese: 手（て）一杯（いっぱい）なんです。／やることが山積（やまづ）みで。
chinese: 忙得不可开交 (Máng de bùkě kāijiāo) / 事情一大堆 (Shìqing yīdàduī)
spanish: Tengo mucho lío. / Estoy hasta arriba de cosas.

similar: I have no sense of direction.
I can't find my way anywhere.
example:
A: Just meet me at the corner of 5th and 14th.
B: You know I'm bad with directions, right? Can you just send me your location?
A: Haha, my bad. I forgot you're basically helpless without GPS.
B: It's not funny! I'll end up in the wrong borough by accident.
A: Sent. Just follow the blue dot, okay?
B: On my way. Don't leave without me!
japanese: 方向音痴（ほうこうおんち）なんです。／道（みち）がわからなくて。
chinese: 路痴 (Lùchī) / 分不清东南西北 (Fēn bù qīng dōngnánxīběi)
spanish: Me oriento fatal. / Soy un desastre con las direcciones.

example:
A: I heard about the breakup. How are you holding up?
B: It's been tough, but I'm trying to stay busy.
A: That's probably for the best. Let me know if you wanna vent.
B: Thanks, I really appreciate it. Friends like you are a lifesaver.
A: Any time. Let's grab some food tomorrow, my treat.
B: Sounds like a plan. I could definitely use a distraction.
japanese: 調子（ちょうし）はどう？／なんとかやってる？
chinese: 你还撑得住吗? (Nǐ hái chēng de zhù ma?) / 最近好吗? (Zuìjìn hǎo ma?)
spanish: ¿Cómo lo llevas? / ¿Qué tal estás aguantando?

primary: All you have to do is do it.
example:
A: I really want to start my own YouTube channel but I'm scared.
B: Honestly? All you have to do is do it. Stop planning and just record something.
A: But what if it's not perfect right away?
B: No one's first video is perfect. You learn as you go.
A: You're right. I'm just gonna pick up the camera today.
B: That's the spirit. Start small and grow from there.
japanese: やるしかないよ。／とにかくやってみなよ。
chinese: 干就完了 (Gàn jiù wán le) / 做了再说 (Zuò le zàishuō)
spanish: Solo tienes que hacerlo. / Lánzate y hazlo.

primary: What do you have in mind?
example:
A: We should definitely do something fun for your birthday.
B: I'm down. What do you have in mind? I'm open to anything.
A: I was thinking we could do a rooftop dinner or something.
B: Ooh, that sounds classy. Which spot were you thinking?
A: There's this new place in Williamsburg with a crazy view.
B: Say less. I'm already there in my head.
japanese: 何（なに）か考（かんが）えがあるの？／どうするつもり？
chinese: 你打算怎么办? (Nǐ dǎsuàn zěnme bàn?) / 你有什么主意? (Nǐ yǒu shénme zhǔyi?)
spanish: ¿Qué tienes pensado? / ¿Qué se te pasa por la cabeza?

example:
A: I'm not going to the party if she's gonna be there.
B: Come on, don't be that way! It's my birthday, just ignore her.
A: You know she always tries to start drama with me.
B: I'll make sure she stays on the other side of the room.
A: Fine, I'll go, but if she says one thing to me, I'm out.
B: Deal. I'm just glad you're coming.
japanese: そんな態度（たいど）とらないでよ。／冷（つめ）たくしないで。
chinese: 别那样 (Bié nàyàng) / 别这副样子 (Bié zhè fù yàngzi)
spanish: No seas así. / Venga, no te pongas así.

example:
A: We've been planning this launch for months.
B: For real. It's finally time to get the ball rolling.
A: Everyone knows their roles, right?
B: Yeah, we're all set. Let's just execute.
A: Perfect. I'll send out the first batch of emails now.
B: Let's do it. Onwards and upwards!
japanese: 始（はじ）めようか。／取（と）り掛（か）かろう。
chinese: 开始行动吧 (Kāishǐ xíngdòng ba) / 步入正轨 (Bùrù zhèngguǐ)
spanish: Pongámonos en marcha. / Vamos a empezar ya.

primary: It costs an arm and a leg.
example:
A: Did you see those new designer shoes at the mall?
B: Yeah, but honestly? It costs an arm and a leg just to look at them.
A: No cap. I love the style, but I have bills to pay.
B: Exactly. I could buy like ten pairs of regular sneakers for that price.
A: Facts. Some things just aren't worth the hype.
B: Definitely. I'll stick to my thrift store finds.
japanese: めっちゃ高（たか）いよ。／ぼったくりレベルだよ。
chinese: 贵得离谱 (Guì de lípǔ) / 宰人呢 (Zǎirén ne)
spanish: Cuesta un ojo de la cara. / Vale un riñón.

example:
A: I'm just trying to finish this task as fast as possible.
B: Look, don't just go through the motions. Quality actually matters here.
A: I know, I'm just feeling a bit burnt out today.
B: Take a break then. It's better to do it right than to do it twice.
A: You're right. I'll step away for a bit and come back refocus.
B: Smart move. Do it right, and you won't have to worry about it later.
japanese: いい加減（かげん）にやらないで。／ちゃんとやって。
chinese: 别走过场 (Bié zǒuguòchǎng) / 别敷衍 (Bié fūyǎn)
spanish: No lo hagas por cumplir. / Ponle ganas.

primary: You took the words right out of my mouth.
similar: That's exactly what I was thinking.
I was about to say that.
example:
A: This coffee shop is way too loud to get any work done.
B: Seriously! You took the words right out of my mouth.
A: Let's just head over to the library instead.
B: I'm down. It's much quieter over there anyway.
A: Facts. Let's pack up our stuff and go.
B: Say less. I'm already out the door.
japanese: まさにそれを言（い）おうとしてた。／先（さき）に言（い）われちゃった。
chinese: 英雄所见略同 (Yīngxióng suǒjiàn lüètóng) / 我正要这么说呢 (Wǒ zhèngyào zhème shuō ne)
spanish: Me lo has quitado de la boca. / Justo iba a decir eso.

example:
A: I was just joking about your new haircut, chill out.
B: Honestly? You crossed the line when you brought up my insecurities.
A: My bad, I didn't realize it would bother you that much.
B: Some things just aren't funny, man. You gotta know the limit.
A: You're right. I'm really sorry. I didn't mean any harm.
B: I appreciate the apology. Let's just not go there again.
japanese: それは言（い）い過（す）ぎだよ。／一線（いっせん）を越（こ）えてるよ。
chinese: 过分了啊 (Guòfèn le a) / 越界了 (Yuèjiè le)
spanish: Te has pasado. / Te has pasado de la raya.

similar: He really knows what he's talking about.
example:
A: Should I ask the new guy for help with the coding issue?
B: Definitely. He really knows his stuff when it comes to React.
A: That's good to hear. I was struggling with this component for hours.
B: He'll probably fix it in like five minutes. He's a wizard.
A: Alright, I'll go hit him up now.
B: Good luck. Let me know what he says.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は詳（くわ）しいよ。／彼（かれ）はプロだよ。
chinese: 他在行 (Tā zàiháng) / 他有两下子 (Tā yǒu liǎngxiàzi)
spanish: Él sabe de lo que habla. / Es un hacha en lo suyo.

example:
A: This week has been such a struggle at work.
B: I know it's tough, but hang in there! Only two more days till the weekend.
A: I'm honestly just counting down the hours at this point.
B: You've got this. Keep your head up and push through.
A: Thanks for the encouragement. It really helps during these long shifts.
B: Any time. You're almost there!
japanese: 踏（ふ）ん張（ば）って！／持（も）ちこたえて！
chinese: 坚持住! (Jiānchí zhù!) / 挺住! (Tǐng zhù!)
spanish: ¡Aguanta! / ¡No te rindas!

primary: You need to break the habit.
example:
A: I keep checking my phone every five minutes without even thinking.
B: You really need to break that habit. It's killing your focus.
A: I know, but it feels like an addiction at this point.
B: Try leaving it in another room while you're working.
A: That's a good idea. I'll give it a shot today.
B: Trust me, you'll feel way more productive.
japanese: その癖（くせ）直（なお）しなよ。／いい加減（かげん）やめなよ。
chinese: 改改这个毛病 (Gǎigǎi zhège máobìng) / 戒掉这个习惯 (Jièdiào zhège xíguàn)
spanish: Tienes que dejar ese hábito. / Corta con eso ya.

primary: You hit the nail on the head.
example:
A: I think the real reason we're losing customers is the checkout process.
B: Wow, you really hit the nail on the head. That's exactly where the drop-off happens.
A: It's just too complicated and takes too many steps.
B: Facts. We need to streamline it as much as possible.
A: Let's start working on a simpler design today.
B: I'm all for it. That should definitely boost our numbers.
japanese: 図星（ずぼし）だね。／核心（かくしん）を突（つ）いてるね。
chinese: 一针见血 (Yīzhēnjiànxiě) / 说到点子上了 (Shuō dào diǎnzi shàng le)
spanish: Has dado en el clavo. / Lo has clavado.

primary: My brain is not as good as it used to be.
similar: I'm not as sharp as before.
I feel a bit rusty lately.
example:
A: Do you remember the name of that movie we watched last night?
B: Honestly? My brain is not as good as it used to be. I already forgot.
A: Haha, it was 'Inception'! How could you forget that?
B: I don't know, man. Lately I just can't keep names straight.
A: It's all good. Maybe you just need some more sleep.
B: Facts. I'm definitely feeling a bit sluggish.
japanese: 頭（あたま）が回（まわ）らなくなってきた。／焼（や）きが回（まわ）ったかな。
chinese: 记性大不如前 (Jìxìng dà bùrú qián) / 脑子不好使了 (Nǎozi bù hǎoshǐ le)
spanish: Ya no tengo la cabeza como antes. / Estoy perdiendo facultades.

example:
A: How much did you pay for that bottle of water at the concert?
B: Ten bucks. I honestly felt like I was being ripped off.
A: That's highway robbery! They really know people are desperate.
B: For real. I should've just brought my own reusable bottle.
A: Live and learn, I guess. At least you're hydrated now.
B: Facts, but my wallet is definitely feeling lighter.
japanese: ぼったくられたよ。／高（たか）すぎたよ。
chinese: 被宰了 (Bèi zǎi le) / 被坑了 (Bèi kēng le)
spanish: Me han timado. / Me han estafado.

example:
A: Where are you right now?
B: I'm out and about, running errands.
A: Can you grab milk?
B: Sure, I'm near the bodega.
A: Thanks, you save my life.
B: No problem, headed home soon.
japanese: 出先（でさき）だよ。／外（そと）まわり中（ちゅう）だよ。
chinese: 外出了 (Wàichū le) / 在外面办事呢 (Zài wàimiàn bànshì ne)
spanish: Estoy por ahí. / Ando de un lado para otro.

primary: I can't get that off my mind.
similar: It's all I can think about.
example:
A: You've been staring at that same page for twenty minutes.
B: I know. I just can't get that conversation we had earlier off my mind.
A: Was it that bad? I thought we cleared things up.
B: It's not that, it's just a lot to process, you know?
A: I feel you. Just take your time with it.
B: Thanks. I'll try to focus on something else for a bit.
japanese: 頭（あたま）から離（はな）れないんだ。／気（き）になって仕方（しかた）ない。
chinese: 挥之不去 (Huīzhībùqù) / 总是想着这事儿 (Zǒngshì xiǎngzhe zhè shìr)
spanish: No me lo quito de la cabeza. / Le doy muchas vueltas.

example:
A: I think I can finish this whole project in one night.
B: Look, don't kid yourself. You know that's not gonna happen.
A: But I'm feeling really motivated right now!
B: Motivation is great, but physics and time are still real things.
A: Fine, maybe I'll need two nights then.
B: Better. Let's aim for a realistic deadline instead.
japanese: 自惚（うぬぼ）れないで。／現実（げんじつ）を見（み）なよ。
chinese: 别自欺欺人了 (Bié zìqīqīrén le) / 别做白日梦了 (Bié zuò báirìmèng le)
spanish: No te engañes. / Abre los ojos.

similar: It's no walk in the park.
example:
A: How was the half-marathon? Was it as fun as you expected?
B: Honestly? It's no picnic. My legs are basically jelly right now.
A: I bet. Twenty-one kilometers is a long way to run.
B: For real. The hills at the end were especially brutal.
A: I'm still proud of you for finishing though!
B: Thanks. I'm definitely taking a break from running for a while.
japanese: 楽（らく）じゃないよ。／一筋縄（ひとすじなわ）ではいかないよ。
chinese: 不容易 (Bù róngyì) / 挺费劲的 (Tǐng fèijìn de)
spanish: No es camino de rosas. / No es nada fácil.

example:
A: I still can't believe he said those mean things to me.
B: Look, it happened weeks ago. You just need to let it go.
A: It's hard though. I really thought he was my friend.
B: Some people aren't worth the energy. Focus on yourself instead.
A: You're right. I'm just wasting my time thinking about him.
B: Exactly. Let's go out and have some fun instead.
japanese: 忘（わす）れなよ。／水（みず）に流（なが）そう。
chinese: 随它去吧 (Suí tā qù ba) / 算了吧 (Suàn le ba)
spanish: Déjalo estar. / Olvídalo ya.

example:
A: I'm quitting my job to become a mime.
B: You need to come to your senses.
A: It's my passion!
B: It doesn't pay rent.
A: Money isn't everything.
B: In New York? Yes, it is.
japanese: 正気（しょうき）に戻（もど）れよ。／現実（げんじつ）を見（み）ろよ。
chinese: 清醒点儿吧 (Qīngxǐng diǎnr ba) / 找回理智 (Zhǎohuí lǐzhì)
spanish: Entra en razón. / Recupera el juicio.

example:
A: We've been at this for ten hours. My brain is officially fried.
B: Honestly? Let's call it a day. We can finish this in the morning.
A: I'm all for it. I'm literally seeing spots at this point.
B: Facts. Everyone go home, get some rest, and we'll regroup then.
A: Sounds like a plan. Safe travels everyone!
B: Peace out! See you tomorrow.
japanese: 今日（きょう）はここまで。／切（き）り上（あ）げよう。
chinese: 今天就到这儿吧 (Jīntiān jiù dào zhèr ba) / 散会 (Sànhuì)
spanish: Por hoy ya está bien. / Dejémoslo por hoy.

example:
A: Did you see him throwing a tantrum in the middle of the store?
B: Yeah, it was so embarrassing. Honestly? He needs to act his age.
A: For real. You're thirty-five, not five. Calm down.
B: Some people just never learn how to regulate their emotions.
A: It's honestly just sad to watch.
B: Facts. Maturity is clearly not inherited.
japanese: 年相応（としそうおう）に振（ふ）る舞（ま）いなよ。／大人（おとな）げないよ。
chinese: 成熟点儿 (Chéngshú diǎnr) / 干点大人的事儿 (Gàn diǎn dàrén de shìr)
spanish: Compórtate como un adulto. / A ver si maduras.

similar: It was too complex for me.
example:
A: Did you understand the technical part of the presentation?
B: Not at all. Honestly? Most of it just went over my head.
A: I feel you. Those charts were incredibly confusing.
B: For real. I'm gonna have to ask for a simplified summary later.
A: Same. I don't think anyone in that room actually followed along.
B: Facts. They really need to work on their communication skills.
japanese: 理解（りかい）できなかった。／難（むずか）しすぎた。
chinese: 没听懂 (Méi tīng dǒng) / 深奥了点 (Shēn'ào le diǎn)
spanish: No me he enterado de nada. / Se me escapa.

example:
A: (Calling) Hi, are you open today?
B: Yes, until 9 PM.
A: Do I need a reservation?
B: Walk-ins are fine.
A: Great, see you in ten.
B: We'll be here.
japanese: 今日（きょう）やってますか？／営業（えいぎょう）してますか？
chinese: 今天开门吗? (Jīntiān kāimén ma?) / 营业吗? (Yíngyè ma?)
spanish: ¿Abrís hoy? / ¿Estáis abiertos?

example:
A: I can't believe I spilled a tiny bit of coffee on my shirt!
B: Look, it's barely noticeable. Don't make a big deal out of it.
A: But I have an important meeting in twenty minutes!
B: Just dab it with some water, it'll be fine. No one's gonna be staring at your chest.
A: Alright, alright. I'm just overthinking it.
B: Facts. Just focus on your presentation instead.
japanese: 大騒（おおさわ）ぎしないで。／大（おお）げさにしないで。
chinese: 别小题大做 (Bié xiǎotídàzuò) / 别大惊小怪的 (Bié dàjīngxiǎoguài de)
spanish: No hagas un mundo de ello. / No le des tanta importancia.

similar: To make a long story short.
example:
A: Can you explain the whole situation with the merger?
B: Well, in a nutshell, we're combining two teams to save on costs.
A: So are there gonna be layoffs then?
B: That's the part we're still figuring out, but hopefully not.
A: I see. Thanks for clarify it so clearly.
B: No problem. I'll keep you posted as I hear more.
japanese: 一言（ひとこと）で言（い）えば／要（よう）するに
chinese: 简而言之 (Jiǎn'éryánzhī) / 概括地说 (Gàikuò de shuō)
spanish: En resumidas cuentas. / Total, que...

example:
A: We're throwing a surprise party for him this Friday.
B: Ooh, I love surprises! I'll definitely be there.
A: Just whatever you do, don't spill the beans! He has no idea.
B: My lips are sealed. I'm actually really good at keeping secrets.
A: Good to hear. We want this to be a total shock.
B: Bet. He's gonna be so hyped.
japanese: 秘密（ひみつ）をもらさないでね。／バラさないでね。
chinese: 别走漏风声 (Bié zǒulòu fēngshēng) / 守口如瓶 (Shǒukǒurúpíng)
spanish: No te vayas de la lengua. / No sueltes prenda.

example:
A: Hey, are you guys open?
B: We close in 5 minutes.
A: Can we just get takeout?
B: Kitchen is closed, sorry.
A: Man, we're starving.
B: Try the pizza place next door.
japanese: 営業（えいぎょう）してますか？／まだやってる？
chinese: 你们开业吗? (Nǐmen kāiyè ma?) / 营业中吗? (Yíngyèzhōng ma?)
spanish: ¿Estáis abiertos? / ¿Seguís atendiendo?

primary: I'm going to keep my eyes peeled.
similar: I'll keep a sharp eye out.
example:
A: I lost my keys somewhere near the park. Have you seen them?
B: Haven't seen them yet, but I'm going to keep my eyes peeled for you.
A: Thanks, man. They've got a little green keychain on them.
B: Got it. I'll hit you up as soon as I spot anything.
A: I really appreciate the help. I'm so stressed right now.
B: Chill, we'll find them. Stay positive.
japanese: 目（め）を光（ひか）らせておくよ。／注意（ちゅうい）して見（み）ておくよ。
chinese: 我会留意观察的 (Wǒ huì liúyì guānchá de) / 睁大眼睛找 (Zhēngdà yǎnjīng zhǎo)
spanish: Estaré atento. / No le quitaré ojo.

similar: I'm with you all the way.
example:
A: I'm finally gonna ask for that promotion this afternoon.
B: Go for it! Honestly, I'm right behind you 100%.
A: Thanks. I'm still a little nervous about how they'll react.
B: You've earned it, so just be confident and state your case.
A: Your support really means a lot to me. Fingers crossed!
B: You'll kill it. Let's celebrate after work either way.
japanese: 応援（おうえん）してるよ。／バックアップするよ。
chinese: 我挺你 (Wǒ tǐng nǐ) / 我在你身后支持你 (Wǒ zài nǐ shēnhòu zhīchí nǐ)
spanish: Te apoyo en todo. / Estoy contigo a muerte.

example:
A: I'm just saying, maybe if you cleaned up more occasionally...
B: Ugh, there you go again. Can we please just have one meal without an argument?
A: I'm just trying to have a reasonable conversation about the house!
B: Your timing is always the worst though. Let's just eat.
A: Fine, but we're talking about this later tonight.
B: Great. Looking forward to it already.
japanese: また始（はじ）まった。／またそれ？
chinese: 又来了 (Yòu lái le) / 老调重弹 (Lǎodiàochòngtán)
spanish: Ya estamos otra vez. / Otra vez con lo mismo.

example:
A: He cancelled again.
B: Figures.
A: He always has an excuse.
B: He's unreliable, stop inviting him.
A: I keep hoping he'll change.
B: Figures you'd say that.
japanese: やっぱりね。／そう来（く）ると重（おも）った。
chinese: 我就知道 (Wǒ jiù zhīdào) / 意料之中 (Yìliào zhī zhōng)
spanish: Me lo imaginaba. / No me extraña.

example:
A: Is it cold outside?
B: It's snowing. Duh.
A: I didn't look out the window.
B: Check your weather app then.
A: You don't have to be mean.
B: I'm just freezing, sorry.
japanese: 当（あ）たり前（まえ）でしょ。／見（み）ればわかるでしょ。
chinese: 废话 (Fèihuà) / 那还用说 (Nà hái yòng shuō)
spanish: Pues claro. / Obvio.

example:
A: Are you done with the report yet? How about now? Now?
B: Honestly? Stop bugging me! I told you I'll have it by 5 PM.
A: I just wanted to make sure we're on track.
B: Your constant questions are actually making me slower. Chill out.
A: Alright, alright. I'll leave you alone for now.
B: Thank you. I really need to focus.
japanese: 構（かま）わないで。／うざいからやめて。
chinese: 别烦我 (Bié fán wǒ) / 别缠着我 (Bié chánzhe wǒ)
spanish: Deja de darme la lata. / No me rayes más.

similar: I know exactly how you feel.
example:
A: I feel so embarrassed for tripping in front of everyone.
B: Don't even worry about it. I've been there before, trust me.
A: Everyone probably thinks I'm such a klutz now.
B: In three minutes, they'll have forgotten all about it. Stay chill.
A: I hope so. It was just so public, you know?
B: Facts. But honestly, most people are too busy with their own stuff to care.
japanese: 私（わたし）も経験（けいけん）あるよ。／わかる、その気持（きも）ち。
chinese: 我也经历过 (Wǒ yě jīnglì guò) / 感同身受 (Gǎntóngshēnshòu)
spanish: Ya he pasado por eso. / Sé lo que es.

primary: We're working with a skeleton crew.
similar: Only a few people are here.
example:
A: Why is service taking so long at the restaurant today?
B: Honestly? We're working with a skeleton crew because of the flu going around.
A: Oh, that makes sense. I apologize for being impatient.
B: No worries. We're doing our best with what we've got.
A: I'll just be patient then. I'm in no rush anyway.
B: I appreciate the understanding. Your food should be out soon.
japanese: 人手不足（ひとでぶそく）なんです。／ギリギリの人数（にんずう）でやってます。
chinese: 人手严重不足 (Rénshǒu yánzhòng bùzú) / 只有几个核心人员 (Zhǐyǒu jǐ gè héxīn rényuán)
spanish: Estamos en cuadro. / Somos cuatro gatos hoy.

example:
A: Why don't we just use the new software for the project?
B: That's the thing... it's not compatible with our current systems.
A: Oh... I didn't realize that was an issue.
B: Yeah, we'd have to upgrade everything, which costs a fortune.
A: Well, that's a huge hurdle then.
B: Facts. We're gonna have to stick with the old way for now.
japanese: そこが問題（もんだい）なんだよ。／それがねえ...
chinese: 问题就在这儿 (Wèntí jiù zài zhèr) / 关键就在这儿 (Guānjiàn jiù zài zhèr)
spanish: Ese es el tema. / Ahí está la cosa.

example:
A: I found this book very intriguing.
B: What's it about?
A: Time travel and coffee.
B: Weird combo.
A: But it works somehow.
B: Might borrow it after you.
japanese: 興味深（きょうみぶか）いね。／面白（おもしろ）いね。
chinese: 很有趣 (Hěn yǒuqu) / 挺勾人的 (Tǐng gōurén de)
spanish: Intrigante. / Curioso.

example:
A: My phone just ran out of battery right when I needed it most.
B: Don't even stress. It happens all the time to the best of us.
A: It's just so frustrating! I was in the middle of a call.
B: Next time just keep a portable charger with you. Game changer.
A: You're right. I'm just gonna go plug it in now.
B: Better late than never. I'll wait for you to come back online.
japanese: よくあることだよ。／日常茶飯事（にちじょうさはんじ）だよ。
chinese: 司空见惯了 (Sīkōngjiànguàn le) / 经常发生 (Jīngcháng fāshēng)
spanish: Pasa a cada rato. / Es el pan de cada día.

similar: Nothing that proves it for sure.
example:
A: I'm pretty sure he stole the idea, but I can't prove it.
B: That's the problem. There is no smoking gun, so it's your word against his.
A: It's so frustrating! I know it's my concept.
B: I believe you, but without some kind of paper trail, it's tough.
A: I'll start keeping better notes and records from now on.
B: Smart move. Protect yourself for next time.
japanese: 決定打（けっていだ）がないね。／確証（かくしょう）がないね。
chinese: 没有铁证 (Méiyǒu tiězhèng) / 证据不足 (Zhèngjù bùzú)
spanish: No hay pruebas contundentes. / No hay nada definitivo.

example:
A: Why are you being so quiet? Are you still mad about the game?
B: Honestly? Yeah, I'm salty because we should've won that one easily.
A: It was a close game, though! You played really well.
B: That doesn't matter if we didn't get the W. Let's just go home.
A: Alright, alright. Don't be such a sore loser.
B: Whatever. I'll be over it tomorrow morning.
japanese: イライラしてるんだ。／不機嫌（ふきげん）なんだ。
chinese: 我有点不爽 (Wǒ yǒudiǎn bùshuǎng) / 闹别扭呢 (Nào bièniu ne)
spanish: Estoy picado. / Estoy molesto.

similar: Believe me, you don't wanna hear it.
example:
A: How was your meeting with the scary boss today?
B: Look, you don't even want to know. It was a total disaster.
A: Was it really that bad? Did they mention the budget thing?
B: Just stop asking. I'm trying to erase the last hour from my memory.
A: Alright, alright. I'll stop bugging you. Let's just grab a drink.
B: Best idea you've had all day. Let's go.
japanese: 知（し）らない方（ほう）がいいよ。／聞（き）かない方（ほう）が身（み）のためだよ。
chinese: 你还是别知道的好 (Nǐ háishì bié zhīdào de hǎo) / 说来话长，别打听了 (Shuō lái huà cháng, bié dǎting le)
spanish: Mejor no quieras saberlo. / No preguntes.

example:
A: Did you watch that documentary?
B: Yeah, the cult one? Fascinating.
A: I couldn't look away.
B: People are so easily manipulated.
A: Scary but true.
B: Totally fascinating psychology.
japanese: 魅力的（みりょくてき）だね。／引（ひ）き込（こ）まれるね。
chinese: 非常迷人 (Fēicháng mírén) / 太引人入胜了 (Tài yǐnrénrùshèng le)
spanish: Fascinante. / Increíble.

similar: I was held up in traffic.
It was a parking lot out there.
example:
A: You're finally here! We were about to start without you.
B: My bad, I got stuck in traffic on the BQE for like forty minutes.
A: That road is literally always a nightmare. I hate it.
B: For real. I should've just taken the train, it would've been way faster.
A: Well, you're here now. Let's get down to business.
B: Facts. I'm ready to go.
japanese: 渋滞（じゅうたい）にはまった。／道（みち）が混（こ）んでて。

example:

similar: We've gotta think outside the box.
example:

example:

B: Facts. That's a real game changer for the wallet.

chinese: 总比没有强 (Zǒng bǐ méiyǒu qiáng) / 聊胜于无 (Liáoshèngyúwú)

example:

example:

example:

example:

similar: It's taking a backseat for now.

example:

example:

A: Alright, let's get down to business then.
B: Bet. Hand me that Allen wrench.
japanese: 簡単（かんたん）だよ。／どうってことないよ。
chinese: 这很简单 (Zhè hěn jiǎndān) / 没什么难的 (Méishénme nán de)
spanish: No tiene misterio. / Está chupado.

similar: Wait till you hear this part.
example:
A: I found the perfect apartment in the Lower East Side for only $1500!
B: Wow! That's an insane deal. What's the catch?
A: But there's a twist... the landlord says I have to share it with three ghosts.
B: Haha, you're kidding right? Please tell me you're joking.
A: I wish! I'm actually starting to think it might be haunted for real.
B: Save your money and keep looking. No ghost-mates for me!
japanese: でもオチがあるんだ。／でも一筋縄（ひとすじなわ）ではいかないんだ。
chinese: 但有个反转 (Dàn yǒu gè fǎnzhuǎn) / 剧情有变 (Jùqíng yǒu biàn)
spanish: Pero hay un giro. / Pero hay una sorpresa.

example:
A: Is the server still crashing every five minutes?
B: No, looks like we're finally out of the woods. The traffic has stabilized.
A: Thank goodness! I was about to have a mental breakdown.
B: For real. That was a stressful three hours for everyone involved.
A: Let's just monitor it for another hour just to be totally safe though.
B: Smart move. I'll keep an eye on the analytics.
japanese: 危機（きき）は脱（だっ）したよ。／峠（とうげ）は越（こ）えたよ。
chinese: 脱离险境了 (Tuōlí xiǎnjìng le) / 渡过难关了 (Dùguò nánguān le)
spanish: Ya salimos del peligro. / Ya pasamos lo peor.

example:
A: What time should we head out for dinner tonight?
B: Honestly? Let's just play it by ear. It depends on when everyone finishes work.
A: Alright, just hit me up when you're ready to leave then.
B: For sure. I'll give you a thirty-minute heads up.
A: Sounds like a plan. I'm just gonna chill here till then.
B: Bet. Catch you later.
japanese: 臨機応変（りんきおうへん）にいこう。／出（で）たとこ勝負（しょうぶ）でいこう。
chinese: 见机行事 (Jiànjī xíngshì) / 到时候再说 (Dào shíhou zàishuō)
spanish: Vamos viendo. / Improvisemos.

example:
A: So, whatever happened with that guy you were seeing last month?
B: Look, don't even bring it up. It ended very, very badly.
A: Oh snap... my bad! I didn't know it was that serious.
B: It's fine, I'm just trying to delete him from my memory entirely.
A: I feel you. Let's talk about something way more positive instead.
B: Best idea. Tell me more about that new project you're working on.
japanese: その話（はなし）はしないで。／触（ふ）れないで。
chinese: 提都别提 (Tí dōu bié tí) / 别再说这事了 (Bié zài shuō zhè shì le)
spanish: Ni lo menciones. / Ni hables de eso.

primary: Your eyes are bigger than your stomach.
similar: You took more than you can handle.
Be realistic about what you can finish.
example:
A: I think I'm gonna order two more large pizzas for the party.
B: Look, your eyes are bigger than your stomach! We still have leftovers from last time.
A: I just don't want anyone to go hungry, you know?
B: I get it, but we already have plenty of snacks too. Chill on the pizza.
A: Alright, maybe you're right. I'll just get one more instead.
B: Still probably too much, but whatever. Suit yourself.
japanese: 欲張（よくば）りすぎだよ。／食（た）べきれないでしょ。
chinese: 贪多嚼不烂 (Tānduō jiáo bù làn) / 别眼大肚子小 (Bié yǎn dà dùzi xiǎo)
spanish: Comes con los ojos. / Te serviste demasiado.

example:
A: Do you think my local pizza spot is as good as Joe's in the Village?
B: Honestly? It's not even close. Joe's is in a whole other league.
A: Come on! Mine is pretty solid for a neighborhood joint.
B: Solid, yeah, but Joe's is legendary. There's just no comparison.
A: I guess I need to head down there and do a taste test then.
B: Facts. You'll see exactly what I'm talking about.
japanese: 足元（あしもと）にも及（およ）ばないよ。／比（くら）べものにならないよ。
chinese: 差远了 (Chà yuǎn le) / 没法比 (Méifǎ bǐ)
spanish: No se le acerca ni un poco. / No tiene comparación.

similar: I see why you did that.
example:
A: I decided to quit my corporate job and just travel for a year.
B: Honestly? I don't blame you. That job was killing your soul.
A: It really was. I'm just so ready for a change of pace.
B: For real. You've been working so hard for years, you deserve a break.
A: Thanks for the support. A lot of people think I'm crazy.
B: They're just jealous of your freedom. Live your life!
japanese: 無理（むり）もないよ。／責（せ）められないよ。
chinese: 我不怪你 (Wǒ bù guài nǐ) / 我理解你 (Wǒ lǐjiě nǐ)
spanish: No te culpo. / Yo hubiera hecho lo mismo.

similar: Don't let it get to you.
example:
A: My boss made a really snarky comment about my presentation today.
B: Look, don't let it bother you. He's always like that after his morning meeting.
A: It still hurtful though! I worked so hard on those slides.
B: I know, but you did a great job and everyone else loved it. Stay positive.
A: You're right. I'm just gonna focus on the good feedback instead.
B: Smart move. Negative energy is just not worth your time.
japanese: 気（き）にしないで。／ドンマイ。
chinese: 别往心里去 (Bié wǎng xīnlǐ qù) / 别让它困扰你 (Bié ràng tā kùnrǎo nǐ)
spanish: Que eso no te moleste. / No le hagas caso.

similar: Let me know what you need.
example:
A: I really need some help organizing the event next week.
B: Any time! I'm at your service. Just tell me what needs doing.
A: Could you handle the guest list and the catering details?
B: 100%. I'll get started on it first thing tomorrow morning.
A: You're a lifesaver! I was honestly about to panic.
B: Chill, we've got this. Teamwork makes the dream work!
japanese: 何（なん）でも言（い）って。／手伝（てつだ）うよ。
chinese: 随叫随到 (Suíjiàosuídào) / 为你效劳 (Wèi nǐ xiàoláo)
spanish: Estoy a tu servicio. / ¿En qué te puedo ayudar?

example:
A: How did she stay so calm when the whole system went down?
B: Honestly? She's cool as a cucumber during crises. It's impressive.
A: I'd be running around like a headless chicken, for real.
B: Me too. I don't know how she does it. It must be meditation or something.
A: Either way, I'm glad she's on our team.
B: Facts. We really need that kind of steady energy right now.
japanese: 彼女（かのじょ）は平気（へいき）な顔（かお）してたよ。／全然（ぜんぜん）動（どう）じてなかった。
chinese: 非常冷静 (Fēicháng lěngjìng) / 处变不惊 (Chǔbiànbùjīng)
spanish: Ella es muy tranquila. / Ella no se pone nerviosa.

example:
A: Have you met the new CEO yet? Is he as terrifying as everyone says?
B: Not at all! Honestly, he's super down to earth and actually listens to ideas.
A: Oh wow! That's such a relief to hear.
B: For real. He even ate lunch with us in the breakroom today.
A: That's dope. It's nice to have a leader who actually feels like a human being.
B: 100%. Makes the whole office vibe so much better.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は気取（きと）ってないよ。／堅実（けんじつ）な人（ひと）だよ。
chinese: 很接地气 (Hěn jiēdìqì) / 很朴实 (Hěn pǔshí)
spanish: Él es muy sencillo. / Él tiene los pies en la tierra.

primary: We have to address the problem.
similar: We need to deal with the issue.
example:
A: We've been ignoring the drop in sales for three months now.
B: Look, we have to address the problem before it gets any worse.
A: I agree, but what's our first step? We need more data.
B: Let's start by surveying our most loyal customers. See what's changed.
A: Smart move. I'll set that up by the end of the week.
B: Perfect. Time to be proactive instead of just hoping for the best.
japanese: 問題（もんだい）に対処（たいしょ）しなきゃ。／何（なん）とかしなきゃ。
chinese: 得解决这个问题 (Děi jiějué zhège wèntí) / 必须正视问题 (Bìxū zhèngshì wèntí)
spanish: Tenemos que hablar del problema. / Hay que solucionar esto.

primary: How old do you think I am?
similar: What's your best guess on my age?
Do you think I'm older or younger?
Give me a number on my age.
example:
A: You seem so mature for someone just starting their career.
B: Really? Haha, how old do you think I am? Most people get it wrong.
A: I'd say... maybe twenty-five? You've got that youthful energy.
B: Actually, I'm thirty-two! I just take really good care of my skin.
A: No way! You definitely don't look a day over twenty-two.
B: Haha, I'll take that as a huge win! Thanks for the kind words.
japanese: 何歳（なんさい）に見（み）える？／いくつだと思（おも）う？
chinese: 你猜我多大? (Nǐ cāi wǒ duō dà?) / 你觉得我几岁? (Nǐ juéde wǒ jǐ suì?)
spanish: ¿Cuántos años crees que tengo? / ¿Qué edad me echas?

primary: It put me on the map.
similar: It brought me into the spotlight.
example:
A: How did you get that job at the huge tech firm?
B: Honestly, that viral app I built last year? It really put me on the map.
A: Oh word! I remember seeing that one on Product Hunt.
B: Yeah, it got a lot of buzz very quickly. Companies started reaching out to me after that.
A: That's the dream, for real. Hard work actually paying off.
B: Facts. It's all about that one project that catches the right eyes.
japanese: それで名（な）が知（し）れ渡（わた）ったんだ。／世（よ）に出（で）るきっかけになった。
chinese: 让我一举成名 (Ràng wǒ yījǔchéngmíng) / 让我在这一行有了地位 (Ràng wǒ zài zhè yī háng yǒu le dìwèi)
spanish: Me hizo famoso. / Me dio a conocer.

primary: They are selling like hot cakes.
example:
A: Did you manage to get those new sneakers that dropped today?
B: No way, man! They were selling like hot cakes and sold out in three minutes.
A: That's wild. I was on the site at 10 AM too and I couldn't even load the page.
B: For real. Resellers are probably already hiking the price up to five hundred.
A: I hate that so much. Just ruins the fun for the actual fans.
B: Facts. I'm just gonna wait for the next restock.
japanese: 飛（と）ぶように売（う）れてるよ。／バカ売（う）れしてるよ。
chinese: 非常抢手 (Fēicháng qiǎngshǒu) / 像刚出锅的小吃一样卖得快 (Xiàng gāng chūguō de xiǎochī yīyàng mài de kuài)
spanish: Se venden como pan caliente. / Se están vendiendo muy rápido.

primary: This is at the heart of the matter.
similar: This is what everything centers around.
This is the crux of the situation.
example:
A: Why are we even talking about the office layout again?
B: Look, efficiency is at the heart of the matter. We need to work better.
A: I thought it was just about making the place look nicer.
B: That's a side effect. The real goal is maximizing our output.
A: I see. So the layout actually affects how we collaborate then.
B: Facts. It's the foundation of everything we do here.
japanese: これが核心（かくしん）だよ。／一番大事（いちばんだいじ）なところだよ。
chinese: 这是问题的核心 (Zhè shì wèntí de héxīn) / 关键就在这儿 (Guānjiàn jiù zài zhèr)
spanish: Este es el punto clave. / Esto es lo más importante.

primary: Who do you think I am?
similar: You clearly don't know who you're dealing with.
Do you really think I'd do that?
You have no idea who I am.
example:
A: Are you really gonna try to sneak into the club without an ID?
B: Yo, who do you think I am? I've been doing this since I was eighteen.
A: I'm just saying, the bouncer looks pretty intense tonight.
B: Chill. I've got my ways. Just watch and learn.
A: Alright, if you get kicked out, I'm not waiting for you.
B: Don't even worry. I'll be at the bar before you're even through the line.
japanese: 私（わたし）を誰（だれ）だと思（おも）ってるの？／なめないでよ。
chinese: 你把我当什么人了? (Nǐ bǎ wǒ dāng shénme rén le?) / 你以为我是谁? (Nǐ yǐwéi wǒ shì shuí?)
spanish: ¿Quién te crees que soy? / ¿Por quién me tomas?

example:
A: It started as a small argument over who left the milk out.
B: And then? How did the whole kitchen end up covered in flour?
A: Honestly? It just spiraled out of control. Things were thrown, people were yelling...
B: That sounds like a scene from a movie, for real.
A: It was a nightmare. We're still cleaning up the mess.
B: Facts. I think you guys need a serious roommate meeting soon.
japanese: 収拾（しゅうしゅう）がつかなくなった。／泥沼（どろぬま）化（か）した。
chinese: 失控了 (Shīkòng le) / 局面一发不可收拾 (Júmiàn yīfābùkěshōushi)
spanish: Se salió de control. / Todo se complicó rápido.

similar: It was all over the internet.
example:
A: Did you see that video of the cat playing the piano?
B: Yeah! It quickly went viral this morning. My whole feed is full of it.
A: It's so wholesome though. I've watched it like ten times already.
B: For real. It's the kind of content we all need right now.
A: Facts. I heard the owner is already getting talk show invites.
B: That's wild. The internet is a crazy place for sure.
japanese: あっという間（ま）に広（ひろ）まったね。／バズったね。
chinese: 迅速走红 (Xùnsù zǒuhóng) / 很快就传开了 (Hěn kuài jiù chuánkāi le)
spanish: Se hizo viral rápido. / Se volvió muy popular.

primary: At the end of the day.
similar: When all is said and done.
example:
A: We've been debating which color to paint the walls for three hours.
B: Look, at the end of the day, it's just a wall. We just need to pick one.
A: But the 'vibe' needs to be perfect for the brand!
B: I get it, but we have bigger problems to solve right now.
A: You're right. Let's just go with the light grey and move on.
B: Facts. Decision made. Let's get some lunch.
japanese: 結局（けっきょく）のところ／要（よう）するに
chinese: 说到底 (Shuō dào dǐ) / 归根结底 (Guīgēnjiédǐ)
spanish: A fin de cuentas. / Al final del día.

example:
A: How was the puppy's first day at the park?
B: Oh man, he was full of beans! He ran around for three hours straight.
A: I bet he's fast asleep now though.
B: 100%. He's been snoring for the last two hours. It's adorable.
A: That's the best part about high-energy dogs, they crash hard.
B: Facts. I'm just glad he had a good time.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は元気（げんき）いっぱいだったよ。／ハッスルしてた。
chinese: 精力充沛 (Jīnglì chōngpèi) / 活力十足 (Huólì shízú)
spanish: Tenía mucha energía. / Estaba muy animado.

primary: That is a tough nut to crack.
similar: It's a hard nut to crack.
example:
A: We're still trying to figure out how to reduce our churn rate.
B: Yeah, that is a tough nut to crack. Customers seem so fickle these days.
A: We've tried discounts, better support, everything...
B: Maybe it's not the service, but the actual product itself?
A: That's a scary thought, but you might be right.
B: Facts. It's time for some deep analysis.
japanese: 難（むずか）しい問題（もんだい）だね。／厄介（やっかい）な案件（あんけん）だね。
chinese: 这是块硬骨头 (Zhè shì kuài yìnggǔtou) / 挺难办的 (Tǐng nán bàn de)
spanish: Es un hueso duro de roer. / Es un problema difícil.

example:
A: Are you coming over tonight for dinner?
B: For sure! I haven't seen you in weeks, we really need to chew the fat.
A: I've got so much to tell you about the new job.
B: I bet! I've got some tea to share too. It's gonna be a long night.
A: Perfect. I'll have the wine ready.
B: Say less. I'm on my way.
japanese: 積（つ）もる話（はなし）をしよう。／ゆっくりしゃべろう。
chinese: 漫无目的地闲聊 (Mànwúmùdìde xiánliáo) / 叙叙旧 (Xùxùjiù)
spanish: Vamos a chismear. / Vamos a platicar un rato.

example:
A: We're finally ahead in the fourth quarter!
B: That's great, but don't let your guard down. They could still come back.
A: True, their star player just got back on the court.
B: Exactly. Keep the pressure on till the final buzzer sounds.
A: Roger that. We're staying locked in.
B: Facts. No room for mistakes now.
japanese: 油断（ゆだん）しないで。／気（き）を抜（ぬ）かないで。
chinese: 别掉以轻心 (Bié diàoyǐqīngxīn) / 保持警惕 (Bǎochí jǐngtì)
spanish: No bajes la guardia. / Mantente alerta.

similar: They claimed they could do everything.
They offered the world with no way to deliver.
example:
A: The new agency says they can triple our traffic in one month.
B: Look, they're promising the moon. No one can actually guarantee that.
A: I know it sounds too good to be true, but what if they're legit?
B: Trust me, I've heard this before. They just want the contract.
A: I should probably ask for some case studies then.
B: Smart move. Don't believe the hype without some proof.
japanese: 無理（むり）な約束（やくそく）をしたね。／大風呂敷（おおぶろしき）を広（ひろ）げたね。
chinese: 他们漫天许诺 (Tāmen màntiān xǔnuò) / 乱开空头支票 (Luàn kāi kōngtóuzhīpiào)
spanish: Prometieron la luna y las estrellas. / Prometieron demasiado.

example:
A: How is the new intern doing with his first project?
B: Honestly? He's on track. He should be done by Friday.
A: That's good to hear. I was worried the learning curve would be too much.
B: He's a quick learner, for real. Very proactive too.
A: Dope. I'll check in with him tomorrow morning.
B: Sounds good. He's doing a solid job.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は順調（じゅんちょう）だよ。／予定通（よていどお）りだよ。
chinese: 进展顺利 (Jìnzhǎn shùnlì) / 在计划内 (Zài jìhuà nèi)
spanish: Va por buen camino. / Lo está haciendo bien.

primary: It's not as bad as it seems.
example:
A: I accidentally formatted the wrong drive and lost all my notes!
B: Chill, it's not as bad as it seems. We have most of that backed up to the cloud.
A: Wait, really? Even the stuff from this morning?
B: Yeah, the auto-sync actually saved your life. Check your account.
A: Oh my god, you're right! Thank you! I was about to cry.
B: See? Technology actually works sometimes.
japanese: 見（み）た目（め）ほど悪（わる）くないよ。／案外（あんがい）なんとかなるよ。
chinese: 没那么糟糕 (Méi nàme zāogāo) / 情况还好 (Qíngkuàng hái hǎo)
spanish: No es tan malo como parece. / No es para tanto.

example:
A: I'm literally shaking right now. What if I mess up my line?
B: Look, just calm your nerves. You've practiced this a hundred times.
A: But the audience is so huge! And my parents are in the front row!
B: Just focus on your breathing. You're gonna be amazing, trust me.
A: Alright, I'm taking a big breath now. Okay, I can do this.
B: That's the spirit. You're a pro.
japanese: 落（お）ち着（つ）いて。／リラックスして。
chinese: 稳住情绪 (Wěnzhù qíngxù) / 别紧张 (Bié jǐnzhāng)
spanish: Calma los nervios. / Tranquilízate.

primary: It was a shot in the arm.
similar: It was a stimulant for the situation.
example:
A: The team was really feeling down after that last loss.
B: Yeah, but that new sponsorship was exactly the shot in the arm we needed.
A: For real. Everyone is so motivated now.
B: It's crazy how much of a difference some good news can make.
A: Facts. We're ready to take on the next challenge with full energy.
B: Let's get it.
japanese: カンフル剤（ざい）になったよ。／元気（げんき）が出（で）たよ。
chinese: 打了一剂强心针 (Dǎ le yī jì qiángxīnzhēn) / 很大的鼓舞 (Hěn dà de gǔwǔ)
spanish: Fue un gran impulso. / Fue justo lo que necesitábamos.

primary: That's the way the ball bounces.
similar: Sometimes things just don't go your way.
example:
A: I was so sure I was gonna win that raffle, but I didn't even place.
B: Well, that's just the way the ball bounces sometimes. Better luck next time.
A: I guess I'll just have to keep trying my luck with other stuff.
B: For real. You can't win them all, right?
A: Facts. It was just a fun little thing anyway.
B: Exactly. Keep that positive attitude going.
japanese: 世（よ）の中（なか）そんなもんだよ。／運（うん）が悪（わる）かったね。
chinese: 这就是命 (Zhè jiù shì mìng) / 事实就是这样 (Shìshí jiùshì zhèyàng)
spanish: Así son las cosas. / Así es la vida.

similar: best thing I heard all day
example:
A: Meeting is cancelled.
B: That's music to my ears.
A: Let's grab lunch early.
B: Way ahead of you.
A: Taco truck?
B: You read my mind.
japanese: それは朗報（ろうほう）だね！／聞（き）けて嬉（うれ）しいよ！
chinese: 这可太好了 (Zhè kě tài hǎo le) / 正合我意 (Zhènghé wǒ yì)
spanish: Me alegra oír eso. / Qué buena noticia.

primary: He was not pulling his weight.
similar: He was a burden on the team.
He wasn't doing his fair share.
example:
A: Why did you decide to let the lead designer go?
B: Honestly? He was not pulling his weight and the rest of the team was frustrated.
A: I noticed some of the projects were falling behind lately.
B: Exactly. Everyone else was working overtime while he was just chilling.
A: That's not fair to anyone. It's better to have a smaller, more dedicated team.
B: Facts. We're already seeing better results without the dead weight.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は足（あし）を引（ひ）っ張（ぱ）ってたよ。／役（やく）に立（た）ってなかった。
chinese: 他不尽职 (Tā bù jìnzhí) / 他出工不出力 (Tā chū gōng bù chū lì)
spanish: No estaba haciendo su parte. / Era una carga.

example:
A: He says he missed the meeting because his alarm clock literally exploded.
B: Honestly? I don't buy it. That sounds like a complete lie.
A: It's a pretty creative excuse though, you gotta admit.
B: Creative, yeah, but definitely not true. He just overslept again.
A: I should probably just give him a formal warning then.
B: Facts. Consistency matters in this office.
japanese: 信（しん）じないよ。／騙（だま）されないよ。
chinese: 我不信 (Wǒ bù xìn) / 少来这套 (Shǎo lái zhè tào)
spanish: No me lo trago. / No lo creo.

similar: I put in effort for my outfit.
I'm ready for the red carpet.
example:
A: Wow! You look amazing today! Where are you going?
B: Thanks! I got all dolled up for that awards ceremony tonight.
A: You're definitely gonna be the star of the show.
B: Haha, I appreciate that! I even did my hair and makeup myself.
A: Teach me your ways! Seriously, you look like a whole different person.
B: It's all about the confidence and some secret lipstick tricks.
japanese: おめかししたんだ。／気合（きあ）い入（い）れて着飾（きかざ）った。
chinese: 打扮得很漂亮 (Dǎban de hěn piàoliang) / 花枝招展的 (Huāzhīzhāozhǎn de)
spanish: Me arreglé mucho. / Me puse guapa.

example:
A: I closed three deals today.
B: Wow, you're on a roll.
A: Just lucky I guess.
B: Nah, you're talented.
A: Drinks on me tonight?
B: I'm not saying no to that.
japanese: 絶好調（ぜっこうちょう）だね！／ノッてるね！
chinese: 你最近运气真好 (Nǐ zuìjìn yùnqi zhēn hǎo) / 你正在兴头上 (Nǐ zhèngzài xìingtóu shàng)
spanish: Estás en racha. / Te está yendo súper bien.

example:
A: Did you get the apartment?
B: No, the deal fell through.
A: What happened?
B: Landlord wanted more deposit.
A: That sucks.
B: Back to Craigslist searching.
japanese: 話（はなし）が流（なが）れたよ。／ダメになった。
chinese: 成交不了了 (Chéngjiāo bù liǎo le) / 黄了 (Huáng le)
spanish: El trato se cayó. / No se hizo el negocio.

primary: I had a falling out with him.
similar: We've stopped speaking to each other.
example:
A: How is your best friend doing? I haven't seen him around lately.
B: Honestly? I had a falling out with him last month. We haven't talked since.
A: Oh no! I'm so sorry to hear that. I thought you guys were inseparable.
B: Yeah, me too, but some things just can't be easily fixed.
A: I feel you. If you ever wanna talk about it, I'm here.
B: Thanks. I appreciate the support, for real.
japanese: 彼（かれ）と仲違（なかたが）いしたんだ。／喧嘩（けんか）別（わか）れした。
chinese: 我和他闹翻了 (Wǒ hé tā nàofān le) / 我们产生隔阂了 (Wǒmen chǎnshēng géhé le)
spanish: Me peleé con él. / Dejé de hablarme con él.

example:
A: I'm struggling to set up this new coffee machine. There are so many buttons!
B: Chill out. It's not rocket science. Just press the 'brew' button after adding water.
A: But what about all these other settings? 'Aroma', 'Strength'...
B: Just ignore those for now. Start with the basics and you'll be fine.
A: Alright, alright. I'm overthinking it as usual.
B: Facts. Just focus on your morning cup of joe.
japanese: 難（むずか）しいことじゃないよ。／誰（だれ）にでもできるよ。
chinese: 并不难 (Bìng bù nán) / 没什么深奥的 (Méishénme shēn'ào de)
spanish: No es ciencia nuclear. / No es tan difícil.

primary: We all have to pick up the slack.
similar: We need to compensate for the missing effort.
Everyone needs to help out more.
example:
A: Since two developers left unexpectedly, things have been crazy.
B: I know. We all have to pick up the slack until new hires are on board.
A: I'm already taking on three extra projects myself.
B: For real. It's not ideal, but it's what's needed right now.
A: Hopefully they find some good replacements soon.
B: Facts. We can't keep this pace up forever.
japanese: みんなでカバーしなきゃ。／遅（おく）れを取（と）り戻（もど）さなきゃ。
chinese: 咱们得补上空缺 (Zánmen děi bǔ shàng kòngquē) / 得把剩下的活儿干了 (Děi bǎ shèngxià de huór gàn le)
spanish: Tenemos que cubrir el trabajo. / Hay que echarle ganas entre todos.

primary: I threw caution to the wind.
similar: I just went for it without worrying about the consequences.
example:
A: You actually booked a flight to Bali without checking your bank account?
B: Yeah! I just threw caution to the wind and went for it. YOLO!
A: That's either incredibly brave or very bold of you.
B: A bit of both, I guess. I just really needed a break from reality.
A: I feel you. Sometimes you just gotta take the leap, right?
B: Facts. I'll figure out the money situation later. For now, it's island time.
japanese: 思（おも）い切（き）ってやったよ。／後先（あとさき）考（かんが）えずにやった。
chinese: 豁出去了 (Huō chūqù le) / 不顾一切 (Bùgùyīqiè)
spanish: Me arriesgué. / No lo pensé dos veces.

similar: Don't judge a book by its cover.
example:
A: He's so attractive! But honestly, he's kind of rude to everyone.
B: See? Beauty is only skin deep. You gotta find someone with a good heart.
A: I know, I know. I just wish he was nicer.
B: For real. Aesthetic only takes you so far in a real relationship.
A: Facts. I'm definitely looking for something more substantial now.
B: Exactly. Personality is the real winner.
japanese: 人は見（み）かけによらないよ。／大事（だいじ）なのは中身（なかみ）だよ。
chinese: 美貌只是表面的 (Měimào zhǐshì biǎomiàn de) / 心灵美才是真的美 (Xīnlíng měi cáishì zhēnde měi)
spanish: La belleza es superficial. / Lo que importa es lo de adentro.

similar: I find it hard to say what I mean.
I'm a bit shy in conversations.
example:
A: You should tell her how you really feel. Be romantic!
B: Honestly? I'm not good with words. I always get tongues-tied around her.
A: Try writing her a letter instead. It's more thoughtful and less pressure.
B: That's a good idea. I can take my time and say exactly what I mean.
A: Exactly. Just be sincere and she'll love it.
B: Thanks for the advice. I'll get started on that tonight.
japanese: 口下手（くちべた）なんです。／言葉（ことば）にするのが苦手（にがて）で。
chinese: 我不善辞令 (Wǒ bùshàn cílìng) / 我挺笨嘴拙舌的 (Wǒ tǐng bènzuǐzhuōshé de)
spanish: No soy bueno con las palabras. / Me cuesta expresarme.

similar: I'm at the end of my energy.
example:
A: Do you wanna grab a late-night snack after this shift?
B: Honestly? I'm running on fumes. I just want to go home and sleep.
A: I feel you. It's been a long day for both of us.
B: For real. I've been awake for like eighteen hours. My brain is fried.
A: Get some rest then! We'll catch up tomorrow when you're human again.
B: Facts. See you later.
japanese: もうヘトヘトだよ。／ガス欠（けつ）寸前（すんぜん）だよ。
chinese: 精疲力竭 (Jīngpílìjié) / 累得快虚脱了 (Lèi de kuài xūtuō le)
spanish: No puedo más. / Estoy agotado.

example:
A: Should we ask the team which direction we should go for the project?
B: Look, I call the shots around here. We're going with my plan.
A: I just thought some extra input would be helpful.
B: I appreciate that, but I have the most experience and I'm leading this.
A: Alright, if that's how it's gonna be. I'll just follow the lead.
B: Smart move. Let's stay focused and execute.
japanese: 私（わたし）が仕切（しき）るよ。／決定権（けっていけん）は私（わたし）にある。
chinese: 我说了算 (Wǒ shuō le suàn) / 我做主 (Wǒ zuòzhǔ)
spanish: Yo soy el que manda. / Yo decido aquí.

primary: I have butterflies in my stomach.
similar: I have that nervous fluttering feeling.
example:
A: You're about to go out on stage in front of five thousand people!
B: I know! I have serious butterflies in my stomach right now.
A: Just take a deep breath and remember why you're here.
B: I'm trying! But my hands are literally shaking. This is insane.
A: You've got this. Once you get out there, the nerves will fade away.
B: Thanks. I'm going for it. See you on the other side!
japanese: ドキドキしてる。／緊張（きんちょう）で胃（い）が痛（いた）い。
chinese: 我心里忐忑不安 (Wǒ xīnlǐ tǎntè bù'ān) / 我挺紧张的 (Wǒ tǐng jǐnzhāng de)
spanish: Tengo mariposas en el estómago. / Estoy muy nervioso.

similar: They saw your message and didn't reply.
example:
A: It's been six hours and he still hasn't replied to my text.
B: Ouch. Looks like you've been left on read, my friend.
A: But he was just active on Instagram two minutes ago!
B: That's a classic sign. Honestly? Just let it go for now.
A: I hate that feeling so much. It's so awkward.
B: Facts. Don't double text. Just wait and see if he eventually reaches out.
japanese: 既読（きどく）スルーされたね。／無視（むし）されてるね。
chinese: 被无视了 (Bèi wúshì le) / 已读不回 (Yǐ dú bù huí)
spanish: Te dejaron en visto. / Te ignoraron.

similar: She was overly fond of me.
She really took great care of me.
example:
A: It's so nice to see how much your grandma loves you.
B: Yeah, she always doted on me when I was growing up. I was her favorite.
A: I can tell! She always has your favorite cookies ready when we visit.
B: For real. She's the best. I try to visit her as often as I can.
A: That's sweet. Family connections like that are precious.
B: Facts. I really appreciate everything she's done for me.
japanese: 彼女（かのじょ）は私（わたし）を猫（ねこ）っ可愛（かわ）がりした。／甘（あま）やかされた。
chinese: 她很疼我 (Tā hěn téng wǒ) / 她把我当个宝 (Tā bǎ wǒ dāng gè bǎo)
spanish: Me consentía mucho. / Me mimaba.

similar: I created it entirely by myself.
example:
A: This pasta sauce is incredible! Where did you get the recipe?
B: Honestly? I made it from scratch using tomatoes from my own garden.
A: No way! This tastes like it's from a high-end restaurant.
B: Thanks! It takes a while to simmer everything down, but it's totally worth it.
A: You should definitely start selling this. People would love it.
B: Maybe one day! For now, it's just for friends.
japanese: 一（いち）から手作（てづく）りしたんだ。／全（ずべ）て自分（じぶん）で作（つく）った。
chinese: 从头开始做的 (Cóngtóu kāishǐ zuò de) / 纯手工制作 (Chún shǒugōng zhìzuò)
spanish: Lo hice desde cero. / Lo hice yo mismo.

similar: Don't take credit for my work.
Stop taking the spotlight for yourself.
example:
A: I was just about to tell everyone about the new partnership...
B: But I already posted it on the company Slack channel this morning!
A: Yo! Don't steal my thunder like that! I wanted to announce it officially.
B: My bad! I thought you wanted it out as soon as possible.
A: I did, but I also wanted to share the credit with the team during the meeting.
B: I see. I'm sorry. I'll let you handle the rest of the updates then.
japanese: 手柄（てがら）を横取（よこど）りしないで。／いいとこ取（と）りしないで。
chinese: 别抢我的风头 (Bié qiǎng wǒ de fēngtóu) / 别抢我的功劳 (Bié qiǎng wǒ de gōngláo)
spanish: No me robes el protagonismo. / No me opaques.

example:
A: Did you ask him about the missing files yet?
B: Yeah, but as soon as I mentioned the budget, he just clammed up.
A: That's suspicious. He's usually so talkative about everything else.
B: For real. It's like he's hiding something he doesn't want me to find.
A: I should probably have a more formal chat with him tomorrow.
B: Good luck with that. He's acting very strange lately.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は黙（だま）り込（こ）んじゃった。／貝（かい）になっちゃった。
chinese: 他守口如瓶 (Tā shǒukǒurúpíng) / 他一言不发 (Tā yīyánbùfā)
spanish: Se quedó callado. / No dijo ni pío.

primary: I would go on a spending spree.
similar: I'd spend all my money at once.
I'd blow all my cash on fun things.
example:
A: If I won the lottery today, the first thing I'd do is hire a financial advisor.
B: Not me! I would go on a huge spending spree at all the luxury stores in SoHo.
A: Aren't you worried about running out of money eventually?
B: Not with a hundred million dollars! I'd have plenty to spare.
A: Facts, but I'd still be nervous about losing it all overnight.
B: Live a bit! Life is too short for all that worry.
japanese: 豪遊（ごうゆう）したいな。／パーッと使（つか）いたい。
chinese: 我要疯狂购物 (Wǒ yào fēngkuáng gòuwù) / 我要买买买 (Wǒ yào mǎi mǎi mǎi)
spanish: Gastaría sin control. / Compraría de todo.

primary: I don't want to open up a can of worms.
similar: I don't want to cause more problems.
Let's not get into a complicated situation.
I'd rather not start something complex.
Keep the peace by not mentioning it.
example:
A: Should we mention the unresolved issue from last month during the meeting?
B: Honestly? I don't want to open up a can of worms right now. Let's focus on today's tasks.
A: I agree, it might derail the whole conversation for hours.
B: Exactly. We have enough on our plate without more drama.
A: We'll bring it up in a separate session then.
B: Facts. Better to handle it when we have more time to properly deal with it.
japanese: 寝（ね）た子（こ）を起（お）こしたくない。／ややこしくしたくない。
chinese: 我不想惹麻烦 (Wǒ bùxiǎng rě máfan) / 我不想捅娄子 (Wǒ bùxiǎng tǒng lóuzi)
spanish: No quiero abrir la caja de Pandora. / No quiero meter la pata.

similar: No, let me pay for this.
example:
A: This dinner was incredible! Let's split it fifty-fifty.
B: No way, don't worry about it. It's my treat today since you helped me with my project.
A: Are you sure? That was a really expensive meal though.
B: 100%. I really appreciate all your support lately. It means a lot.
A: Thank you so much! I'll get the next round for sure then.
B: Say less. It was my pleasure!
japanese: 私（わたし）のおごりです。／ここは持（も）ちます。
chinese: 我请客 (Wǒ qǐngkè) / 这顿算我的 (Zhè dùn suàn wǒ de)
spanish: Yo invito. / Va por mi cuenta.

similar: Get your head in the game!
example:
A: I was just imagining what it would be like to live on Mars for a year...
B: Yo! Snap out of it! We have a deadline in thirty minutes and you haven't even started.
A: My bad! I got lost in my own thoughts for a second.
B: Clearly! Let's focus on the actual work before the boss gets mad.
A: On it. I'm locked in now, I promise.
B: That's what I like to hear. Let's get it done.
japanese: しっかりして！／目（め）を覚（さ）まして！
chinese: 振作点！ (Zhènzuò diǎn!) / 醒醒吧！ (Xǐngxǐng ba!)
spanish: ¡Reacciona! / ¡Despierta!

primary: You got us into this mess.
similar: It's your fault we're in this situation.
This is all because of you.
You led us into this trouble.
We're here because of your decision.
example:
A: Why are we stuck in the middle of a traffic jam in Brooklyn at midnight?
B: Look, you're the one who thought this shortcut was a 'game changer'! 
A: I didn't know there was literally going to be construction on every single block!
B: Well, you got us into this mess, so now we're just gonna have to wait it out.
A: I'm sorry, okay? I was just trying to save us some time.
B: Next time, let's just use the regular GPS and stay on the main road.
japanese: お前（まえ）のせいだよ。／君（きみ）が巻（ま）いた種（たね）だよ。
chinese: 是你把我们害惨了 (Shì nǐ bǎ wǒmen hài cǎn le) / 都是你惹的祸 (Dōushì nǐ rě de huò)
spanish: Nos metiste en este lío. / Es tu culpa que estemos así.

primary: It's not what it looks like.
similar: There's a logical explanation for this.
example:
A: Why were you at the office at 3 AM with all the lights off?
B: Honestly? It's not what it looks like. I just forgot my keys and didn't want to bother anyone.
A: That sounds incredibly suspicious, don't you think?
B: I know! I was literally crawling through the window when security saw me.
A: Wow, that's intense. I'm just glad you didn't get arrested.
B: Facts. I'm definitely not doing that again.
japanese: 誤解（ごかい）だよ！／見（み）た目（め）とは違（ちが）うんだ！
chinese: 不是你想的那样 (Búshì nǐ xiǎng de nàyàng) / 你误会了 (Nǐ wùhuì le)
spanish: No es lo que parece. / No pienses mal.

example:
A: What's your guilty pleasure?
B: Watching reality trash TV.
A: Like 'Love Island'?
B: Exactly. It's so bad it's good.
A: I won't judge.
B: You watch it too, don't you?
japanese: やめられない楽（たの）しみは何（なに）？／ギルティ・プレジャーってある？
chinese: 你有什么坏习惯？ (Nǐ yǒu shénme huài xíguàn?) / 你的罪恶快感是什么？ (Nǐ de zuìè kuàigǎn shì shénme?)
spanish: ¿Cuál es tu gusto culposo? / ¿Qué es lo que te gusta en secreto?

similar: I was chosen for the worst task.
I ended up with the responsibility no one wanted.
Fate wasn't on my side this time.
I'm stuck with the undesirable duty.
example:
A: Why are you cleaning the coffee machine on a Friday afternoon?
B: Ugh, I got the short straw during the team meeting today. Everyone else escaped.
A: That's rough! It always seems to be you, doesn't it?
B: For real. I think they're secretly out to get me at this point.
A: I'll help you finish it so you can leave earlier too.
B: You're a legend! I really appreciate that, for real.
japanese: 貧乏（びんぼう）くじ引（ひ）いちゃった。／ハズレ引（ひ）いた。
chinese: 我倒霉了 (Wǒ dǎoméi le) / 我抽到了下下签 (Wǒ chōudàole xiàxiàqiān)
spanish: Me tocó bailar con la más fea. / Me tocó la peor parte.

similar: She's the greatest of all time.
She's at the top of her game.
example:
A: Did you see Beyonce's performance last night? It was insane!
B: 100%. She truly is the GOAT. No one else even comes close.
A: The production, the vocals, the energy... it was just a whole different level.
B: Facts. She's been consistent for decades now. It's pure dedication.
A: I want to be like her when I grow up. Not even joking.
B: We all do. She's a true inspiration to everyone.
japanese: 彼女（かのじょ）はマジで神（かみ）だよ。／史上最高（しじょうさいこう）だよ。
chinese: 她真是永远的神 (Tā zhēnshì yǒngyuǎn de shén) / 她是绝对的传奇 (Tā shì juéduì de chuánqí)
spanish: Ella es la mejor de la historia. / Es una leyenda.

primary: I've got a lot of mixed emotions.
similar: I'm feeling many things at once.
I'm not exactly sure how to feel.
example:
A: How do you feel about moving to a whole new city for the first time?
B: Honestly? I've got a lot of mixed emotions. Excitement, but also a lot of fear.
A: That's totally normal! It's a huge life change for you.
B: For real. I'm gonna miss all my friends here, but the new opportunity is dope.
A: Just take it one step at a time. You'll settle in before you know it.
B: Thanks. I'm trying to stay positive and focused on the future.
japanese: 複雑（ふくざつ）な心境（しんきょう）だよ。／何（なん）とも言（い）えない気持（きも）ち。
chinese: 我百感交集 (Wǒ bǎigǎn jiāojí) / 我心情很复杂 (Wǒ xīnqíng hěn fùzá)
spanish: Tengo sentimientos encontrados. / No sé cómo sentirme.

similar: This isn't as bad as it could be.
It's manageable compared to my past experiences.
It's not the end of the world.
I've dealt with more difficult things.
example:
A: Look at the state of this office after the party! It's a disaster!
B: Chill out. I've seen worse. At least there's no permanent damage.
A: You call this manageable? There's literally glitter on every single surface!
B: It'll take a few hours to clean up, but it's not the worst thing I've ever seen.
A: You should've seen my college dorm after finals week then.
B: Facts. This is basically a nursery school compared to that chaos.
japanese: もっと酷（ひど）いの見（み）たことあるよ。／まだマシな方（ほう）だよ。
chinese: 我见过更糟的 (Wǒ jiànguò gèng zāo de) / 这还不算最坏的 (Zhè hái búsuàn zuìhuài de)
spanish: He visto cosas peores. / No está tan mal.

similar: Something is off about this tea.
This tea has a strange flavor.
I'm not liking the taste of this tea.
Is this tea expired or something?
example:
A: You didn't finish your matcha latte. Is everything okay with it?
B: Honestly? The tea tastes funny. It's almost... metallic?
A: Oh no! Maybe the milk was off or the water wasn't filtered correctly.
B: For real. It's definitely not the usual quality I expect from this place.
A: I'll go ask them to remake it for you. You shouldn't have to drink that.
B: Thanks, I appreciate it. I was just gonna leave it but it's so expensive!
japanese: お茶（ちゃ）の味（あじ）が変（へん）だ。／なんかおかしな味（あじ）がする。
chinese: 这茶味道怪怪的 (Zhè chá wèidào guàiguài de) / 茶有点不对劲 (Chá yǒudiǎn búduìjìn)
spanish: El té sabe raro. / El té tiene un sabor extraño.

similar: It's very cheap for the value.
I'm essentially getting it for free.
example:
A: Look at these vintage boots I found for only twenty bucks!
B: No way! They look like they're worth at least two hundred. That's a steal.
A: I know! I saw them in the back of the store and couldn't believe the price tag.
B: You definitely scored big time today. Those are gonna look dope with your outfit.
A: Facts. Thrifting is honestly my favorite thing to do on weekends.
B: Same. Nothing beats that feeling of finding a diamond in the rough.
japanese: 超（ちょう）お買（か）い得（どく）だよ。／タダ同然（どうぜん）だよ。
chinese: 真便宜 (Zhēn piányi) / 简直是白菜价 (Jiǎnzhí shì báicàijià)
spanish: Es una ganga. / Está regalado.

primary: Now is the time to decide.
similar: We can't wait any longer to choose.
The deadline for deciding has arrived.
example:
A: I'm still not sure which summer internship I should take.
B: Look, now is the time to decide. Both offers expire by the end of today.
A: I know, both are so good but for different reasons!
B: Just go with your gut feeling. Which one makes you feel more excited about the work?
A: Honestly? The creative agency one. I'm just worried about the pay.
B: Facts, but the experience might lead to something way bigger later. Just do it!
japanese: 今（いま）が決（き）め時（どき）だよ。／今（いま）決断（けつだん）しなきゃ。
chinese: 现在是做决定的时候了 (Xiànzài shì zuò juédìng de shíhou le) / 该拍板了 (Gāi pāibǎn le)
spanish: Es hora de decidir. / Tienes que decidir ya.

similar: I just went for it spontaneously.
I made it up as I went along.
No planning involved, I just did it.
example:
A: Your presentation today was so smooth! How long did you spend practicing?
B: Honestly? I didn't prepare at all. I just winged it based on what I remembered from the meeting.
A: Wow! You're a natural at public speaking then. I would've been a mess.
B: Thanks! I just try to stay calm and speak from the heart, you know?
A: I wish I had that kind of confidence. I literally have to write everything down.
B: Facts. Whatever works for you though, everyone has their own style.
japanese: ぶっつけ本番（ほんばん）でやったよ。／適当（てきとう）に合（あ）わせたよ。
chinese: 我是临时发挥的 (Wǒ shì línshí fāhuī de) / 我没准备，硬上的 (Wǒ méi zhǔnbèi, yìngshàng de)
spanish: Lo improvisé. / Lo hice al aventón.

example:
A: You ordered a whole pizza?
B: It's my cheat day.
A: I thought you were keto.
B: Not today. Today I feast.
A: Can I have a slice?
B: Get your own, this is mine.
japanese: 今日（きょう）はチートデイなんだ。／好（す）きなもの食（た）べる日（ひ）なんだ。
chinese: 今天是我的放纵日 (Jīntiān shì wǒ de fàngzòngrì) / 今天不管嘴了 (Jīntiān bùguǎn zuǐ le)
spanish: Hoy rompo la dieta. / Hoy como lo que quiera.

primary: I'm at a loss for words.
similar: I don't know what to say.
example:
A: Surprise! We all pitched in to get you that guitar you've been eyeing!
B: Oh my god... I'm at a loss for words right now. You guys are the best.
A: We know how much you've been wanting to start playing again.
B: This is incredible. I'm literally shaking.
A: Just start practicing! We expect a concert by next month.
B: Facts. I'm gonna get on that right away. Thank you so much!
japanese: 言葉（ことば）が出（で）ないよ。／あきれてものが言（い）えない（良（い）い意味（いみ）でも悪（わる）い意味（いみ）でも）。
chinese: 我无语了 (Wǒ wúyǔ le) / 我说不出话来 (Wǒ shuōbùchū huà lái)
spanish: Me quedé sin palabras. / No sé qué decir.

similar: We did more than what was required.
example:
A: The client was absolutely blown away by the final presentation.
B: That's great! We really went the extra mile with those custom animations.
A: For real. It took us all weekend, but it was totally worth it.
B: Facts. Now we're definitely gonna get that contract extension.
A: I'm just glad everyone's hard work paid off.
B: Let's celebrate with a team dinner tonight.
japanese: 特別（とくべつ）な努力（どりょく）をしたよ。／一歩（いっぽ）踏（ふ）み込（こ）んでやった。
chinese: 我们加倍努力了 (Wǒmen jiābèi nǔlì le) / 我们做得超出了预期 (Wǒmen zuò de chāochūle yùqī)
spanish: Hicimos un esfuerzo extra. / Dimos más del cien.

similar: I cut them out of my life.
They are no longer in my circle.
example:
A: Haven't seen you hanging out with that group lately. What happened?
B: Honestly? I canceled them after that drama last weekend. I don't need that energy.
A: Wow, that's a bold move. They were your main friends for a while.
B: I know, but life is too short for toxic people. No cap.
