A: I feel you. Sometimes you just gotta protect your peace.
B: Facts. I'm much happier already.
japanese: 彼（かれ）とは縁（えん）を切（き）ったよ。／ブロックした。
chinese: 我跟他们绝交了 (Wǒ gēn tāmen juéjiāo le) / 我拉黑他们了 (Wǒ lāhēi tāmen le)
spanish: Los cancelé. / Ya no me junto con ellos.

similar: I had so much to do.
example:
A: Sorry I didn't get back to your text yesterday.
B: No worries! I figured you were swamped with work for the big launch.
A: For real. I didn't even have time to eat lunch until 4 PM.
B: That sounds intense. Hope things are calming down today.
A: A little bit, but I still have a mountain of emails to get through.
B: Facts. The grind never stops, huh?
japanese: 仕事（しごと）に追（お）われてたんだ。／めちゃくちゃ忙（いそが）しかった。
chinese: 我忙得不可开交 (Wǒ máng dé bùkěkāijiāo) / 我忙死了 (Wǒ máng sǐ le)
spanish: Estaba hasta el cuello de trabajo. / Tenía muchísima chamba.

similar: You're getting it for next to nothing.
example:
A: I found this high-end blender at a garage sale for five dollars!
B: No way! That's as cheap as chips. Those usually go for over a hundred.
A: I know! I checked the price online as soon as I got home.
B: You really scored big time today. Does it even work?
A: Perfectly. I already made a smoothie this morning.
B: Facts. What a lucky find!
japanese: 激安（げきやす）だよ。／捨て値（すてね）だよ。
chinese: 太便宜了 (Tài piányi le) / 便宜得要命 (Piányi dé yàomìng)
spanish: Está baratísimo. / Cuesta casi nada.

similar: Treat this place like your own.
example:
A: Thanks for letting me stay here while I look for an apartment.
B: Of course! Make yourself at home. There's plenty of space in the fridge.
A: You're a lifesaver. I'll try not to get in the way too much.
B: Chill. We've been friends for years. Just do your thing.
A: I really appreciate it, for real.
B: Say less. Let's grab some takeout tonight.
japanese: くつろいでね。／自分（じぶん）の家（いえ）だと思（おも）って。
chinese: 别客气 (Bié kèqi) / 当自己家一样 (Dāng zìjǐ jiā yíyàng)
spanish: Estás en tu casa. / Siéntete cómodo.

similar: Take the deal as it is.
That's it, take it or walk away.
example:
A: I'll give you fifty bucks for that vintage jacket.
B: No way, it's worth at least eighty. Sixty-five, take it or leave it.
A: Sixty is the most I can do right now, honestly.
B: Alright, fine. Take it or leave it, sixty is the final price.
A: Okay, deal. I've been looking for this specific style for weeks.
B: Facts. It's a classic piece.
japanese: 嫌（いや）ならいいよ。／これで手（て）を打（う）って。
chinese: 要就要，不要拉倒 (Yào jiù yào, búyào lādǎo) / 一口价 (Yìkǒujià)
spanish: Tómalo o déjalo. / Es mi última oferta.

primary: I don't want to have egg on my face.
similar: I don't want to look foolish.
I don't want to be humiliated.
I'm trying to avoid a public fail.
example:
A: Are you sure about these statistics for the meeting?
B: Definitely. I don't want to have egg on my face in front of the board.
A: Good thinking. They can be pretty brutal with their questions.
B: For real. I've double-checked everything three times already.
A: Better safe than sorry when it comes to the executives.
B: Facts. I'm ready for whatever they throw at me.
japanese: 恥（はじ）をかきたくないんだ。／顔（かお）に泥（どろ）を塗（ぬ）りたくない。
chinese: 我不想丢脸 (Wǒ bùxiǎng diūliǎn) / 我不想出洋相 (Wǒ bùxiǎng chūyángxiàng)
spanish: No quiero quedar en ridículo. / No quiero pasar vergüenza.

similar: I have a big decision to make.
I'm faced with a difficult choice.
My life is about to change direction.
I'm uncertain about which path to take.
example:
A: I'm not sure if I should stay at this job or go back to grad school.
B: It sounds like you're at a crossroads. What does your gut tell you?
A: Honestly, it change every day. One minute I'm ready to quit, the next I'm fine.
B: Maybe take a week off and clear your head?
A: That's a good idea. I need to figure out what I really want long-term.
B: Facts. Don't rush into anything you'll regret later.
japanese: 岐路（きろ）に立（た）たされている。／決断（けつだん）の時（とき）だ。
chinese: 我面临抉择 (Wǒ miànlín juézé) / 我在十字路口 (Wǒ zài shízìlùkǒu)
spanish: Estoy en una encrucijada. / No sé qué camino tomar.

example:
A: You always seem so honest about everything in your life.
B: Yeah, I'm an open book. I don't see the point in hiding things.
A: I wish I could be more like that. I'm always worried about what people think.
B: Life is much easier when you're just yourself. No cap.
A: I guess it takes a lot of confidence to be that vulnerable.
B: Facts. But it's totally worth it for the real connections you make.
japanese: 隠（かく）し事（ごと）はないよ。／何（なん）でもオープンだよ。
chinese: 我这人没秘密 (Wǒ zhè rén méi mìmì) / 我很坦率 (Wǒ hěn tǎnshuài)
spanish: Soy un libro abierto. / No tengo secretos.

primary: There was a little bit of a kerfuffle.
similar: There was a bit of a fuss.
Things got a little messy for a second.
example:
A: What was all that noise in the lobby earlier?
B: Oh, there was a little bit of a kerfuffle over a missing delivery.
A: Did they figure it out? Everyone sounded pretty heated.
B: Yeah, turns out it was just at the wrong door. All good now.
A: People really lose their cool over the smallest things sometimes.
B: Facts. Delivery day brings out the crazy in everyone.
japanese: ちょっとした騒動（そうどう）があったんだ。／揉（も）め事（ごと）があった。
chinese: 出了点小乱子 (Chūle diǎn xiǎo luànzi) / 有点小骚动 (Yǒudiǎn xiǎo sāodòng)
spanish: Hubo un pequeño alboroto. / Hubo un lío.

primary: The boys didn't cut the mustard.
similar: They failed to meet the standard.
They were inadequate for the task.
They fell short of the goal.
example:
A: How did the new interns do on their first assignment?
B: Honestly? The boys didn't cut the mustard. I've had to redo most of it.
A: That's disappointing. I thought they were supposed to be top-tier.
B: They have the degrees, but no real-world experience. It shows.
A: Maybe they just need a bit more time to adjust?
B: Possibly, but right now, it's more work for me. Facts.
japanese: 期待（きたい）外（はず）れだったな。／使（つか）い物（もの）にならなかった。
chinese: 那些小伙子不行 (Nàxiē xiǎohuǒzi bùxíng) / 没达到要求 (Méi dádào yāoqiú)
spanish: Los chicos no dieron la talla. / No estuvieron a la altura.

primary: How thoughtful of you to say that.
similar: Thank you for being so kind.
That's very nice of you to mention.
That means a lot coming from you.
example:
A: I really think your new project is going to change the industry.
B: Wow, how thoughtful of you to say that. I've been working so hard on it.
A: It really shows. Your dedication is inspiring, for real.
B: I appreciate the support. It's been a long journey.
A: You deserve all the success that's coming your way.
B: Facts. Thank you so much for the encouragement.
japanese: そう言（い）ってくれてありがとう。／気（き）が利（き）くね。
chinese: 你真体贴 (Nǐ zhēn tǐtiē) / 谢谢你这么说 (Xièxie nǐ zhème shuō)
spanish: Qué lindo detalle de tu parte. / Gracias por decir eso.

primary: There is a fat chance of you winning.
similar: You have very little chance of winning.
Zero chance of you taking the W.
example:
A: I'm thinking about entering the city marathon next month.
B: Honestly? There is a fat chance of you winning against those pros.
A: Hey! I've been training for three months already!
B: I know, but these guys train for years. Just being realistic.
A: I'm still gonna do it for the experience though.
B: Facts. That's a better mindset anyway. Just finish the race!
japanese: 勝（か）ち目（め）はないよ。／可能性（かのうせい）はゼロに等（ひと）しいね。
chinese: 你没什么希望赢 (Nǐ méi shénme xīwàng yíng) / 你赢的机会渺茫 (Nǐ yíng de jīhuì miǎománg)
spanish: No tienes ninguna oportunidad. / Es imposible que ganes.

similar: He got the hint at last.
He's finally on the same page.
He finally realized what was going on.
example:
A: After three warnings, he finally stopped showing up late.
B: Good. It took him long enough, but he finally got the message.
A: I was about to let him go, honestly.
B: I think the threat of losing the job really motivated him.
A: Facts. Some people just need a wake-up call to change.
B: Glad things are finally running smoothly in the office.
japanese: やっとわかってくれたか。／遅（おそ）いよ気づくのが。
chinese: 他终于明白了 (Tā zhōngyú míngbai le) / 他终于想通了 (Tā zhōngyú xiǎngtōng le)
spanish: Por fin entendió. / Ya le cayó el veinte.

example:
A: He told the boss he finished the entire report over the weekend.
B: No way! I saw him at the beach on Saturday. He's lying through his teeth.
A: I knew it! His version of the story didn't make any sense.
B: For real. He thinks he can just fake his way through everything.
A: I should probably mention what I saw to the manager then.
B: Facts. Don't let him get away with that. It's not fair to the team.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は平気（へいき）で嘘（うそ）をついてる。／見（み）え透（す）いた嘘（うそ）だ。
chinese: 他在睁眼说瞎话 (Tā zài zhēngyǎn shuō xiāhuà) / 满嘴跑火车 (Mǎnzuǐ pǎo huǒchē)
spanish: Miente con todos los dientes. / Es un mentiroso de primera.

primary: For lack of a better word
example:
A: It was just... weird.
B: Weird how?
A: For lack of a better word, 'cringe'.
B: Ah, got it.
A: Just uncomfortable vibes.
B: Say no more.
japanese: 適切（てきせつ）な言葉（ことば）が見（み）つからないけど／なんて言（い）えばいいか...
chinese: 找不到更好的词 (Zhǎobúdào gèng hǎo de cí) / 姑且这么说吧 (Gūqiě zhème shuō ba)
spanish: A falta de una palabra mejor. / Por no decir otra cosa.

example:
A: We've been sitting here for two hours talking about the plan.
B: You're right. It's time to get moving and actually execute.
A: Ready when you are. Let's head to the site.
B: Grab your gear and let's go. We have a lot of work ahead.
A: No more talking, just doing from now on.
B: Facts. Let's show them what we're capable of.
japanese: そろそろ行（い）こうか。／動（うご）き出（だ）そう。
chinese: 该行动了 (Gāi xíngdòng le) / 该走了 (Gāi zǒu le)
spanish: Es hora de moverse. / Vámonos.

similar: Exactly, that's what I want to hear!
example:
A: I'm not gonna let that setback stop me. I'm gonna try again tomorrow!
B: That's the spirit! I knew you wouldn't give up that easily.
A: For real. One failure doesn't define the whole project.
B: Facts. Consistency is the key to winning anyway.
A: I'm feeling more motivated than ever now.
B: Let's get it! I'm right behind you.
japanese: その意気（いき）だよ！／いい心掛（こころが）けだ！
chinese: 这就对了！ (Zhè jiù duì le!) / 这种精神就对了！ (Zhèzhǒng jīngshén jiù duì le!)
spanish: ¡Esa es la actitud! / ¡Así se habla!

similar: I'm on the road to recovery.
example:
A: How are you feeling after that flu you had last week?
B: Much better, thanks. I'm on the mend and should be back in the office by Monday.
A: That's great news! We've really missed having you around.
B: I missed being there too. Staying in bed all day is so boring.
A: Rest up for a few more days just to be safe though.
B: Facts. I don't want to overdo it and get sick again.
japanese: 良（よ）くなってきているよ。／回復（かいふく）に向（む）かってる。
chinese: 我在康复中 (Wǒ zài kāngfù zhōng) / 我快好了 (Wǒ kuài hǎo le)
spanish: Me estoy recuperando. / Ya voy mejor.

similar: I'm on board with your idea.
example:
A: Think about it: we'd have a pool, a private chef, and zero noise.
B: Honestly? You sold me with the 'private chef' part. Let's book the villa.
A: I knew that would be the game changer for you!
B: For real. I'm tired of cooking every single day while on vacation.
A: It's gonna be the most relaxing trip ever, I promise.
B: Facts. I'm already counting down the days.
japanese: その気（き）になったよ。／君（きみ）に説得（せっとく）されたよ。
chinese: 你说服我了 (Nǐ shuōfú wǒ le) / 我买账了 (Wǒ mǎizhàng le)
spanish: Me convenciste. / Trato hecho.

primary: I can't wrap my head around that.
similar: I don't understand it at all.
I'm struggling to grasp the concept.
It makes no sense to me.
example:
A: They're saying the universe is constantly expanding into... what, exactly?
B: Honestly, I can't wrap my head around that either. It's too abstract.
A: My brain literally starts hurting when I think about it for too long.
B: Same. Physics is just on a whole different level, no cap.
A: Maybe we should just stick to talking about movies instead.
B: Facts. That's much easier for my human brain to handle.
japanese: 全（まった）く理解（りかい）できない。／想像（そうぞう）もつかない。
chinese: 我搞不懂 (Wǒ gǎobùdǒng) / 我无法理解 (Wǒ wúfǎ lǐjiě)
spanish: No me cabe en la cabeza. / No lo entiendo.

similar: That's lovely of you to do.
example:
A: I brought you some homemade soup since I heard you were feeling under the weather.
B: Aw, that's so sweet of you! I really needed this right now.
A: It's my grandma's recipe, so it's guaranteed to make you feel better.
B: You're a lifesaver, for real. I'm gonna eat it right away.
A: Let me know if you need anything else from the store later.
B: Facts. You're the best friend a person could ask for.
japanese: 優（やさ）しいね。／気遣（きづか）いが嬉（うれ）しいよ。
chinese: 你真好 (Nǐ zhēn hǎo) / 你太甜了 (Nǐ tài tián le)
spanish: Qué tierno de tu parte. / Eres un amor.

similar: Leave it to me, I'll solve it.
example:
A: We lost the keys to the storage unit and we need that gear by tomorrow morning!
B: Chill. I'll figure it out. I think I know where they might be hidden.
A: I've looked everywhere! I'm starting to panic, honestly.
B: Just take a deep breath. I've got this under control.
A: I hope so. We really can't afford any more delays.
B: Facts. I'll hit you up as soon as I find them.
japanese: 何（なん）とかするよ。／自分（じぶん）で考（かんが）えるよ。
chinese: 我会搞定的 (Wǒ huì gǎodìng de) / 我会想办法的 (Wǒ huì xiǎng bànfǎ de)
spanish: Ya veré qué hago. / Yo lo resuelvo.

primary: Mobile technology is taking center stage.
similar: Everything is revolving around smartphones now.
Mobile technology is the main focus.
example:
A: Why are we prioritizing the mobile app over the web version this year?
B: Look at the data. Mobile technology is taking center stage for our users.
A: True, over eighty percent of our traffic comes from phones now.
B: Exactly. We need to go where our audience is already spending their time.
A: It's a big shift, but it definitely makes sense for the brand.
B: Facts. It's all about staying relevant in this market.
japanese: モバイル技術（ぎじゅつ）が主役（しゅやく）になってるね。／中心（ちゅうしん）になってきてる。
chinese: 移动技术成主流了 (Yídòng jìshù chéng zhǔliú le) / 手机是老大了 (Shǒujī shì lǎodà le)
spanish: La tecnología móvil es lo principal. / Los celulares son lo de hoy.

primary: He will lay bare the ugly truth.
similar: He will reveal the harsh reality.
He's going to tell the unfiltered truth.
example:
A: I heard the CEO is giving a state-of-the-company speech tomorrow.
B: Yeah, and everyone's nervous because he said he will lay bare the ugly truth about our finances.
A: No more corporate fluff then? That's actually kind of refreshing.
B: In a way, yeah, but it might mean some serious layoffs are coming.
A: That's the scary part. We've known things were bad for a while though.
B: Facts. It's better to know the truth than to live in denial.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は不都合（ふつごう）な真実（しんじつ）を暴（あば）くだろう。／全部（ぜんぶ）ぶちまけるだろう。
chinese: 他会揭露丑陋的真相 (Tā huì jiēlù chǒulòu de zhēnxiàng) / 他会把老底都揭出来 (Tā huì bǎ lǎodǐ dōu jiē chūlái)
spanish: Él dirá la cruda verdad. / Él destapará la olla.

primary: I will leave no stone unturned.
similar: I'll be thorough in my search.
I won't stop until I find it.
I'm going to look into every detail.
example:
A: We still haven't found the source of the leak in the database.
B: Don't worry. I will leave no stone unturned until we identify the problem.
A: We've checked the logs, the server, everything... it's like a ghost.
B: I'm going to do a deep dive into the actual code structure tonight.
A: I appreciate the dedication. This is a critical issue for us.
B: Facts. I won't sleep until this is resolved.
japanese: 徹底的（てっていてき）にやるよ。／草（くさ）の根（ね）分（わ）けても捜（さが）すよ。
chinese: 我会不遗余力 (Wǒ huì bùyíyúlì) / 我会想尽一切办法 (Wǒ huì xiǎngjìn yíqiè bànfǎ)
spanish: No dejaré piedra sin mover. / Haré hasta lo imposible.

similar: I'm going to hit the gym.
Heading to the fitness center now.
example:
A: Hey, you wanna grab some pizza after work?
B: I wish! But I'm off to the gym. I've been slacking lately.
A: Respect. I should probably go too, but I'm just too lazy today.
B: Come with me! You'll feel so much better after a good session.
A: Maybe tomorrow. For now, it's just me and my sofa.
B: Facts. Enjoy your rest then, I'll see you later!
japanese: ジムに行（い）ってくる。／筋（きん）トレしてくる。
chinese: 我去健身了 (Wǒ qù jiànshēn le) / 我去锻炼了 (Wǒ qù duànliàn le)
spanish: Me voy al gimnasio. / Ya me voy a entrenar.

example:
A: Why are you being so quiet today? Is everything okay?
B: Look, here's the thing: I'm just really stressed about this move next week.
A: Oh! I thought I did something to annoy you!
B: No, not at all. It's just a lot to handle all by myself.
A: I'm so sorry! I should have realized you needed some help.
B: Facts. If you have any free time this weekend, let me know.
japanese: 実（じつ）はこういうことなんだ。／要点（ようてん）はね...
chinese: 事情是这样的 (Shìqing shì zhèyàng de) / 问题在于 (Wèntí zàiyú)
spanish: La cosa es esta. / El punto es este.

primary: The day can't come soon enough.
similar: I'm so looking forward to it.
I can't wait for that day.
I wish it were that day already.
example:
A: Only three more days until we leave for Europe!
B: For real. The day can't come soon enough. I'm so ready to disconnect.
A: Have you finished all your packing yet?
B: Almost. I just need to grab a few travel-size toiletries today.
A: I'm so jealous! Take lots of pictures for me.
B: Facts. I'll be posting them all over my feed, don't worry.
japanese: 待（ま）ち遠（どお）しいよ。／早（はや）く来（こ）ないかな。
chinese: 那一天快点来吧 (Nà yìtiān kuàidiǎn lái ba) / 等不及那一天了 (Děngbují nà yìtiān le)
spanish: Ya quiero que llegue ese día. / No puedo esperar.

similar: He has a lot of power.
He's a big deal in the industry.
People listen to what he says.
example:
A: How did he manage to get a meeting with the investors so quickly?
B: Honestly? He has serious clout in the tech world. One phone call and he's in.
A: I wish I had that kind of influence. It would make things so much easier.
B: It takes years to build that kind of reputation, for real.
A: Facts. I guess I'll just have to keep grinding until I get there.
B: That's the only way to do it. Keep pushing.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は顔（かお）が利（き）く。／影響力（えいきょうりょく）がある。
chinese: 他很有影响力 (Tā hěn yǒu yǐngxiǎnglì) / 他是大佬 (Tā shì dàlǎo)
spanish: Él tiene influencia. / Él es pesado.

similar: He went missing without a trace.
example:
A: Where did that guy go who was talking to us earlier?
B: Man, I have no idea. He literally vanished into thin air as soon as I turned my back.
A: That's so creepy! He didn't even say goodbye or anything.
B: For real. It's like he just phased out of reality. This place is weird.
A: Maybe he was just an NPC in our simulation?
B: Facts. Let's get out of here before something else happens.
japanese: 煙（けむり）のように消（き）えた。／跡形（あとかた）もなく消（き）えた。
chinese: 他凭空消失了 (Tā píngkōng xiāoshī le) / 人间蒸发了 (Rénjiān zhēngfā le)
spanish: Se esfumó. / Desapareció del mapa.

similar: I'm still waiting for an answer on the original point.
example:
A: So, about the money you owe me from last month...
B: Oh! Did you see that the new season of that show just dropped?
A: Yo, don't change the subject. We were talking about the fifty bucks.
B: Alright, alright. I'll Venmo you right now, chill out.
A: Thank you. I've been asking you for weeks, man.
B: Facts. My bad. It slipped my mind, I promise.
japanese: 話（はなし）をそらさないで。／話題（わだい）を変（か）えないで。
chinese: 别转移话题 (Bié zhuǎnyí huàtí) / 别打岔 (Bié dǎchà)
spanish: No cambies el tema. / No te desvíes.

primary: I'm a glass half full person.
similar: I try to look on the bright side.
I focus on the good things.
example:
A: Everything is going wrong today! This project is a absolute disaster.
B: Look, I'm a glass half full person. At least we found the problem early.
A: How can you be so positive right now? We're literally three days behind schedule!
B: Panicking won't help. Let's just focus on what we can fix today.
A: I guess you're right. Your attitude is actually kind of helpful, for real.
B: Facts. Let's just take it one step at a time and we'll get through it.
japanese: 楽観的（らっかんてき）なんだ。／物事（ものごと）を良（よ）い方（ほう）に捉（とら）えるタイプなんだ。
chinese: 我比较乐观 (Wǒ bǐjiào lèguān) / 我凡事往好处想 (Wǒ fánshì wǎng hǎochù xiǎng)
spanish: Soy optimista. / Veo el vaso medio lleno.

similar: Money isn't easy to come by.
You have to work hard for your cash.
We need to be careful with our spending.
Wealth doesn't just appear out of nowhere.
example:
A: Can I get those new three-hundred-dollar sneakers for my birthday?
B: Listen, money doesn't grow on trees. You need to show me you're taking your chores seriously first.
A: But all my friends already have them! I feel so left out.
B: I understand, but that doesn't mean we can just blow our budget on shoes.
A: Fine, I'll start helping out around the house more then.
B: Facts. Show me some effort and we'll talk about it next month.
japanese: 金（かね）のなる木（き）なんてないんだよ
chinese: 钱不是大风刮来的 (Qián búshì dàfēng guā lái de) / 赚钱不容易 (Zhuànqián bù róngyì)
spanish: El dinero no crece en los árboles. / El dinero cuesta ganarlo.

primary: Let's get into the swing of things.
similar: Let's get accustomed to the routine.
Time to get into the flow of work.
Let's familiarize ourselves with the situation.
Time to start working at our usual pace.
example:
A: It's my first day back after a two-week vacation and my brain is totally fried.
B: No worries. Let's just get into the swing of things slowly. No stress.
A: I have three hundred unread emails! Where do I even start?
B: Just pick one, handle it, and move to the next. You'll be back in the flow in no time.
A: I hope so. I feel like I've forgotten how to do my basic job tasks.
B: Facts. It happens to the best of us after a long break.
japanese: ペースを掴（つか）んでいこう
chinese: 让我们进入状态 (Ràng wǒmen jìnrù zhuàngtài) / 找找感觉 (Zhǎozhao gǎnjué)
spanish: Vamos a agarrarle el ritmo. / Vamos a meternos en ambiente.

similar: I'm in the process of doing it.
I haven't forgotten, I'm making progress.
example:
A: Have you finished the design for the new landing page yet?
B: I'm working on it right now. It should be ready by the end of the day.
A: Awesome. The client is really eager to see the initial concepts.
B: For real. I'm just trying to make sure the color palette is perfect.
A: Take your time, then. Quality over speed every single time.
B: Facts. I'll send you a preview link in a couple of hours.
japanese: 今（いま）やってるところ
chinese: 我在弄了 (Wǒ zài nòng le) / 正在处理 (Zhèngzài chǔlǐ)
spanish: Estoy en eso. / Lo estoy trabajando.

similar: She told us something that blew our minds.
She gave us a huge surprise.
example:
A: Did you hear about Sarah at the meeting earlier?
B: Yeah! She dropped a bombshell that she's moving to Japan next month!
A: No way! I had no idea she was even thinking about leaving the country.
B: For real. Everyone was just sitting there in total shock. It was wild.
A: I wonder what prompted such a big change so suddenly?
B: Facts. I'm definitely going to reach out and ask her about it tonight.
japanese: 彼女（かのじょ）、爆弾（ばくだん）発言（はつげん）したよ
chinese: 她放了个重磅炸弹 (Tā fàng le gè zhòngbàng zhàdàn) / 她说了个惊人消息 (Tā shuō le gè jīngrén xiāoxi)
spanish: Soltó una bomba. / Dio una noticia impactante.

similar: I was in a difficult dilemma.
I was faced with two equally tough choices.
I didn't know which way to turn.
I was stuck in a complex situation.
I was in a real pickle.
example:
A: Why did you take so long to decide between the two job offers?
B: Honestly? I was in a real quandary. Both had amazing benefits and great teams.
A: That's a good problem to have, but I bet it was still stressful.
B: 100%. I literally made a pro and con list that was three pages long.
A: So what finally made you choose the startup over the big bank?
B: Facts. The potential for growth and the creative freedom just felt more 'me'.
japanese: どうしようか困（こま）ってたんだ
chinese: 我左右为难 (Wǒ zuǒyòu wéinán) / 我很难办 (Wǒ hěn nánbàn)
spanish: Estaba en un dilema. / No sabía qué hacer.

example:
A: I can't believe we missed the train.
B: Well, it is what it is.
A: Now we have to wait an hour.
B: Let's just get a drink.
A: You're so calm.
B: Panicking won't make the train come back.
japanese: しょうがないよ
chinese: 也就只能这样了 (Yě jiù zhǐnéng zhèyàng le) / 没办法的事 (Méibànfǎ de shì)
spanish: Es lo que hay. / Así son las cosas.

similar: I stayed up all night to work.
I didn't sleep at all last night.
I was awake through the entire night.
I worked until the sun came up.
I had zero sleep because of this project.
example:
A: You look absolutely exhausted today. What happened?
B: Ugh, I pulled an all-nighter trying to finish that final report before the deadline.
A: Wow! You really should have started on it earlier, man.
B: I know, I know. I'm a terrible procrastinator. It finally caught up with me.
A: Well, at least it's done now. Go home and crash for twelve hours.
B: Facts. I'm gonna fall asleep as soon as my head hits the pillow.
japanese: 徹夜（てつや）しちゃった
chinese: 我熬了个通宵 (Wǒ áo le gè tōngxiāo) / 我一夜没睡 (Wǒ yíyè méishuì)
spanish: Me pasé la noche en vela. / No dormí en toda la noche.

primary: He has a heart of gold.
similar: He would do anything for anyone.
He's the sweetest person I know.
example:
A: I heard Jim spent his entire Saturday helping that new family move in.
B: That doesn't surprise me. He really has a heart of gold.
A: For real. He never asks for anything in return either. He's just naturally helpful.
B: Exactly. We need more people like him in this world, honestly.
A: Facts. He's a real gem of a human being.
B: I'm glad he's part of our team, for sure.
japanese: 彼（かれ）はすごくいい人（ひと）だよ
chinese: 他心肠特别好 (Tā xīncháng tèbié hǎo) / 他人太好了 (Tā rén tài hǎo le)
spanish: Tiene un corazón de oro. / Es un pan de Dios.

example:
A: How was the date?
B: Right off the bat, he insulted my job.
A: Ouch. Dealbreaker?
B: Totally. I left in ten minutes.
A: Good for you.
B: Who does that?
japanese: 初（はじ）めからいきなり
chinese: 一开始就... (Yìkāishǐ jiù...) / 立马... (Lìmǎ...)
spanish: De entrada. / Desde el principio.

example:
A: Do you trust him?
B: I've trusted him from day one.
A: He seems loyal.
B: He's never let me down.
A: That's rare these days.
B: Keep your friends close.
japanese: 最初（さいしょ）からずっと
chinese: 从第一天起 (Cóng dì-yī tiān qǐ) / 一开始 (Yìkāishǐ)
spanish: Desde el primer día. / Desde el comienzo.

primary: This is a walk in the park.
similar: I can do this with my eyes closed.
example:
A: Wow, that coding challenge looks really intense. Are you gonna be okay?
B: Honestly? This is a walk in the park for me. I've done way harder stuff than this.
A: Respect. I would have no idea where to even start with that logic.
B: Once you learn the fundamentals, it's just like solving a puzzle.
A: I'll have to take your word for it. Good luck anyway!
B: Facts. I'll have this finished in ten minutes, just watch.
japanese: こんなの朝飯前（あさめしまえ）だよ
chinese: 这很简单 (Zhè hěn jiǎndān) / 这就是小菜一碟 (Zhè jiùshì xiǎocài yì dié)
spanish: Esto es pan comido. / Es súper fácil.

similar: I don't necessarily agree with that.
Don't include me in your statement.
example:
A: Everyone is so bored during these weekly meetings, right?
B: Hey! Speak for yourself. I actually find the updates quite helpful.
A: Seriously? It's just two hours of people talking about things that don't matter.
B: Well, some of us actually like knowing what's going on in the rest of the firm.
A: I guess I'm just more task-oriented than you are then.
B: Facts. Different strokes for different folks, I guess.
japanese: 一緒（いっしょ）にしないで
chinese: 那是你觉得 (Nà shì nǐ juéde) / 代表你自己就好 (Dàibiǎo nǐ zìjǐ jiù hǎo)
spanish: Habla por ti. / Eso lo dirás tú.

similar: Focus and do a better job.
example:
A: I forgot my laptop at home again and I have a presentation in ten minutes!
B: Seriously? You really need to get your act together. This is the third time this month.
A: I know, I know. My morning routine is just so chaotic lately.
B: Maybe try setting a checklist by the door or something. You're gonna get fired.
A: You're right. I'm gonna make some serious changes starting tonight.
B: Facts. Consistency and reliability are everything in this industry.
japanese: しっかりしてよ
chinese: 振作起来 (Zhènzuò qǐlái) / 别掉链子 (Bié diàoliànzi)
spanish: Ponte las pilas. / Organízate.

example:
A: Aren't you worried about the major changes they announced for next year?
B: Honestly? I'm not phased. I've been through plenty of corporate restructures before.
A: I wish I had your confidence. I'm already looking for other job opportunities.
B: Chill out. Change is part of life. Just adapt and keep moving forward.
A: I guess you're right. Experience really does make a difference, huh?
B: Facts. Once you've seen it all, nothing really surprises you anymore.
japanese: 全然（ぜんぜん）平気（へいき）だよ
chinese: 我无所谓 (Wǒ wúsuǒwèi) / 我没受影响 (Wǒ méi shòu yǐngxiǎng)
spanish: No me afecta. / Me da igual.

example:
A: I'll start working on the project after I finish this game.
B: Seriously? Don't drag your feet, the deadline is in two hours!
A: I know, I know. I just needed a quick break to clear my head.
B: You've been on that 'break' for forty-five minutes, man.
A: alright, alright. I'm closing the game now. I'm on it.
B: Facts. We really need to get this done.
japanese: グズグズしないで
chinese: 别磨蹭 (Bié móceng) / 别拖拖拉拉 (Bié tuōtuōlālā)
spanish: No te tardes tanto. / No le des tantas vueltas.

example:
A: Hey! I'm trying to study and you're making way too much noise!
B: I was just practicing my drums for a second...
A: Knock it off! You've been 'practicing' for an hour. My head is pounding.
B: My bad, I didn't realize it was that loud. I'll stop now.
A: Thank you. I really need to focus on this final exam.
B: Say less. I'll go play something on my phone instead.
japanese: いい加減（かげん）にして！
chinese: 别闹了！ (Bié nào le!) / 够了！ (Gòu le!)
spanish: ¡Ya párale! / ¡Basta ya!

similar: What's the occasion for your visit?
What brings you to this place?
How did you end up here today?
I didn't expect to see you here!
example:
A: Oh! Hey Mark! What brought you here to the library on a Saturday?
B: Honestly? I just needed some quiet time to work on my portfolio.
A: I thought you always worked at that coffee shop downtown.
B: It was too crowded today, no cap. This place is much more peaceful.
A: I feel you. It's a hidden gem for productivity, for real.
B: Facts. I'm actually getting quite a lot done today.
japanese: 何（なに）しに来（き）たの？
chinese: 什么风把你吹来了？ (Shénme fēng bǎ nǐ chuī lái le?) / 你怎么来了？ (Nǐ zěnme lái le?)
spanish: ¿Qué te trae por aquí? / ¿Qué haces aquí?

primary: The ball is in your court.
similar: I've done my part, now you decide.
example:
A: I've sent you all the details and my final offer for the partnership.
B: Thanks, I'll review it with my team this afternoon and let you know.
A: Perfect. The ball is in your court now. I hope we can make this work.
B: We're definitely interested, we just need to double-check the numbers.
A: Take your time. I'm confident it's a great deal for both of us.
B: Facts. I'll hit you up by tomorrow morning for sure.
japanese: あとは君（きみ）次第（しだい）だよ
chinese: 看你的了 (Kàn nǐ de le) / 决定权在你 (Juédìngquán zài nǐ)
spanish: La decisión es tuya. / Ahora te toca a ti.

similar: I'll believe it when I see it.
example:
A: I heard he's finally going to start showing up to meetings on time.
B: Haha! That will be the day. He's been late every single time for three years.
A: Maybe he's actually trying to change his habits now?
B: I doubt it. He literally laughed when the boss mentioned punctuality.
A: I guess some people just never learn, no cap.
B: Facts. I'll keep my expectations exactly where they are—at zero.
japanese: そんなことあるわけない
chinese: 太阳从西边出来了 (Tàiyáng cóng xībiān chūlái le) / 那才怪呢 (Nà cái guài ne)
spanish: Eso nunca pasará. / ¡Ni lo sueñes!

similar: They're putting up a fierce fight.
They're struggling with everything they have.
They're determined to win at all costs.
They're giving it their absolute all in the conflict.
example:
A: Both companies are trying to win that government contract.
B: Yeah, they're fighting tooth and nail for it. It's gettin' pretty intense.
A: I heard they're even hiring specialized lobbyists now.
B: For real. Millions of dollars are on the line, so it makes sense.
A: It's definitely gonna be a long and messy battle.
B: Facts. Only one of them is coming out on top.
japanese: 彼（かれ）ら必死（ひっし）に戦（たたか）ってるよ
chinese: 他们争得很凶 (Tāmen zhēng de hěn xiōng) / 拼得你死我活 (Pīn de nǐ sǐ wǒ huó)
spanish: Están luchando con uñas y dientes. / Están peleando a muerte.

similar: I did exceptionally well on the test.
I crushed the exam beyond expectations.
example:
A: How did your driving test go? Were you nervous?
B: I was! But honestly? I passed with flying colors. Not a single mistake.
A: No way! That's incredible! Most people fail on their first try.
B: I know! I was so focused, I didn't even notice the instructor was there.
A: You should celebrate tonight. Let's grab some dinner.
B: Facts. I'm treated myself to a big steak as soon as I get home.
japanese: 好成績（こうせいせき）で合格（ごうかく）したよ
chinese: 我高分通过了 (Wǒ gāofēn tōngguò le) / 我成绩很棒 (Wǒ chéngjì hěn bàng)
spanish: Pasé con honores. / Me fue excelente.

primary: I don't want to make a scene.
similar: I want to avoid public drama.
I don't want to embarrass anyone.
Let's not draw attention to ourselves.
Keep the peace by not reacting loudly.
example:
A: Can you believe he just said that to her in front of everyone?
B: I know! She was so calm though. She clearly didn't want to make a scene.
A: If it were me, I would have yelled right back, no cap.
B: That would have just made things worse for everyone. She's classier than that.
A: You're right. Sometimes staying quiet is the most powerful move.
B: Facts. She handle that situation with so much grace.
japanese: 騒（さわ）ぎにしたくないんだ
chinese: 我不想把事情闹大 (Wǒ bùxiǎng bǎ shìqing nàodà) / 我不想当众出丑 (Wǒ bùxiǎng dāngzhòng chūchǒu)
spanish: No quiero hacer un escándalo. / No quiero armar un show.

similar: I laughed so hard at that.
That was so funny I couldn't stop.
You literal made my day with that joke.
example:
A: Did you see that video of the dog trying to eat its own Shadow?
B: Oh man, that cracked me up for like ten minutes straight!
A: The way it just kept spinning in circles was pure comedy gold.
B: For real. Dogs are honestly the best thing on the internet.
A: I shared it with my whole family. Everyone loved it.
B: Facts. We all need a good laugh like that sometimes.
japanese: 超（ちょう）ウケたよ
chinese: 笑死我了 (Xiào sǐ wǒ le) / 我笑喷了 (Wǒ xiào pēn le)
spanish: Me mató de risa. / Me hizo reír muchísimo.

similar: I'd like to point out that.
example:
A: You're always so lazy when it comes to chores around here.
B: Actually, I'll have you know that I already did all the laundry this morning.
A: Wait, really? The whole basket? Even my heavy jeans?
B: Yes, everything is already folded and in your room. Check it yourself.
A: Wow... I'm sorry, I shouldn't have assumed you were slacking.
B: Facts. Don't underestimate my productivity when I'm motivated.
japanese: 言（い）っとくけど
chinese: 我告诉你 (Wǒ gàosu nǐ) / 你要搞清楚 (Nǐ yào gǎo qīngchu)
spanish: Para que lo sepas. / Que te quede claro.

example:
A: Should I bring an umbrella?
B: It looks sunny.
A: But the forecast said rain.
B: Better safe than sorry.
A: True, I'll take it.
B: You'll thank me if it pours.
japanese: 念（ねん）のためね
chinese: 小心驶得万年船 (Xiǎoxīn shǐ de wànniánchuán) / 保险起见 (Bǎoxiǎn qǐjiàn)
spanish: Mejor prevenir que lamentar. / Más vale prevenir.

example:
A: This summer heat in the city is getting absolutely unbearable.
B: You're telling me! I've had my AC on full blast for three days straight.
A: My electricity bill is gonna be insane next month, but it's worth it.
B: For real. I can't even step outside without melting in five minutes.
A: I'm just staying inside until September at this point.
B: Facts. Let's just pray for some literal rain soon.
japanese: 全（まった）くその通（とお）り！
chinese: 谁说不是呢！ (Shéi shuō búshì ne!) / 这还用你说！ (Zhè hái yòng nǐ shuō!)
spanish: ¡Dímelo a mí! / ¡Ni me digas!

similar: She gave him a piece of her mind.
She lectured him for a long time.
She was really angry and let him know.
He got a serious talking-to from her.
example:
A: Why was Mike looking so depressed at the party last night?
B: Man, his wife chewed him out for forgetting their anniversary. It was brutal.
A: Ouch. That's a huge mistake to make, no cap.
B: For real. He felt so bad he didn't even want to eat his favorite cake.
A: I hope he made it up to her with something really special today.
B: Facts. He was already looking at jewelry websites this morning.
japanese: 奥（おく）さんにこっぴどく怒（おこ）られたんだ
chinese: 他老婆把他骂了一顿 (Tā lǎopo bǎ tā mà le yí dùn) / 他挨老婆骂了 (Tā ái lǎopo mà le)
spanish: Su esposa le puso una regañada. / Su mujer lo regañó feo.

similar: Broadcast this news to your network.
Promote this to your friends and family.
example:
A: Our new community garden is finally open to the public this weekend!
B: That's amazing! I'll definitely be there to support it.
A: Please spread the word on your social media. We need more volunteers.
B: Say less. I'll post it on my Instagram story right now.
A: Thank you! We really want this to be a success for the whole neighborhood.
B: Facts. People need more green spaces in this city anyway.
japanese: みんなに広（ひろ）めてね
chinese: 帮忙传一下 (Bāngmáng chuán yíxià) / 广而告之 (Guǎng ér gào zhī)
spanish: Por favor corre la voz. / Pásale el dato a todos.

primary: I hate to break it to you, but.
similar: I'm sorry to have to tell you this.
I regret being the bearer of bad news, but.
I've got some difficult information for you.
Don't take this the wrong way, but.
example:
A: I'm so excited to use my new discount code for that luxury store!
B: Look, I hate to break it to you, but that code expired at midnight.
A: Wait, really? But it said it was valid until the end of the month!
B: I think it was 'while supplies last' or something. It's not working for me either.
A: Oh my god, I was literally about to buy that purse. I'm so sad.
B: Facts. Better to know now than at the checkout screen though.
japanese: 言（い）いにくいんだけど
chinese: 我不想打击你，但是... (Wǒ bùxiǎng dǎjī nǐ, dànshì...) / 虽然不好听，但... (Suīrán bù hǎotīng, dàn...)
spanish: Odio decirte esto, pero... / Siento ser yo quien te lo diga, pero...

similar: It makes no difference to me.
As far as I'm concerned, it doesn't matter.
Whatever happens, I don't give a damn.
example:
A: He's actually thinking about quitting the team and joining the rival club.
B: For all I care, he can go. He hasn't been a good teammate lately anyway.
A: Wow, you really don't seem bothered by it at all.
B: Honestly? The team vibe will probably improve without his negative energy.
A: I guess it's better to have people who actually want to be here.
B: Facts. We're better off focusing on our own performance.
japanese: 私（わたし）の知（し）ったことじゃない
chinese: 我才不在乎呢 (Wǒ cái búzàihu ne) / 关我屁事 (Guān wǒ pì shì)
spanish: Por mí, lo que sea. / Me da exactamente lo mismo.

similar: Focus on something else, it's fine.
example:
A: I'm so sorry I'm ten minutes late! The subway was absolutely packed.
B: Relax, don't sweat it. The meeting hasn't even started yet.
A: I hate being late, I feel so irresponsible when it happens.
B: Chill. We all know how unpredictable the commute can be in this city.
A: Thanks for being so understanding. I really appreciate it.
B: Facts. Let's just grab some coffee and get ready for the presentation.
japanese: 気（き）にしないで
chinese: 别担心 (Bié dānxīn) / 没事儿 (Méishìr)
spanish: No te preocupes. / Tranki, no pasa nada.

similar: I swear this is exactly what happened.
Every word I'm saying is true.
example:
A: You actually met a celebrity at the grocery store last night?
B: Yes! No word of a lie, he was standing right behind me in the cereal aisle.
A: Did you say anything? Or were you too starstruck?
B: I just said 'Hi' and he gave me a little nod. It was so intense.
A: That's a crazy story to tell! People are gonna think you're capping.
B: Facts. But I have a blurry photo to prove it! Check this out.
japanese: 本当（ほんとう）の話（はなし）だよ
chinese: 绝无半句虚言 (Juéwú bànjù xūyán) / 我没骗你 (Wǒ méi piàn nǐ)
spanish: Te lo juro por mi vida. / Es la pura verdad.

primary: People came out of the woodwork.
similar: A bunch of people showed up suddenly.
Everyone suddenly wanted a piece of the action.
It felt like a swarm appeared out of nowhere.
example:
A: As soon as I announced I had extra tickets to the concert, people came out of the woodwork.
B: I bet! Everyone's been trying to get into that show for months.
A: I had random people from high school messaging me asking for a favor!
B: For real. Success really brings out the 'old friends', doesn't it?
A: It was a bit overwhelming, to be honest. I just ended up giving them to my cousins.
B: Facts. Best way to avoid all that unnecessary drama.
japanese: どこからともなく人（ひと）が湧（わ）いてきた
chinese: 人都冒出来了 (Rén dōu mào chūlái le) / 大家都钻出来了 (Dàjiā dōu zuān chūlái le)
spanish: Salió gente hasta debajo de las piedras. / Apareció gente de la nada.

meaning: 금방 다시 할 수 있는 일이에요.
similar: It's something you never forget how to do.
It'll come back to you quickly.
You'll regain the skill in no time.
It's a natural ability once learned.
example:
A: I haven't coded in Python in over three years. I'm worried I've forgotten it all.
B: Don't worry, it's like riding a bike. Once you start, it'll all come back.
A: I hope so. I have that big technical interview on Monday.
B: Just spend a few hours on some practice problems tonight. You'll be fine.
A: You're right. The fundamentals are still there somewhere in my brain.
B: Facts. Just trust your experience and you'll crush it.
japanese: 体（からだ）が覚（おぼ）えてるよ
chinese: 这就像骑自行车一样 (Zhè jiù xiàng qí zìxíngchē yíyàng) / 学会了就不会忘 (Xuéhuì le jiù búhuì wàng)
spanish: Es como andar en bici, no se olvida. / Lo que bien se aprende no se olvida.

similar: I studied this book very carefully.
I read every single word in detail.
I was deeply absorbed in this reading.
I spent hours analyzing this text.
example:
A: You seem to know everything about ancient history all of a sudden.
B: Well, I poured over this book for the last three weeks. It's fascinating.
A: No way! That looks like a textbook from the 80s. Is it even readable?
B: Surprisingly, yeah. The level of detail is just unmatched by modern stuff.
A: Respect. I can barely finish a five-page article these days.
B: Facts. Deep reading really changes your perspective on things, for real.
japanese: この本（ほん）熟読（じゅくどく）したんだ
chinese: 我钻研了这本书 (Wǒ zuānyán le zhè běn shū) / 我仔细读了这本书 (Wǒ zǐxì dú le zhè běn shū)
spanish: Me devoré este libro. / Leí este libro con lupa.

similar: It should have been done a long time ago.
It's about time we made a move.
No more waiting, it's necessary now.
example:
A: Are we finally starting the office renovation next week?
B: Yes! It's high time we did. The carpets are literally falling apart.
A: I've been complaining about those stains for two years, honestly.
B: For real. It's embarrassing to have clients come in here with the place looking like this.
A: I'm just glad the budget finally got approved for the whole building.
B: Facts. It's gonna look like a whole different place soon.
japanese: もうとっくにやるべき時間（じかん）だよ
chinese: 早该这么做了 (Zǎo gāi zhème zuò le) / 早就该这样了 (Zǎojiù gāi zhèyàng le)
spanish: Ya era hora. / Ya nos tardamos.

primary: I don't want to split hairs.
similar: Let's not get bogged down in tiny details.
Let's focus on the big picture.
I'm not trying to be pedantic here.
example:
A: Technicianly, we were three minutes late, not five.
B: Look, I don't want to split hairs. The meeting already started, let's just go in.
A: I'm just saying, accuracy matters when it comes to time management!
B: I get it, but right now, three or five doesn't make a difference. Move it.
A: Alright, alright. I'm going. Sorry for being such a stickler.
B: Facts. Let's just get the info we need and get out of here.
japanese: 細（こま）かいことにこだわりたくない
chinese: 我不想斤斤计较 (Wǒ bùxiǎng jīnjīnjìjiào) / 我不想抠字眼 (Wǒ bùxiǎng kōu zìyǎn)
spanish: No quiero buscarle la quinta pata al gato. / No nos pongamos detallistas.

similar: That was a significant fail on his part.
He really dropped the ball this time.
example:
A: What happened with the marketing campaign? I heard it was a absolute disaster.
B: Man, the lead designer made a blunder and forgot the link to the actual product.
A: No way! So all that traffic just went to... nowhere?
B: Exactly. Thousands of dollars in ad spend just gone down the drain.
A: Ouch. He's definitely gonna be in trouble for that one.
B: Facts. It's a miracle he still has a job after such a huge error.
japanese: 彼（かれ）、大（おお）ポカやらかした
chinese: 他犯了个大错 (Tā fàn le gè dàcuò) / 他搞砸了 (Tā gǎo zá le)
spanish: Metió la pata. / Cometió un error garrafal.

similar: He has more money than he knows what to do with.
He's super rich and loves to spend.
example:
A: Did you see his new sports car? It must have cost a fortune.
B: Oh, he has money to burn. He's got three more just like it at home.
A: I wish I could just drop that much cash on a whim like it's nothing.
B: For real. Some people really live in a different world than the rest of us.
A: I guess it's nice if you can afford that kind of lifestyle though.
B: Facts. I'd definitely be traveling the world every single weekend.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は湯水（ゆみず）のように金（かね）を使（つか）う
chinese: 他钱多得烧得慌 (Tā qián duō de shāo de huāng) / 他富得流油 (Tā fù de liúyóu)
spanish: Tiene dinero para tirar para arriba. / Le sobra la plata.

similar: I was on the verge of crying.
I felt a lump in my throat.
I struggled to speak due to being overwhelmed with emotion.
example:
A: How was the movie? I heard it was a real tear-jerker.
B: Oh man, I got so choked up during the ending. I wasn't expecting that.
A: I saw it too! When they finally reunited, I was literally sobbing.
B: For real. It's rare for a movie to actually touch your heart like that.
A: I definitely need a fluffy comedy to watch after this to feel better.
B: Facts. That was too heavy for a Friday night, no cap.
japanese: グッときちゃった
chinese: 我哽咽了 (Wǒ gěngyè le) / 我感动得说不出话 (Wǒ gǎndòng de shuōbùchū huà)
spanish: Se me hizo un nudo en la garganta. / Me puse sentimental.

meaning: 가만히 있는 것보단 움직이는 게 낫지.
example:
A: I don't feel like gym today.
B: Just do a light walk.
A: Is that enough?
B: Better moving than not.
A: You're right, I'll go.
B: Consistency is everything.
japanese: 動（うご）かないよりマシだよ
chinese: 动起来总比不动强 (Dòng qǐlái zǒngbǐ búdòng qiáng) / 有动静总比没有好 (Yǒu dòngjing zǒngbǐ méiyǒu hǎo)
spanish: Peor es nada. / Algo es algo.

primary: You have to learn the ropes.
similar: You need to understand how things work here.
Learn the basics of the job.
Figure out the routine and unspoken rules.
Acquire the necessary skills for this environment.
example:
A: It's my first week here and I feel so overwhelmed by all the systems.
B: Don't worry, you just have to learn the ropes. It takes a bit of time for everyone.
A: Is there a manual or something I can read to understand the workflow?
B: Honestly? The best way is to just shadowing someone for a few days.
A: That sounds much better than reading a boring PDF anyway.
B: Facts. You'll catch on much faster once you see it in action.
japanese: コツを覚（おぼ）えないとね
chinese: 你得懂行 (Nǐ děi dǒngháng) / 你得摸清门道 (Nǐ děi mōqīng méndào)
spanish: Tienes que agarrarle la onda. / Tienes que aprender cómo funciona esto.

similar: He's exploiting the situation for all it's worth.
He's dragging it out for personal gain.
He's being greedy with the opportunity.
He's making a big deal out of it just to get attention.
example:
A: Did you see his latest post about that minor injury from two weeks ago?
B: Man, he's totally milking it for likes and sympathy at this point.
A: I know! He's still wearing a 'brace' that clearly isn't even for his arm.
B: For real. It's so obvious what he's doing. Everyone sees through it.
A: People really do anything for clout these days, no cap.
B: Facts. It's actually kind of embarrassing to watch, honestly.
japanese: 彼（かれ）、調子（ちょうし）に乗（の）ってるね
chinese: 他在利用这一点 (Tā zài lìyòng zhè yìdiǎn) / 他在过度消费 (Tā zài guòdù xiāofèi)
spanish: Le está sacando el jugo. / Se está aprovechando.

meaning: 좋은 것만 골라 가질 순 없어요.
similar: You have to take the good with the bad.
Don't just choose the easy parts.
Take the whole package as it is.
Consistency matters across everything, not just the fun stuff.
example:
A: I only want to work on the creative side of the business, not the admin stuff.
B: Look, it's a small team. You can't cherry pick the tasks you like.
A: But I'm way better at designing things than I am at spreadsheets!
B: I get it, but we all have to do the boring work too. It's part of the job.
A: Fine, I'll start working on those reports this afternoon then.
B: Facts. Thank you for being a team player. It makes a difference.
japanese: いいとこ取（ど）りはできないよ
chinese: 你不能挑三拣四 (Nǐ bùnéng tiāosānjiǎnsì) / 不能只挑好的 (Bùnéng zhǐ tiāo hǎo de)
spanish: No puedes escoger solo lo bueno. / Tienes que aceptar todo, no solo lo que te gusta.

similar: You identified the core issue correctly.
example:
A: I think the real reason we're losing customers is the confusing checkout process.
B: You hit the bullseye! I've been saying that for months but no one listened.
A: It just feels like there are too many steps and it's frustrating.
B: For real. We need to simplify it ASAP if we want to save our sales.
A: I'll start working on a redesign concept tomorrow morning.
B: Facts. That should be our number one priority right now.
japanese: 図星（ずぼし）だね
chinese: 你说到点子上了 (Nǐ shuō dào diǎnzi shàng le) / 正中红心 (Zhèngzhòng hóngxīn)
spanish: Diste en el clavo. / Acertaste.

similar: Does the name really matter that much?
The name isn't the most important part.
A name doesn't define the essence.
It's what's inside that counts, not the label.
Why focus so much on the title or name?
example:
A: They're changing the brand name from 'TechGuru' to 'SmarterThings'.
B: Honestly? What's in a name? As long as the product still works, I don't care.
A: It sounds a bit more modern, but I'll miss the original vibe.
B: For real. People worry way too much about branding these days, no cap.
A: I guess it's just about staying competitive in the market, right?
B: Facts. But ultimately, the service is what keeps people coming back.
japanese: 名前（なまえ）なんて飾（かざ）りだよ
chinese: 名字有什么重要的？ (Míngzi yǒu shénme zhòngyào de?) / 叫什么无所谓 (Jiào shénme wúsuǒwèi)
spanish: ¿Qué importa el nombre? / El nombre es lo de menos.

similar: He backs up his words with actions.
He's a man of action, not just talk.
He's reliable and does what he says he will.
example:
A: I wasn't sure about the new manager, but he's actually helping us with the heavy lifting.
B: Yeah, he's great. He really walks the walk. No more just barking orders.
A: It's so refreshing to have a leader who isn't afraid to get their hands dirty.
B: For real. The morale of the team has improved so much since he started.
A: I actually feel motivated to work harder when he's around.
B: Facts. That's the difference between a boss and a real leader.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は有言実行（ゆうげんじっこう）タイプだ
chinese: 他言行一致 (Tā yánxíng yízhì) / 他说到做到 (Tā shuōdào zuòdào)
spanish: Él demuestra con hechos. / Él cumple lo que dice.

primary: We'll cross that bridge when we come to it.
similar: Let's not worry about that until it happens.
We'll deal with that problem later.
Save that discussion for when it's relevant.
No need to stress about potential future issues now.
example:
A: What if the client rejects the whole concept after we've already built it?
B: You know what? We'll cross that bridge when we come to it. Focus on the now.
A: I just want to have a backup plan just in case things go south.
B: I hear you, but let's not waste energy on 'what ifs' right now. Let's build it.
A: Alright, alright. I'm staying focused on the current phase.
B: Facts. That's the only way we're gonna finish this on time anyway.
japanese: その時（とき）になったら考（かんが）えよう
chinese: 船到桥头自然直 (Chuán dào qiáotóu zìrán zhí) / 到时候再说 (Dàoshíhou zài shuō)
spanish: Ya nos preocuparemos de eso cuando llegue el momento. / Cada cosa a su tiempo.

similar: Wait for things to calm down first.
Let's wait for the initial reaction to pass.
Give it some time to normalize.
Don't make a move until the situation is clear.
Patience is key right now, let's wait.
example:
A: Everyone is so upset after the announcement this morning!
B: I know. Let's let the dust settle before we try to explain anything else.
A: People need time to process the news, for real.
B: Exactly. Acting impulsively right now will only make things more heated.
A: We'll have a formal follow-up meeting next week then.
B: Facts. By then, cooler heads should hopefully prevail.
japanese: ほとぼりが冷（さ）めるのを待（ま）とう
chinese: 等风头过去再说 (Děng fēngtóu guòqù zài shuō) / 先等等看 (Xiān děngdeng kàn)
spanish: Deja que se calmen las aguas. / Esperemos a que pase el alboroto.

primary: He was as hard as nails.
similar: He was incredibly tough and unsympathetic.
He had a cold and unyielding personality.
He was very stern and strict.
He was emotionally distant and harsh.
He didn't show any mercy or weakness.
example:
A: I heard the old professor was absolute nightmare to work with.
B: Man, he was as hard as nails. He never gave anyone a break, no cap.
A: No matter how hard I studied, I could never get a grade higher than a B-.
B: For real. He used to fail people for the smallest mistakes. It was brutal.
A: Some people are just built differently, in a bad way.
B: Facts. I'm just glad I finally finished his class and moved on.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は冷徹（れいてつ）だったよ
chinese: 他心如铁石 (Tā xīnrútiěshí) / 他很冷酷 (Tā hěn lěngkù)
spanish: Era duro como una piedra. / No tenía compasión.

primary: You have what it takes to succeed.
similar: You possess the necessary skills and qualities.
You're capable of achieving great things.
You have the potential to win.
I believe in your ability to make it happen.
example:
A: I'm really nervous about starting my own business from zero.
B: Look, you have what it takes to succeed. You're hardworking and smart.
A: Do you really think so? It feels like such a huge risk, no cap.
B: 100%. Every successful person feels that way at the start. Just keep going.
A: I appreciate the vote of confidence. It really helps right now.
B: Facts. I know you're gonna crush it. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise.
japanese: 君（きみ）には成功（せいこう）する素質（そしつ）があるよ
chinese: 你具备成功的条件 (Nǐ jùbèi chénggōng de tiáojiàn) / 你是块成功的料 (Nǐ shì kuài chénggōng de liào)
spanish: Tienes todo para triunfar. / Tienes madera de campeón.

similar: Be careful not to ruin your current good situation.
Don't test fate by asking for too much.
example:
A: I already got a free appetizer, maybe I should ask for a free drink too?
B: Honestly? Don't push your luck. They've already been very generous today.
A: But the service was a bit slow at first! I think I deserve it.
B: Chill. You got a whole meal for fifty percent off. Just enjoy it and move on.
A: Alright, alright. I'll just be happy with what I got.
B: Facts. Don't be that guy who always wants more than his fair share.
japanese: 調子（ちょうし）に乗（の）るなよ
chinese: 别得寸进尺 (Bié décùnjìnchǐ) / 别不知好歹 (Bié bùzhī hǎodǎi)
spanish: No tientes a la suerte. / No abuses de tu suerte.

primary: I'm at the end of my rope.
similar: I'm completely exhausted and stressed out.
I can't handle any more of this.
I'm desperate and don't know what to do.
example:
A: I have three deadlines tomorrow and my laptop just literally died.
B: Oh no! I'm so sorry! Do you want to borrow mine for the night?
A: Honestly? I'm at the end of my rope. I just want to give up and cry.
B: Take a deep breath. We'll find a solution together. No stress.
A: Thank you. I'm just so overwhelmed by everything right now.
B: Facts. Let's grab some coffee and tackle one thing at a time.
japanese: もう限界（げんかい）だよ
chinese: 我忍无可忍了 (Wǒ rěnwúkěrěn le) / 我快崩溃了 (Wǒ kuài bēngkuì le)
spanish: Estoy al límite. / Ya no aguanto más.

similar: What a coincidence to see you here!
Strange to meet you in this place!
Isn't it funny how things work out?
What a tiny world we live in!
example:
A: Wait, you went to the same high school as my brother in Seattle?
B: No way! It's such a small world! I literally haven't seen him in years.
A: He always talks about how much he miss that city. It's so beautiful.
B: Small world, for real. I'm actually visiting there next month for a wedding.
A: I'll have to tell him we met! He's gonna be so surprised.
B: Facts. Let's exchange numbers and I'll send him a message.
japanese: 世間（せけん）は狭（せま）いね
chinese: 世界真小 (Shìjiè zhēn xiǎo) / 真是冤家路窄 (Zhēnshì yuānjiālùzhǎi)
spanish: El mundo es un pañuelo. / ¡Qué pequeño es el mundo!

similar: One more mistake and you're in big trouble.
You're pushing the boundaries too far.
Be very careful about your next move.
example:
A: I was only five minutes late to the meeting, why is the boss so mad?
B: Look, you're on thin ice after that feedback you missed last week.
A: I didn't think it was such a big deal, no cap.
B: It is to him. He's really big on professional and consistency lately.
A: I guess I'll have to be extra careful from now on then.
B: Facts. Don't give him any more reasons to doubt your commitment.
japanese: 危（あぶ）ない橋（はし）渡（わた）ってるよ
chinese: 你在如履薄冰 (Nǐ zài rúlǚbóbīng) / 你处境很危险 (Nǐ chǔjìng hěn wēixiǎn)
spanish: Estás en la cuerda floja. / Te la estás jugando.

similar: Let's see if I can do it.
I'll take a crack at it.
I'll go for it and see what happens.
example:
A: We need someone to lead the presentation in front of the whole team.
B: Honestly? I'll give it a shot. I've been wanting to practice public speaking.
A: That's the spirit! It's a great opportunity to show your expertise.
B: I'm a bit nervous, but I'll prepare as much as I can by Friday.
A: You'll be amazing. Just speak from the heart and you'll crush it.
B: Facts. I'm actually kind of excited for the challenge now.
japanese: やってみるよ
chinese: 我试试看 (Wǒ shìshi kàn) / 我尝试一下 (Wǒ chángshì yíxià)
spanish: Voy a intentarlo. / Le voy a dar una oportunidad.

primary: You can never be too careful
example:
A: Locking the door again?
B: You can never be too careful.
A: We live in a safe area.
B: Crime happens everywhere.
A: Okay, Mr. Paranoid.
B: It's called being prepared.
japanese: 用心（ようじん）するに越（こ）したことはない
chinese: 小心总没错 (Xiǎoxīn zǒng méi cuò) / 多留个心眼准没错 (Duō liú gè xīnyǎn zhǔn méi cuò)
spanish: Toda precaución es poca. / Nunca se es demasiado cuidadoso.

similar: We've reached the end of the project.
example:
A: We've finally edited all the videos for the campaign! Phew.
B: Awesome. That's a wrap for the whole team then. Well done everyone.
A: Can we actually go home early today? I'm exhausted.
B: For real. You all worked so hard this week, you definitely deserve a break.
A: Let's celebrate with some drinks after we drop the files off.
B: Facts. See everyone at the bar in an hour. Great job!
japanese: これでおしまい
chinese: 搞定收工 (Gǎodìng shōugōng) / 完事了 (Wánshì le)
spanish: ¡Esto se acabó! / ¡Misión cumplida!

similar: Wait for all the facts first.
Check the details before you judge the situation.
example:
A: I saw him talking to a recruiter from the rival company earlier!
B: Look, don't jump to conclusions. He might just be catchin' up with a friend.
A: But why would he be meeting him at a coffee shop near their office?
B: It could be anything. Let's just wait and see if he actually mentions it to us.
A: You're right. I shouldn't automatically assume the worst, no cap.
B: Facts. People's lives are more complicated than they look on the surface.
japanese: 早（はや）とちりしないで
chinese: 别急着下结论 (Bié jí zhe xià jiélùn) / 别乱猜 (Bié luàn cāi)
spanish: No saques conclusiones precipitadas. / No te adelantes a los hechos.

example:
A: Wanna go to a jazz bar?
B: That is right up my alley.
A: I knew you'd like it.
B: Live music is my favorite.
A: Table for two at 8?
B: I'm there.
japanese: ドンピシャだね
chinese: 正合我意 (Zhènghé wǒyì) / 也就是我的菜 (Yě jiùshì wǒ de cài)
spanish: Es justo lo mío. / Me viene como anillo al dedo.

primary: It's written all over your face.
similar: I can easily see your true feelings.
You're not hiding your emotions well at all.
Your face tells the whole story.
It's obvious how you're feeling just by looking at you.
example:
A: I'm really not that upset about the project being pushed back.
B: Honestly? It's written all over your face. You're absolutely gutted.
A: Is it that obvious? I thought I was doing a good job of staying calm.
B: Not even close. You have that 'disappointed puppy' look going on, no cap.
A: Well, I really did put a lot of effort into the initial design.
B: Facts. It's totally understandable to be frustrated. Just take some time.
japanese: 顔（かお）に書（か）いてあるよ
chinese: 全写在你脸上了 (Quán xiě zài nǐ liǎnshàng le) / 一看你就知道 (Yí kàn nǐ jiù zhīdào)
spanish: Se te nota en la cara. / Tu cara lo dice todo.

example:
A: Try this jacket on.
B: Wow, this is for me.
A: Fits perfectly.
B: I'm buying it instantly.
A: It's expensive though.
B: Don't care, I love it.
japanese: これ私（わたし）にぴったり
chinese: 这就是我要的 (Zhè jiùshì wǒ yào de) / 这太适合我了 (Zhè tài shìhé wǒ le)
spanish: Esto es para mí. / Esto me queda perfecto.

similar: There are no boundaries to your success.
You can achieve anything you set your mind to.
example:
A: With this new investment, we can actually expand to three new cities!
B: For real. Honestly? The sky is the limit for this project now.
A: I never thought we'd get this far when we started in your basement.
B: Facts. It's all about that consistency and hard work finally paying off.
A: Let's dream big for the next two years. Global domination, maybe?
B: 100%. Let's get it! The world is our oyster now.
japanese: 可能性（かのうせい）は無限大（むげんだい）だよ
chinese: 前途无量 (Qiántú wúliàng) / 没有极限 (Méiyǒu jíxiàn)
spanish: El cielo es el límite. / No hay límites.

similar: Keep working at it to master the skill.
Skill is built through dedicated time and effort.
example:
A: I still struggle with my pronunciation in English, especially the 'th' sound.
B: Don't worry about it too much. Practice makes perfect, for real.
A: I've been watching YouTube tutorials every single day for a week.
B: That's the spirit. You're already making significant progress from when we first met.
A: I hope so. I want to sound like a native New Yorker eventually, no cap.
B: Facts. Just keep talking and you'll get there before you know it.
japanese: 継続（けいぞく）は力（ちから）なり
chinese: 熟能生巧 (Shúnéngshēngqiǎo) / 多练练就好了 (Duō liànlian jiù hǎo le)
spanish: La práctica hace al maestro. / Practicando se aprende.

example:
A: Yo, you're not wearing your glasses today. What's up with that?
B: Oh, I finally did it. I got LASIK over the weekend.
A: No way! How was it? Was it scary?
B: Honestly, it was super quick. Just a bit weird seeing the laser.
A: Can you actually see everything clearly now?
B: It's like I'm seeing the world in 4K. Best decision ever.
japanese: レーシックしたんだ
chinese: 我做了激光近视手术 (Wǒ zuò le jīguāng jìnshì shǒushù) / 我做了准分子 (Wǒ zuò le zhǔnfēnzǐ)
spanish: Me operé de la vista. / Me hice la cirugía láser.

similar: What’s the wait time looking like?
How much longer for a table?
Is it gonna be a minute?
Are we looking at a long wait?
example:
A: Excuse me, we have a reservation for two.
B: Welcome! We're just clearing a spot for you.
A: No rush, but how long is the wait roughly?
B: It should be about ten minutes. Would you like a drink while you wait?
A: That sounds good. We'll just hang out by the bar.
B: Perfect, I'll come grab you as soon as it's ready.
japanese: 待（ま）ち時間（じかん）はどのくらい？
chinese: 要等多久？ (Yào děng duōjiǔ?) / 前面还有几桌？ (Qiánmiàn hái yǒu jǐ zhuō?)
spanish: ¿Cuánto es la espera? / ¿Cuánto tiempo hay que esperar?

similar: I need to use the facilities.
I'll be right back, gotta go.
example:
A: Hey, we're about to start the movie. You ready?
B: Hold up, nature calls. I gotta run to the bathroom.
A: Again? We literally just got here!
B: I know, I know. Too much iced coffee on the way.
A: Fine, just hurry up before the trailers end.
B: I'll be back in a flash. Don't start without me!
japanese: トイレ行（い）ってくる
chinese: 人有三急 (Rén yǒu sānjí) / 我得上厕所 (Wǒ děi shàng cèsuǒ)
spanish: La naturaleza llama. / Tengo que ir al baño.

similar: You can let me out right there.
Just pull over by the corner.
Can you leave me at the entrance?
example:
A: Where exactly do you need to go in this area?
B: Oh, see that coffee shop? Just drop me off there.
A: Are you sure? I can bring you closer to the door.
B: No, this is perfect. I need to grab a latte anyway.
A: Alright then, stay safe out there.
B: Thanks for the ride! Catch you later.
japanese: あそこで降（お）ろして
chinese: 在那儿放我下来 (Zài nàr fàng wǒ xiàlái) / 就在那停 (Jiù zài nà tíng)
spanish: Déjame ahí. / Bájame ahí.

similar: I definitely prefer the real you.
You have a much better vibe in person.
example:
A: Finally, we meet! I was starting to think you were a bot.
B: Haha, nope! Real human here. How do I look?
A: Honestly? You look better in person than in your profile pics.
B: Oh, stop it! You're making me blush.
A: I'm serious. The lighting in those photos was trash.
B: Well, I'm glad the real version passed the test!
japanese: 実物（じつぶつ）の方（ほう）がいいね
chinese: 你本人比照片好看 (Nǐ běnrén bǐ zhàopiàn hǎokàn) / 你真人更漂亮 (Nǐ zhēnrén gèng piàoliang)
spanish: Te ves mejor en persona. / En persona eres más guapo/a.

primary: Could you make that two, please?
similar: Can I get another one of those?
example:
A: I'll have the spicy margarita, please.
B: That's a great choice. And for you, sir?
C: Actually, could you make that two, please?
B: You got it. Two spicy margaritas coming right up.
A: Good call, these are the best in the city.
C: I was thinking the same thing after the first sip.
japanese: 私（わたし）も同（おな）じので
chinese: 请再来一份一样的 (Qǐng zàilái yí fèn yíyàng de) / 给我来个双份 (Gěi wǒ lái gè shuāngfèn)
spanish: ¿Me das dos, por favor? / Que sean dos, por favor.

example:
A: DUDE, YOU WON'T BELIEVE WHAT I JUST HEARD!
B: Whoa, relax! Keep your voice down, everyone's looking.
A: Sorry, I'm just so hyped about the news.
B: I get it, but we're in a library, not a stadium.
A: Right, my bad. Let me tell you quietly.
B: Much better. Now, what's the big secret?
japanese: 声（こえ）を落（お）として／静（しず）かにして
chinese: 小声点 (Xiǎoshēng diǎn) / 别嚷嚷 (Bié rāngrang)
spanish: Baja la voz. / Habla más bajito.

similar: Clear your head with a walk.
Take a lap and cool down.
Go for a stroll to feel better.
example:
A: I'm so stressed out about this presentation tomorrow.
B: You've been staring at that screen for hours. Walk it off.
A: I don't have time! I need to finish this slide.
B: Trust me, ten minutes of fresh air will do wonders.
A: Maybe you're right. My head is spinning.
B: Go on, I'll have a snack ready when you get back.
japanese: 歩（ある）いて忘（わす）れなよ／散歩（さんぽ）でもしておいで
chinese: 去散散心 (Qù sànsanxīn) / 走两步消消气 (Zǒu liǎng bù xiāoxiaoqì)
spanish: Camina para que se te pase. / Sal a caminar un rato.

primary: I tossed and turned all night.
similar: I had a rough night's sleep.
I kept waking up every hour.
example:
A: You look exhausted. Rough night?
B: Tell me about it. I tossed and turned all night.
A: Was it the coffee you had late yesterday?
B: Probably, or maybe just thinking about the move.
A: That's the worst. Did you try any white noise?
B: I tried everything, but my brain wouldn't shut off.
japanese: 一晩中（ひとばんじゅう）寝返（ねがえ）りを打（う）ってた／全然（ぜんぜん）眠（ねむ）れなかった
chinese: 我翻来覆去睡不着 (Wǒ fānláifùqù shuìbuzháo) / 我折腾了一宿 (Wǒ zhēteng le yìxiǔ)
spanish: Di vueltas en la cama toda la noche. / No pegué el ojo en toda la noche.

similar: I can't dance to save my life.
I'm super clumsy on the floor.
I'm a total klutz when it comes to moves.
example:
A: Hey, come out to the dance floor with us!
B: No way, I have two left feet. I'll just embarrass myself.
A: Don't worry about it, nobody's actually watching.
B: Easy for you to say, you actually have moves!
A: Just move with the beat. It's not that deep.
B: Trust me, I'll just end up stepping on someone's toes.
japanese: ダンスは苦手（にがて）なんだ／運動音痴（うんどうおんち）なんだ
chinese: 我手脚笨拙 (Wǒ shǒujiǎo bènzhuō) / 我不会跳舞 (Wǒ búhuì tiàowǔ)
spanish: Tengo dos pies izquierdos. / Soy muy torpe para bailar.

similar: My skin is going crazy right now.
I've got pimples popping up everywhere.
My complexion is currently a mess.
I'm dealing with some serious acne suddeny.
example:
A: Are you okay? You're wearing a lot of foundation today.
B: Ugh, my face is breaking out like crazy. I hate it.
A: Is it the new skincare product you tried?
B: Probably. Or just the stress from finals week.
A: Drink more water, it might help clear it up.
B: I'm trying everything, but nothing seems to work.
japanese: 肌（はだ）が荒（あ）れてる／吹（ふ）き出物（でもの）が出（で）ちゃった
chinese: 我脸上爆痘了 (Wǒ liǎnshàng bàodòu le) / 我长痘痘了 (Wǒ zhǎng dòudou le)
spanish: Me están saliendo granos. / Tengo la cara brotada.

similar: I just want to unplug for a bit.
I need to step away from work.
example:
A: You've been working late every night this month.
B: I know. I'm so burnt out. I want some time off.
A: Why don't you talk to the boss about a long weekend?
B: I'm planning to. I just need to finish this project first.
A: Don't wait too long, your health is more important.
B: You're right. I'm booking a flight as soon as this is done.
japanese: 休（やす）みが欲（ほ）しい／休（やす）みたい
chinese: 我想休息一段时间 (Wǒ xiǎng xiūxi yí duàn shíjiān) / 我想请假 (Wǒ xiǎng qǐngjià)
spanish: Quiero tomarme un tiempo libre. / Necesito unas vacaciones.

primary: I'm not good with my hands.
similar: I'm total klutz at DIY stuff.
I can't build anything to save my life.
example:
A: Can you help me assemble this IKEA bookshelf?
B: Honestly? I'm not good with my hands. I'll probably break it.
A: Come on, it's just a few screws and some wood.
B: Last time I tried, I ended up with a crooked table.
A: Okay, maybe you just hold the instructions then.
B: That, I can definitely do. Let's get started.
japanese: 不器用（ぶきよう）なんだ／手先（てさき）が不器用（ぶきよう）でね
chinese: 我手不巧 (Wǒ shǒu bù qiǎo) / 我手残 (Wǒ shǒucán)
spanish: No soy bueno con las manos. / Soy torpe para las manualidades.

similar: Help, my nose is dripping blood.
example:
A: Hey, are you okay? Your shirt has a stain on it.
B: Wait, what? Oh no, I have a nosebleed!
A: Lean forward and pinch your nose. Don't tilt back!
B: Thanks, I don't know why this happened suddenly.
A: It's probably just the dry air in this office.
B: Yeah, I should probably get a humidifier for my desk.
japanese: 鼻血（はなぢ）が出（で）た
chinese: 我流鼻血了 (Wǒ liú bíxiě le) / 我出鼻血了 (Wǒ chū bíxiě le)
spanish: Me está sangrando la nariz. / Tengo hemorragia nasal.

example:
A: Want to go for a run this evening?
B: No way, I'm pooped after that hike today.
A: It wasn't even that long! Where's your stamina?
B: My legs are like jelly, dude. I'm staying on this couch.
A: Fine, I'll just go by myself then.
B: Enjoy! I'll be right here when you get back.
japanese: ヘトヘトだよ／すごく疲（つか）れた
chinese: 我累瘫了 (Wǒ lèi tān le) / 我累毙了 (Wǒ lèi bì le)
spanish: Estoy hecho polvo. / Estoy reventado.

similar: My singing voice is a nightmare.
I have no ear for music.
example:
A: Let's go to that new karaoke bar tonight!
B: Oh man, you know I'm tone-deaf, right?
A: It doesn't matter! That's the whole point of karaoke.
B: For you, maybe. For me, it's just pure embarrassment.
A: Just pick a song you know by heart. It'll be fine.
B: Alright, but don't say I didn't warn you when I start.
japanese: 音痴（おんち）なんだ
chinese: 我是音痴 (Wǒ shì yīnchī) / 我五音不全 (Wǒ wǔyīnbùquán)
spanish: No tengo oído musical. / Canto fatal.

similar: I haven't had a second to breathe.
Life's been a bit of a mess recently.
example:
A: Long time no see! How have you been lately?
B: Honestly? It's been a little hectic with the new job.
A: I bet! Are you settling in okay though?
B: Yeah, but there's just so much to learn at once.
A: Take it one day at a time. You'll get there.
B: Thanks, I'm definitely trying to keep my head up.
japanese: バタバタしてた／すごく忙（いソガ）しかった
chinese: 最近有点乱 (Zuìjìn yǒudiǎn luàn) / 最近忙疯了 (Zuìjìn máng fēng le)
spanish: Ha sido una locura. / He estado a mil por hora.

similar: It's driving me a bit crazy.
I can't stop thinking about it.
It's bothering me quite a bit.
example:
A: Did you see that typo in the final report?
B: Yeah, but it's not a big deal. The client won't care.
A: I know, but it bugs me every time I look at it.
B: You're such a perfectionist. Just let it go.
A: I can't. I'm going to fix it and resend it.
B: Whatever makes you sleep better at night, I guess.
japanese: 気（き）になる／イライラする
chinese: 这让我很烦 (Zhè ràng wǒ hěn fán) / 这让我心里不舒服 (Zhè ràng wǒ xīnli bù shūfu)
spanish: Me molesta. / Me fastidia.

similar: Not as far as I know.
I haven't heard anything like that.
That's news to me if it's true.
I don't think that's the case.
example:
A: Did they cancel the meeting for tomorrow afternoon?
B: Not to my knowledge. I still have it on my calendar.
A: Oh, weird. I heard a rumor in the breakroom.
B: Let me double-check the email just in case.
A: Thanks, I don't want to show up to an empty room.
B: Nope, still scheduled. We're good to go.
japanese: 私（わたし）の知（し）る限（かぎ）りでは違（ちが）う／聞（き）いてないけど
chinese: 据我所知不是 (Jù wǒ suǒzhī búshì) / 我没听说啊 (Wǒ méi tīngshuō a)
spanish: Que yo sepa, no. / No tengo entendido eso.

similar: Total waste of time trying to fix it.
example:
A: Do you think we can still fix this old laptop?
B: Honestly? It's a lost cause. The motherboard is fried.
A: But I have all my old photos on there!
B: We might be able to save the hard drive, but the laptop's done.
A: Ugh, that's such a bummer. I loved this thing.
B: Time to upgrade to something that actually works.
japanese: 見込（みこ）みがない／どうしようもない
chinese: 没救了 (Méijiù le) / 没戏了 (Méixì le)
spanish: Caso perdido. / No tiene remedio.

primary: That's a blast from the past.
similar: I haven't seen that in ages!
A total trip down memory lane.
example:
A: Look what I found in my attic! It's our old high school yearbook.
B: Whoa, that's a blast from the past! Look at our hairstyles!
A: Right? I completely forgot I ever looked like that.
B: We were so young and clueless back then.
A: Honestly, it's kinda nice to see all these old faces.
B: Definitely. Let's look through it while we have lunch.
japanese: 懐（なつ）かしいね／昔（むかし）を思（おも）い出（だ）すね
chinese: 真是满满的回忆 (Zhēnshì mǎnmǎn de huíyì) / 太怀旧了 (Tài huáijiù le)
spanish: ¡Qué nostalgia! / ¡Eso me trae recuerdos!

similar: Your secret is safe with me.
I'm taking it to the grave.
I'm keeping it on the down-low.
example:
A: You can't tell anyone about the surprise party, okay?
B: Don't worry, my lips are sealed. I won't breathe a word.
A: I'm serious, if he finds out, it's ruined.
B: I get it! I'm the most trustworthy person you know.
A: Good. I'll text you the details later tonight.
B: Perfect. Consider it a top-secret mission.
japanese: 誰（だれ）にも言（い）わないよ／口（くち）チャックする
chinese: 我守口如瓶 (Wǒ shǒukǒurúpíng) / 我嘴很严 (Wǒ zuǐ hěn yán)
spanish: Soy una tumba. / Mis labios están sellados.

similar: I've got to cram for this exam.
Gonna be buried in books all night.
Time to get my head in the game.
I need to grind for this test.
example:
A: Want to grab some coffee later this afternoon?
B: I wish, but I really need to hit the books for my final.
A: Is it that hard? You usually ace everything.
B: This one is a nightmare. I need all the time I can get.
A: Fair enough. Good luck with the studying!
B: Thanks, I'm gonna need all the luck I can find.
japanese: 猛勉強（もうべんきょう）する／勉強（べんきょう）しなきゃ
chinese: 用功读书 (Yònggōng dúshū) / 啃书本 (Kěn shūběn)
spanish: A estudiar se ha dicho. / Ponerse a estudiar.

similar: My mind went blank for a second.
I lost track of what was happening.
I was in my own world.
I went into a trance there.
example:
A: Did you hear anything I just said about the project?
B: Honestly? I spaced out for a bit. Can you repeat that?
A: Come on! It's the most important part of the plan.
B: My bad, I just got distracted by something outside.
A: Focus, dude. We need to get this done today.
B: You're right. I'm all ears now. Proceed.
japanese: ぼーっとしてた／心（こころ）ここにあらずだった
chinese: 我走神了 (Wǒ zǒushén le) / 我发呆了 (Wǒ fādāi le)
spanish: Me fui. / Me quedé en blanco.

similar: Do you sell Nike shoes here?
Is Nike available in your store?
Do you have any Nike gear in stock?
Can I find Nike products at this location?
Are you an authorized Nike retailer?
example:
A: Welcome! Is there anything specific you're looking for?
B: Yeah, quick question: do you guys carry Nike?
A: We do! They're right over in the athletic section.
B: Awesome. I'm looking for the new running shoes.
A: Follow me, I'll show you exactly where they are.
B: Perfect, thanks for the help.
japanese: ナイキ置（お）いてますか？／ナイキ扱（あつか）ってますか？
chinese: 你们这儿卖耐克吗？ (Nǐmen zhèr mài Nàikè ma?) / 有耐克吗？ (Yǒu Nàikè ma?)
spanish: ¿Venden Nike? / ¿Tienen Nike aquí?

similar: Can you pick up on it?
example:
A: I tried a new self-tanner last night. Can you tell?
B: Honestly? It looks totally natural. I wouldn't have known.
A: Really? I was worried it looked too orange.
B: Not at all. You just look like you spent a day at the beach.
A: Phew, such a relief. I was stressing about it all morning.
B: Don't sweat it, you look great!
japanese: 分（わ）かる？／気（き）づいた？
chinese: 看得出来吗？ (Kàn de chūlái ma?) / 明显吗？ (Míngxiǎn ma?)
spanish: ¿Se nota? / ¿Te das cuenta?

similar: He thinks he's the center of the universe.
example:
A: Have you talked to Mark lately? He's gotten so annoying.
B: Tell me about it. He is so full of himself these days.
A: All he talks about is his new car and his promotion.
B: I know, it's like nobody else's life matters to him.
A: I'm starting to avoid his calls altogether.
B: Same here. I don't have time for that kind of energy.
japanese: ナルシストだね／自分（じぶん）が大好（だいす）きだね
chinese: 他太自以为是了 (Tā tài zìyǐwéishì le) / 他太自恋了 (Tā tài zìliàn le)
spanish: Se cree mucho. / Es un creído.

similar: By any chance, do you know?
Do you have any idea about...?
Would you happen to have information on...?
Is it something you're familiar with?
example:
A: Excuse me, do you happen to know where the subway is?
B: Yeah, it's just two blocks down that way on the left.
A: Awesome, thanks! Is it usually crowded this time of day?
B: Usually, yeah. It's rush hour right now.
A: Got it. I'll probably just walk then. Thanks again!
B: Any time. Have a safe one!
japanese: ご存知（ぞんじ）ですか？／知（し）ってたりします？
chinese: 你知道...吗？ (Nǐ zhīdào... ma?) / 你晓得不？ (Nǐ xiǎode bù?)
spanish: ¿De casualidad sabes...? / ¿Por casualidad sabes...?

similar: That will definitely go to your hips.
It's a bit of a calorie bomb.
example:
A: This chocolate cake looks absolutely incredible.
B: I know, but it's so fattening. We probably shouldn't.
A: Come on, it's a special occasion! Just one slice?
B: Fine, but we have to share it. No eating a whole one.
A: Deal. I'll go grab two forks for us.
B: You're a bad influence, you know that?
japanese: 太（フト）りそう／カロリー高（たか）そう
chinese: 这很长肉 (Zhè hěn zhǎng ròu) / 这个热量很高 (Zhèqe rèliàng hěn gāo)
spanish: Eso engorda. / Tiene muchas calorías.

similar: Give her a big hug for me.
Wish her the best from me.
Tell her I'm thinking of her.
example:
A: I'm heading out to visit Sarah in the hospital now.
B: Tell her I hope she feels better soon. Give her my best.
A: I will. She'll be glad to hear from you.
B: I'll try to stop by tomorrow if I can.
A: That would be great. She needs some company.
B: Alright, safe travels! Talk to you later.
japanese: よろしく伝（つた）えて／元気（げんき）でねって言（い）っといて
chinese: 代我向她问好 (Dài wǒ xiàng tā wènhǎo) / 替我问候她 (Tì wǒ wènhòu tā)
spanish: Salúdala de mi parte. / Mándale mis saludos.

similar: Totally decked out for the night.
All dolled up for the occasion.
example:
A: Whoa, check you out! You're dressed to kill tonight.
B: Thanks! I wanted to make a good impression at the event.
A: Well, you definitely nailed it. That suit is fire.
B: I actually just got it last week. Glad it fits well.
A: Ready to head out and turn some heads?
B: You bet. Let's get this show on the road.
japanese: キメキメだね／すごくイケてるね
chinese: 穿得迷死人 (Chuān de mísǐrén) / 盛装打扮 (Shèngzhuāng dǎbàn)
spanish: Vestido para matar. / Estás despampanante.

similar: Just because I feel like it.
I'm my own boss, that's why.
example:
A: Why are you wearing sunglasses indoors? It's literally midnight.
B: Because I can. Plus, it completes the look.
A: You look ridiculous, you know that, right?
B: Maybe, but I'm comfortable, and that's all that matters.
A: I guess there's no arguing with that logic.
B: Exactly. Now, pass me that drink.
japanese: 私（わたし）の勝手（かって）でしょ／やりたいからやるの
chinese: 因为我乐意 (Yīnwèi wǒ lèyì) / 我喜欢，你管着吗 (Wǒ xǐhuan, nǐ guǎn zhe ma)
spanish: Porque puedo. / Porque quiero y puedo.

similar: Just for the heck of it.
I just felt like it, okay?
It's just one of those things.
example:
A: Why did you suddenly decide to dye your hair blue?
B: I don't know, just because. I needed a change.
A: It actually looks pretty cool on you.
B: Thanks! I was worried it might be too much.
A: Nah, it's a vibe. Very bold move.
B: I'm glad I did it then. No regrets!
